Support for audit activities Personnel resources Personnel allocation As a result of the difficult situation of public finances in Europe, the Court continued the staff reduction of 1% per year over a period of five years (2013-2017), as laid down in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013.
As a result, staff in 2014 was reduced from 891 to 882 temporary officials and staff (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the posts in total, 561 are allocated to the audit chambers (including 113 staff in the members' cabinets).
In 2014, with a view to achieving the best possible use of resources, possibilities for increasing efficiency through the unification of procedures were once again identified and implemented in all activities.
The redeployment of staff from support to audit services was also continued in 2014.
However, this was compensated by the shift of certain support services from members' cabinets into an administrative pool and the transfer of the Communication and Institutional Relations Unit to the President's services.
51 Recruitment The Court's employees have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions, and the staff consists of both civil servants and operators with temporary contracts.
In 2014, an internal selection procedure for grade AST 1 and a selection procedure for the recruitment of a speaker were carried out.
The Court also provided placements for 77 university graduates for periods of three to five months throughout the year.
In 2014, the Court recruited 78 staff, 31 officials, 29 temporary staff, 13 contract staff and five seconded national experts.
The number of vacancies has been close to 3% since 2011 (on 31 December 2014 there were 27 vacancies).

Supporting audit activities 55 Support services Professional training For the further development of the Court as a professional examination body and for the optimal use of its existing knowledge, as well as the expertise and expertise at its disposal, continuous training of staff is necessary in order to be able to keep pace with professional developments and to acquire new skills.
In 2014, the Court's staff (auditors and other employees) completed on average eight days of professional training.
The proportion of language courses in continuing vocational training continues to decline.
In 2014, this represented 43% of the total number of training days (compared to 46% in 2013).
To make the best use of existing resources and technologies, the Court has been offering its employees individually tailored e-learning courses and training activities since 2014 in the form of integrated learning, in which the participants complete the general theory in an online training course before the presence event.
In addition, the objective of exchanging existing internal knowledge and providing the Court's auditors with the most up-to-date information on developments in the public sector audit process has continued to organise presentations of internal and external experts on developments in audit and other relevant areas.
Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its communication objectives by providing the results it provides in the languages of EU citizens.
In 2014, the total translation volume was 4% higher than in 2013.
More than 98% of the translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate further expanded the direct participation of translators in the Court's audit and core business: translators provided linguistic support on 40 audit visits throughout the EU and in drafting audit reports.
In 2014, the Translation Directorate focused on quality assurance.
For this purpose, the first quality assurance manual was adopted in the translation sector and a system for customer feedback was developed.
Finally, in order to make the services more efficient, the process of translation work has been reviewed and optimised.In cooperation with the Information Technologies Directorate, the automation of the process has begun.
Support for audit activities 56 All processes related to the development and provision of instruments have been carried out in order to ensure the security and continuity of operations: for example, in 2014 after the new K3 building had been purchased, a comprehensive test was carried out on the re-initiation of a breakdown of IT systems (disaster recovery), and central IT components have been modernised (e.g. introduction of the Court's e-mail system migration).
Administration and infrastructure The role of the Finance and Support Services Directorate is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its strategic objectives, and to ensure that the necessary financing, internal controls and accounting mechanisms are available to support all the Court's activities.
In 2014, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economic.
An environmental management system for the Court is currently being developed in line with the principles of the Community system for environmental management and audit (EMAS), with certification to be obtained by the end of 2016.
In 2014, a number of measures were successfully implemented, which yielded concrete results and demonstrate the Court's commitment to the environment, including: • adoption of an environmental policy; • implementation of an environmental analysis and an assessment of compliance with environmental law; • increasing the number of campaigns to sensitize employees to environmental concerns from four in 2013 to eight in 2014; • obtaining BREEAM environmental certification (the world's leading method for designing and evaluating sustainable buildings) for the K3 building and maintaining the certification mark for good waste management; • promoting sustainable transport among workers by providing a new bicycle room with showers and changing areas for cyclists, by installing an electric car charging station and by reserving good parking places for cycling communities.
Support for audit activities 57 Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union.
The Court's budget accounts for around 0.093 % of total EU expenditure and 1.58% of total administrative expenditure.
In 2014, the overall budget execution rate was 98.8%, compared with 92% in 2013.
The higher execution rate is mainly due to better estimation and planning of expenditure in Title 1, which achieved an average execution rate of 98.8%.
For Title 2, the average execution rate was 98.4%.

Supporting audit activities 59 Auditing and accountability Internal audit of the Court The internal auditor advises the Court on risk control issues by giving opinions on the quality of management and control systems and recommendations to improve the conditions for handling operations and to promote sound financial management.
The internal auditor also supports the work of the external auditor, whose mission is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
The internal auditor reported to the Court on the results of the audits carried out during 2014, the findings, the recommendations and the measures taken on the basis of those recommendations.
The Court reports annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work.
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit certified compliance with the definition of internal audit, code of conduct and standards established by the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA).
This certification was the result of a comprehensive quality evaluation of the Court's internal audit carried out by an external evaluator, Deloitte SARL, at the request of the Internal Auditor and the Internal Audit Committee. Furthermore, it met the IIA's international standards for internal audit professional practice.
External audit of the Court The Court's annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same transparency and accountability principles to itself as to its audited bodies.
The auditor's report – Pricewaterhouse‐ Coopers SARL – on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2013 was published on 18 September 2014.
The audit opinion of the independent auditor – Financial year 2013 On the annual accounts: "We are convinced that the annual closure will give a true picture of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2013, its profitability and cash flows for the year ending on that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Eura‐tom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules of application of the Financial Regulation.
Declaration by the 60 authorising officer by delegation The undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declares, in his capacity as authorising officer by delegation, that the information contained in this report is accurate and accurate, and confirms with sufficient certainty that the resources provided for the activities described in this report have been used for the purposes envisaged and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, and that the control procedures established provide the necessary guarantees for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and for the proper handling of fraud or suspicions of fraud, costs and benefits of the controls are appropriate.
This security is based on the assessment of the undersigned and on the information available to him, such as the reports and statements of the authorising officers by subdelegation, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's audit reports on previous financial years.
Done at Luxembourg, 26 February 2015 Eduardo Ruiz García Secretary-General

European Court of Auditors, HEADINGS OF EU FINANCING
European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
He has 28 members – one from each EU Member State – and employs around 900 staff from all EU Member States in the audit and administration field.
Since its establishment in 1977, the Court has been committed to better EU financial management and better accounting.
Functions of the Court The Court shall verify that the EU funds have been properly recorded and taken up and spent in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations and that the best use is made.
It warns against risks, provides security and provides guidance to EU policy-makers on how to improve public financial management and ensure that European citizens know how to use their money.
Through its audit work and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and sustainability of the European Union.

Foreword by President 04 Dear reader, in 2015, to which the present activity report refers, the European Union was once again faced with major challenges: significant developments in the EU's governance, policy and financial management, including the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the introduction of the Single Resolution Mechanism for banks in the euro area.
These and other developments have led to new audit tasks for the Court.
In 2015, we also reviewed the activities of the EU institutions and other bodies, as well as all EU funds paid to Member States, countries outside the EU, international organisations and other beneficiaries.
In accordance with our obligations under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have prepared annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds, as well as special annual reports on the accounts of more than 50 EU agencies and other bodies.
In addition, we produced 25 special reports on numerous topics, the results of which are summarised in the present activity report.
We would like to draw your attention in particular to two special reports: our report on the emissions trading system, which shows that our work goes beyond purely financial matters, and our report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which is part of a series of new special reports on financial and economic governance.
In addition, we delivered eight opinions last year on new or amended EU legislation with significant financial implications, including an opinion on the Regulation establishing the EFSI.
In order to make a difference with our work, we need to pass on the lessons learned to stakeholders at EU and national level.
During the year, we have further deepened our cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union – our main partners in ensuring EU accountability.
We presented the results of our audits to an increasing number of specialised committees of these bodies, and we took their concerns into account when planning future audits.
The Court also paid high-level visits to the Member States in order to strengthen partnerships with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies.
In 2015, we organised two notable conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and the other in Luxembourg on the future of development aid against the background of the new United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
We also prepared a major internal reform in order to better respond to continuous developments within the European Union.
This report explains some important changes that we have made in relation to our relations with stakeholders, our audits and our resources.
In addition, you will receive important information about our human resources management, finances and achievements and the results of our internal and external audits of the past year as well as about the recent annual discharge procedure.
I hope that this report will give you a useful and interesting overview of the Court's activities in 2015, and with these activities we want to fulfil our mission of improving EU financial management, promoting accountability and transparency and protecting the financial interests of EU citizens.
05 Our activities Our management • Annual reports on the EU general budget • and the European Development Funds for the financial year 2014, which essentially contain the Statements of Assurance and the audit results. • 52 special annual reports with the Court's audit opinions on the accounting of the individual agencies and other bodies of the EU and two summary reports. We carried out an internal reform to streamline our audit and reporting procedures and allow greater flexibility in the management of our resources. • 25 special reports on certain management topics and budgetary areas, including the emissions trading system, youth employment programmes and assistance during the financial crisis. • 8 opinions on new or amended EU legal acts and other decisions affecting financial management, from the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the amended regulation on the Single Resolution Mechanism. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our addressees, including two high-level conferences on EU accountability, one on the security of energy supply and the other on the future of development assistance.
We continued our equal opportunities policy with regard to recruitment and personnel management. • We made considerable progress in integrating audit management and audit documentation information systems. We also made audit-related information available on mobile devices. The premises of the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg.
Our activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions form an important link in the EU's accountability chain, as they are used to hold the bodies responsible for the budget management of the EU accountable, especially in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
These bodies are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies.
In areas with shared management, Member States also have an important role to play, as in expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures.
Our three main products are: • Annual reports which essentially cover the results of audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the European Union budget and of the European Development Funds (EDF), but also aspects of financial management and performance aspects.
• Special reports presenting the results of selected economic or compliance audits on specific expenditure or policy areas or on budgetary or management issues. • Comments on new or amended legal acts affecting financial management and other products based on analyses, either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative.
We strive to manage our resources in a way that ensures an appropriate balance between our various activities, while well covering the various areas of the EU budget and achieving sound results.
In 2015, we used a significant share of our resources to draw up the annual Statements of Assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports.
The work on which the Statement of Assurance is based includes the two aspects on which we have to deliver an annual audit opinion in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We also take into account, as far as possible, the work of other auditors (see section on the examination of EU agencies on page 14) and the management declarations in the form of the Annual Activity Reports of the Directors-General of the Commission.
In addition to statutory audits, we will choose specific expenditure or policy areas at our own discretion. This is based on criteria such as the risk of irregularities or inadequate performance, potential for improvement and public interest.
We select these topics completely independently, but take into account the positions of our addressees.
In 2015, we produced 25 special reports, which are in particular the result of our audit work.
The summaries of the special reports are presented in this activity report (pp. 15-33).
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or amended regulations and regulations (p. 34).
In particular, we would like to draw attention to our opinion on the EFSI in order to clarify both the issue and the impact of our opinions.
All audit reports and opinions are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 audit visits in 2015 While most of the audit work was carried out at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also carried out audit visits to Member State authorities, other beneficiaries of EU funds within and outside the European Union (including organisations involved in the award of EU funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and other EU institutions, agencies and bodies.
Through these visits, we obtained direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the authorisation, administration, collection and payment of EU funds, as well as from the respective final recipients.
Our audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners, and the duration of an inspection visit may be a few days, but also several weeks.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depend on the type of audit and, where appropriate, sample selection.
The number of visits may therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
Within the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited.
In 2015, the Court's auditors spent 4 310 days with on-the-spot audits – in Member States and outside the EU – and obtained audit evidence for annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports).
They also spent a lot of time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralised agencies and bodies throughout the EU.
The field audits took less days than in 2014.
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technologies such as secure data and documents exchange and video conferencing.
Detecting fraud Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases in which we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities.
In combating fraud against the EU budget, the Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
We shall forward to OLAF any suspicion of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the EU's financial interests during our audit work.
OLAF will then follow up these cases, which will decide on possible investigations and, where appropriate, cooperate with the authorities of the Member States.
In 2015, we forwarded 27 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16 cases).

Our activities 10 Annual reports on the 2014 financial year In 2015, we devoted most of our audits to accounting and compliance audits to the implementation of the EU budget for the 2014 financial year.
The 2014 Annual Report from this work was published on 10 November 2015 and presented to our audience, including the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Economy and Finance Council), national parliaments and governments, as well as the media.
The main objective of our annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in assessing the quality of EU financial management by presenting findings and conclusions.
In the 2014 Annual Report, we provide a assurance of the use of EU funds in the financial year under review and highlight areas where the risk of EU funds not being used properly was greatest.
In addition, we analyse why errors have occurred and make useful and cost-effective recommendations on possible improvements.
We have revised the structure of our annual report on the financial year 2014 in order to make the report more readable.
The headings of the chapters now correspond to those of the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
The core element of the report remains the Statement of Assurance, in which we deliver our audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and on compliance with revenue and expenditure rules.
In addition, we have specifically assessed all the EU's key areas of activity and provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management.
The report shall also include information on the performance of the EU budget and on the Commission's performance reporting, in particular with a view to making progress towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.
President Vítor Caldeira presents the European Parliament with the Annual Report 2014 of the European Court of Auditors. EU expenditure in 2014 amounted to 142.5 billion euros = nearly 300 euros per citizen
Our activities 11 The key statements of the 2014 Annual Report The European Court of Auditors calls for a new approach to EU investment and expenditure. - The reliability of the EU's accounts was confirmed for 2014. - Revenues were lawful and correct in 2014. - Payments were substantially affected by errors in 2014.
Conclusions and recommendations 是 The 2014 EU annual accounts were properly drawn up in accordance with international principles and give a true picture of the situation.
Therefore, we were once again able to give an unqualified opinion on their reliability.
However, we gave a failed audit opinion on the regularity of payments. 的 The estimated error rate, which measures the extent of the irregularities, is 4.4% for 2014 payments, close to the error rate for 2013 (4.5%) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2%. 的 The estimated error rates we have calculated were equal (4.6%) for expenditure subject to shared management with Member States and for expenditure directly managed by the Commission.
The highest error rates were recorded for expenditure under the heading 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion' (5.7%) and 'competitiveness for growth and employment' (5.6%).
For administrative expenditure, the lowest estimated error rate (0.5 %) has been calculated. There is a clear link between expenditure types and error rates.
The estimated error rate for reimbursement schemes (5.5%), where the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities on the basis of cost statements drawn up by beneficiaries, is twice the estimated error rate for payment entitlement-based schemes (2.7%), where not costs are reimbursed, but payments depend on compliance with certain conditions.
Without these measures, the estimated total error rate would have been 5,5 %.
The Commission needs further improvement with regard to risk assessment and the impact of corrective action. If the Commission, Member State authorities and independent auditors had used all the information available to them, they would have been able to prevent or detect and correct a significant part of the errors prior to their occurrence.
The Commission should take action to address this persistent problem.
Partnership agreements and programmes do not sufficiently take into account the objectives of Europe 2020 by Member States.
These two aspects enable the Commission to monitor and report on the performance and contribution of the EU budget to Europe 2020 only on a limited basis. 我 The upcoming mid-term review of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework is crucial for the management of EU expenditure.
It is important that the Commission analyse the areas with persistently high error rates as soon as possible, assess the possibilities for reducing those error rates, paying greater attention to the performance of expenditure.
