Overall results 12 The Court analyses the contribution of the various types of error and the different areas of expenditure to the estimated total error rate (see Graph 6).
Expenditure that did not meet the necessary conditions to be claimed under EU-funded projects had the largest share of the estimated total error rate (inclusion of ineligible costs in cost statements: 39% or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
Second, there were projects where either the object(s) financed or the beneficiary should not have been funded under the applicable rules (non-eligible projects/activities or beneficiaries: 22 % or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
As the largest expenditure area with the highest estimated error rate, regional policy, transport and energy contribute by far the most to the estimated overall error rate (44% or 2.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
The agricultural sector: market support and direct payments, where expenditure was almost the same, contribute roughly half as much to the estimated overall error rate.
Corrective measures have a positive impact on the error rate Member States and the Commission are applying corrective measures to protect the EU budget in cases of ineffective control systems or irregular expenditure.
If such corrective measures had not been taken in respect of the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate would have been 6,3 % instead of 4,7 %.
However, the estimated error rate could be significantly further reduced by better application of existing control systems and corrective measures.
The Court noted that the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors in a large part of the error in the areas of shared management before requesting a refund from the Commission.
For example, this would have reduced the estimated error rate in regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9% to 3.9%, in rural development, environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0% and in employment and social affairs from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges for the presentation of reliable financial information Reporting on the corrective adjustments mentioned above does not clearly distinguish between the main types of corrective adjustments and the information is largely provided outside the accounting system.
This makes more detailed analysis more difficult and reduces the accuracy of the figures presented in the accounts and related financial reporting.
A further development is the increasing use of financial instruments to support investment in potentially economically viable projects in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms.
Due to its complex structure, financial instruments require particular care in assessing and recording them in accordance with internationally recognised public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in amounts to be financed from future budgets Among the main features of the budget and financial management of the EU in 2013 are: ο a strong increase in the volume of payments that the Commission was allowed to make through amending budgets: 9.6% of the initial budget; ο a sustained increase in commitments that will give rise to payments in the future (by 2.6%) despite the high level of payment; ο an unchanged period (on average more than two years) between the date of the initial commitment and the date on which the expenditure declarations are accepted by the Commission; ο only 37% of the appropriations allocated to financial instruments were disbursed to final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; ο repayments, interest and dividends of EUR 259 million accumulated since 2008 were not recognised as revenue.
What are obligations and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements: obligations (payments to be paid in the current or coming years) and payments (covering payments paid in the current year).
Payments can only be made against valid commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitments and payments are laid down in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and Parliament.
The nature of EU spending programmes, in particular the long period between commitment and payment, is putting increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This is reflected in a significantly higher budget for payments in 2013, and this trend will continue in a similar way in future budgets.
Overall Results 14 How can budgetary management and financial management be improved, according to the Court, by providing ο more meaningful information on the operation of the correction mechanisms (time, origin and nature) and the accuracy of the corresponding figures by recording information within traditional accounting systems; ο gathering and evaluating all financial instruments and financial instruments in accordance with internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector, in particular by means of reliable procedures for the identification and recording of impairments; ο providing information on cash resources held until payment to final beneficiaries; ο preparing and publishing a long-term cash flow forecast that is updated annually; this would make it easier for the stakeholders concerned to identify future payment needs and set budget priorities. ο improving? Do you want to know more?
Full information on the main audit findings can be found in Chapter 1 "Declaration of reliability and related statements" of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Overall results 15 EU funds and the provision of results EU funds should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
Against this background, it is necessary to achieve good performance inputs (financial, personnel, material, organisational or regulatory resources required for the implementation of the programme), outputs (to be achieved within the framework of the programme), results (immediate changes caused by the programme for direct stakeholders or direct beneficiaries) and effects (long-term societal changes, at least partly due to EU action).
The Court assesses these aspects in its economic audits.
The emphasis is not enough on performance In the 2007-2013 programming period, the use of EU funds focused on absorption (use it or loose it – lapse in non-use) and compliance with legislation and not good performance.
The choice of projects for EU funding was, for example, the first priority was the need for the use of available EU funds, second was the need to comply with the rules and third – and only to a certain extent – was the achievement of results and impacts.
This lack of emphasis on performance is a crucial weak point in the way a large part of the EU budget is built up.
According to the Commission, the 2014-2020 programming period focuses more on performance, with performance-related reserves being the main incentive.
By means of these reserves, the Commission will hold back 6% of the funds allocated to individual Member States until the performance is found to be satisfactory.
However, in practice, input and output indicators will continue to be largely decisive for the release of funds.
The Commission will use result indicators only in a few areas.
The effectiveness of performance reserves will depend on the success of the Commission in negotiating appropriate targets and milestones at the beginning of the programming period and in obtaining accurate, reliable and up-to-date data from Member States to determine whether the targets have been achieved.
The reporting framework is not suitable for the desired performance culture Performance reporting is spread across several general reports at the level of the general budget.
These reports do not provide any information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 Strategy objectives, nor do they provide a comprehensive overview of the results in the form of EU added value.
However, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction, in that it seeks to link the main financial programmes with the available performance information relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of each Directorate-General of the Commission, performance objectives for policy areas within their respective responsibilities are defined in the management plans, which are then reported in the annual activity reports.
The Court's analysis of the management plans and annual activity reports of the Commission's Directorates-General has shown that the assurance of reliability is limited to aspects of regularity and internal control and does not take performance aspects into account.
Moreover, the objectives would be too general to be used for management purposes and the selected indicators are not always suitable for performance measurement.
Overall results 16 The added value of EU expenditure is not always demonstrated The 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013 deal with a wide range of issues in economic impact assessments and assess whether EU intervention has been carried out in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court examined the lessons to be learned from its 2013 Special Reports on the development of the new programmes and projects for the 2014-2020 programming period and concluded that ο The EU added value could not always be ensured. ο In several cases, there were potential take-off effects, i.e. the beneficiaries had carried out the activity without EU funding.
Example: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund compensates workers affected by mass redundancies.
The Court noted that one third of the funding was used for measures that would have been paid by Member States anyway (Special Report No 7/2013 "Has the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provided an EU added value in the reintegration of redundant workers?").
Example: Risk-Sharing Finance Facility The Commission had not sufficiently demonstrated that EU funds provided under the Risk-Sharing Finance Facility (financial instrument intended to facilitate access to debt financing in the field of research) lead to higher investments than the beneficiaries would make without public funds (Special Report No 2/2013 "Did the Commission ensure the efficient implementation of the Seventh Research Framework Programme?").
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented The follow-up to the Court's recommendations as a result of economic audits is a key part of the accountability cycle and can help the Commission effectively implement the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court analysed how the Commission continued to address recommendations made in eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010 and noted that the Commission had implemented either fully or largely 79 % of the recommendations.
The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should tighten up the framework for its performance reporting at the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report contains a summary of all available information on the progress made towards achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. ο The Commission should further develop its performance management and reporting system so that it can take responsibility for the sound financial management and the contribution of the EU budget to political success. ο Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's assessment of performance can be found in Chapter 10 "EU budget and performance report" of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the 2013 budget.
All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/en/ Pages/AuditReportsOpinions.aspx.
The contributions calculated on the basis of the gross national income (GNI) of the Member States or the VAT collected by the Member States accounted for 74 % and 10 % of the revenue respectively in 2013.
Import duties and the production levy on sugar collected by the authorities in the Member States on behalf of the EU accounted for 10 % of the EU's revenue, while the remaining 6 % came from other revenue.
Explanation on the audit of EU revenue EU revenue based on GNI and VAT is calculated on the basis of macroeconomic statistics and estimates provided by Member States.
The Court's audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions relates to the processing of these data by the Commission, but not to the initial collection of these data by the authorities in the Member States.
Consequently, the Court's conclusion on the audit concerns the impact of any errors made by the Commission on the total amount of revenue.
With regard to customs duties, the Court is examining how the Commission deals with the safeguards submitted by the Member States on the claims found.
These data are not sufficiently harmonised among Member States.
A reservation is an instrument that allows the possibility of correction to be kept open for a contested element in GNI data transmitted by a Member State.
There is a general reservation regarding the Greek GNI data for 2008 and 2009, as the data are still based on provisional estimates.
This aspect is part of a problem that affects Greece's national accounts.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 19 The customs authorities of the Member States shall carry out checks to verify that importers comply with customs and import rules.
The Court noted that the quality of these controls was very different in the Member States visited.
This may result in importers deciding to notify goods in a Member State other than the Member State in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of a check and to make it more difficult to collect the duties due.
One example of this practice seems to be the case of an importer that unloaded Chinese textiles in Hamburg (Germany) who transported them to Rotterdam, where they were declared for free circulation, and then sent them to Poland for final sale.
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should work to ensure that Member States harmonise their methods for calculating data on unobserved economic activity. ο The Commission should draw up a detailed action plan with clear milestones and monitor the implementation of this action plan closely in order to tackle the problems encountered in the preparation of Greece's national accounts. ο The Commission should set minimum standards for the controls of the Member States' customs authorities in order to enable a more targeted focus on high-risk importers. Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU revenue can be found in Chapter 2 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
20 This area of expenditure comprises the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivity of agriculture, to ensure a fair standard of living for the agricultural population, to stabilise markets, to ensure supply and to ensure that consumers are supplied at reasonable prices.
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with Member States.
Yes Estimated error rate: 3.6% (2012: 3.8%) Control systems under investigation: conditionally effective Most expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land.
Many quantifiable errors are the result of inaccuracies in the beneficiaries' applications, most often overlying area data (see example).
Example: Overdeclarations – application for aid for non-eligible areas In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania*, some areas declared as permanent grassland for which payments were made were actually fully or partially covered with uneligible vegetation (density of bushes or trees).
No EU aid should have been paid for these non-eligible areas.
In Greece, this error occurred because such areas were classified as eligible grassland and were included in the agricultural parcel identification system accordingly. * Note on the designation of Member States in the examples: the sampling approach applied by the Court does not examine operations every year in each Member State, beneficiary country and/or region.
Examples of errors are intended to illustrate the most common types of errors.
They do not form the basis for conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned.
For all direct aid schemes under the EAGF, beneficiaries of EU aid are legally obliged to "obtain cross-compliance" which relates to environmental protection, human, animal and plant health and animal welfare, as well as to the conservation of land in good agricultural and environmental conditions.
If farmers fail to meet these obligations, their aid will be reduced.
In the course of its audits, the Court found that 25 % of the transactions involved in these obligations were infringing.
In the event of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before a refund was requested from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2,5 %.
More detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 21 The Court's analysis of the integrated management and control systems (IPCoS) in four Member States (Germany, Ireland, France and Italy) revealed weaknesses in the administrative control procedures and the quality of the databases in three Member States (Ireland, France and Italy), ο shortcomings in the quality of on-the-spot checks in two Member States (Germany and Italy), ο weaknesses in the recovery procedures in two Member States (Ireland and Italy).
In spite of the shortcomings identified during the audit, the IACS makes a significant contribution to preventing errors in the expenditure covered by this system.
In the Member States that joined the EU in 2004 or later, producer groups in the fruit and vegetable sector can receive EU aid.
Certain conditions regarding the number and relative size of member producers must be fulfilled for recognition as a producer group.
The Court found that nine out of the 40 producer groups examined in Poland did not meet these conditions.
In its 2013 Annual Activity Report, the Commission reported that it had reserved a risk amount of 25 % of the total expenditure under the measure in question in Poland.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations: ο The Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the full potential of the IACS is realised; for example, they should ensure that the eligibility and size of agricultural parcels are properly assessed and covered. ο The Commission should monitor the corrective measures related to the shortcomings in EU aid to producer groups in Poland. Do you want to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on market support and direct payments in the agricultural sector can be found in Chapter 3 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
22 This area of expenditure covers the policy areas "rural development", "climate and environmental policy", "maritime affairs and fisheries", and "health and consumer protection".
Of the payments in this area, 88% are to the detriment of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with the Member States.
The EAFRD will co-finance rural development expenditure under relevant programmes in the Member States.
Expenditure covers land-related measures (such as agri-environmental payments and compensation to farmers in areas with natural handicaps) and non-area-related measures (such as modernisation of agricultural holdings and basic services for the rural economy and population).
Yes Estimated error rate: 6.7% (2012: 7.9%) Control systems under investigation: Conditionally effective Most errors were due to the fact that the conditions for aid were not met, in particular the following conditions: agri-environmental obligations (see example), special requirements for investment projects and procurement rules.
Example: non-compliance with agri-environmental obligations A farmer in Sardinia (Italy) received compensation for the non-use of polluting plant protection products in the cultivation of artichokes.
In its on-the-spot check, the Court found that the beneficiary had used such plant protection products 12 times during the period under review.
Therefore, the payment of aid was not considered.
Similar cases of non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments have also been identified in the Piedmont region (Italy) as well as in Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania.
Detailed examination of the revenue and expenditure sectors 23 In the case of a significant number of error-laden transactions, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before a refund was requested from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2.0 %.
The Court's examination of the control systems for rural development revealed: ο shortcomings in the control of eligibility conditions, e.g. non-recovery of non-eligible VAT amounts or the risk of double financing (in seven of the eight Member States examined – Germany, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Malta, Romania and Slovenia; Poland was the exception); ο inadequate assessment of the plausibility of costs (in all four Member States examined – Italy, Latvia, Poland and Romania); ο shortcomings in the design and implementation of cross-compliance controls (in all four of the Member States examined – Czech Republic, Spain, Italy and Malta); the cross-compliance obligations require beneficiaries to meet specific conditions, such as environmental and social standards, in order to qualify for aid; ο shortcomings in the control of award rules (in all three Member States examined – Italy, Latvia and Poland; see for example).
For example, insufficient controls on the procurement rules by the Member State In Latvia, the paying agency was the beneficiary of EUR 2 million of EAFRD aid to finance its outsourced IT system, which was subject to public procurement rules.
The Court noted that several serious errors had occurred in the procurement process for the IT system and the subsequent data banks.
For example, instead of an open or restricted procedure, as provided for in the legislation, the paying agency applied a negotiation procedure.
Due to non-compliance with the required procedures, expenditure is not eligible for EU funding.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations for rural development: ο Member States should improve the implementation of their existing administrative controls by using all relevant information available to paying agencies.
In this way, the majority of the errors could be detected and corrected. ο Member States should ensure that the Action Plans aimed at addressing the high estimated level of rural development include all regions and take into account all measures, in particular investment measures, and that they take account of the Commission and the Court's audit findings. Do you want to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU rural, environmental, fisheries and health expenditure can be found in Chapter 4 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
More detailed analysis of the revenue and expenditure areas Regional policy, transport and energy EUR 45.5 billion Subject of our audit 24 This audit covered regional policy (which accounts for 96% of payments in this area of expenditure), mainly financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF).
The aim of regional policy is to strengthen economic and social cohesion in the European Union by reducing the disparities in development between the different regions.
Expenditure on regional policies is subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States, with projects co-financed under approved spending programmes.
The remaining 4% of this audited expenditure covers transport and energy policy areas.
Transport and energy policy aims to provide European citizens and businesses with safe, sustainable and competitive transport and energy systems and services.
These expenditure shall be managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated likely error rate: 6.9% (2012: 6.8%) Control systems investigated: Conditionally effective The Court found serious errors in the award of public contracts, accounting for 39% of the Court's estimated error rate.
The cumulative value of the 122 awarded procedures audited is estimated at EUR 4.2 billion.
Example: Unjustified free-hand contracts for additional construction work at the passenger terminal of an airport in Germany were awarded free-hand to the original contractor.
This additional work was necessary because of man-made preparation, planning and implementation of the project and not due to unforeseen circumstances.
In such cases, a free-handed award is inadmissible and the additional work should therefore have been advertised.
Similar cases of unjustified hands-free award were found in projects in Belgium, the Czech Republic and elsewhere in Germany, as well as in Spain, Italy and Sweden.
Further consideration of revenue and expenditure sectors 25 The Court's auditors also check whether EU state aid rules are complied with.
Illegal State aid confers an unjustified advantage on the beneficiary bodies and therefore affects the internal market.
Errors related to State aid accounted for 17% of the estimated error rate in this area (see example).
Example: State aid for a profitable project of a small or medium-sized enterprise (SMEs) in Slovenia has been granted for research and development activities in the automotive industry.
However, the SME was wholly owned by large companies and undertook its research activities exclusively for them.
As more stringent public funding rules apply to large companies, the company was not entitled to the entire subsidy.
Similar cases were found in Bulgaria and Hungary.
In the case of a significant number of error cases, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before the Commission had been requested to obtain them.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 3,9 %.
The Court's auditors also noted that in 2013 financial instruments continued to receive low levels of disbursement to final beneficiaries.
The funds in question support companies or urban development projects through equity investments, loans or guarantees.
The funds will be provided when their legal structure has been established and will be used to support projects.
A total of 940 financial instruments have been set up in 25 Member States, worth around EUR 12.6 billion.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should require Member States to explicitly confirm in their administrative declarations the effectiveness of the primary controls carried out by the managing authority and the certifying authority. ο The Commission should carry out a thorough evaluation of the ongoing problem of primary controls carried out by authorities in the Member States during the 2007-2013 programming period, as required by the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should analyse the reasons for the frequency of breaches of EU state aid rules. ο The Commission should reduce the continuing delays in disbursement of EU funds through financial instruments. ο Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on regional policy, transport and energy can be found in Chapter 5 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
The audit covered employment and social expenditure, which forms part of the EU's cohesion policy.
The main objectives of spending in this area are to combat unemployment, develop human resources and promote integration into the labour market.
Employment and social policy is implemented mainly through the European Social Fund (ESF): 98% of the payments made in 2013 in this area of expenditure were charged to this fund.
The ESF will support investment in human capital in the form of training and other employment measures.
In a private school in Portugal, the full salary of the school director was charged to the EU project, although he also had other tasks to perform.
In addition, the ceiling for co-financing salaries has not been respected.
The Court also found similar findings in projects in Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
In the case of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States have had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before the Commission has been requested to do so.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 1.8%.
Further consideration of revenue and expenditure areas 27 On the recommendation of the Court and with a view to reducing the likelihood of errors and administrative burdens for the promoters, the application of lump sums and flat rates was extended in 2009 instead of the reimbursement of ‘actual costs'.
In its 2013 audit, the Court did not detect any quantifiable errors in relation to the application of lump sums and flat rates.
This suggests that projects whose costs are reported using such payment options are less error-prone.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should invite Member States to strengthen controls on procurement rules, non-project-related costs or projects without EU added value. ο The Commission should ensure that Member States address the problem of imposing higher levels of staff costs on EU projects than on national funded projects. ο The Commission should ensure that Member States have taken into account all the simplification options provided for in the regulations for the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020. Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on employment and social affairs can be found in Chapter 6 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
28 This expenditure covers expenditure on external relations, development and humanitarian assistance, as well as actions for candidate countries and candidate countries.
The development projects are spread across more than 150 countries around the world and implementation bodies vary considerably in size and experience.
Support for EU funding projects is conditional on compliance with conditions laid down in specific financing agreements, as well as compliance with other requirements, such as tendering and procurement procedures.
Expenditure is managed either directly by the Commission's Directorates-General – through the central Commission services in Brussels or EU delegations in the beneficiary countries – or jointly with international organisations.
Yes Estimated error rate: 2.6% (2012: 3.3%) Control systems under investigation: Effective Most errors concerned ineligible expenditure at final beneficiaries level, such as expenditure incurred outside the eligibility period, inclusion of ineligible expenditure in project cost statements (e.g. VAT, unwarranted personnel costs or overheads) and not backed up by adequate supporting documents.
The Commission validated pre-accession expenditure for a total of EUR 150 million, although it was not confirmed by evidence that the expenditure was incurred and eligible.
The validated amounts were based on Commission estimates rather than on incurred, paid and accepted costs, supported by relevant evidence.
Following the Court's detection of this systematic error, the Commission corrected the accounting operations in question.
Example: Undisbursed expenditure The Commission signed an agreement on EUR 9.5 million with the United Nations Development Programme to promote social development in Moldova.
In 2013, the Commission accepted contracts worth EUR 1.8 million for reimbursement for which no underlying expenditure had yet been incurred.
A closer look at revenue and expenditure sectors 29 Commission Directorate-General EuropeAid manages most of the EU's expenditure in the field of external action from the budget.
The EuropeAid systems studied are assessed as being of limited effectiveness.
In May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main identified shortcomings.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should ensure that the instructions for staff indicate that final management of expenditure should be based only on expenditure actually incurred and should not be based on own estimates.
The Commission has already agreed to amend its final expenditure procedure accordingly. Would you like to know more?

30 The main component of this expenditure is research and innovation projects, which amounted to EUR 7.7 billion in payments in 2013.
The other internal policies concern spending on a number of policy objectives, including education and culture, security, migration and measures to address the consequences of the financial crisis.
Most of the expenditure is managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated error rate: 4.6% (2012: 3.9%) Control systems under investigation: conditionally effective With most payments in this area of expenditure, the Commission is reimbursing costs claimed by beneficiaries in project cost statements.
Errors arise when beneficiaries report ineligible costs that are not detected by the control systems prior to reimbursement by the Commission.
35% of the estimated error rate is due to incorrectly calculated or ineligible personnel costs.
Among other things, it claims the estimated and not the actual personnel costs and working hours that have not been spent on the project.
Apart from non-compliance with expenditure rules, reimbursement of ineligible costs is also hampered by the successful implementation of policy objectives and thus limits the added value of EU support (see example).
Example: Ineligible expenditure reduces EU added value The EU provides funding to ensure efficient and effective controls at EU external borders.
The Court examined a project in Spain involving the purchase of four helicopters, which were to be used 75 % for the surveillance and control of the external borders.
However, the Court found that only 25 % of the hours of operation of the helicopters were related to this purpose.
As a result, the EU should have paid only 25% and not the 75% actually taken over of the helicopter costs.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 31 In the framework of the research expenditure control system, the Commission checks progress reports and cost statements on funded projects before payments are made.
The Court noted that the Commission did not always apply procedures in a uniform way, which could affect the efficiency of the programmes and increase the administrative burden on beneficiaries.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that ο The Commission should provide current, coherent and clear guidance to beneficiaries and authorities in the Member States on the new research programmes for the period 2014-2020 (Horizon 2020) and other internal policies on eligibility rules and control rules. ο The Commission should make its control activities more risk-oriented by focusing audits on high-risk beneficiaries (e.g. less experienced institutions with EU support) and reducing the burden of controls on lower-risk beneficiaries.
Would you like to know more?

A closer look at the revenue and expenditure areas of the European Development Fund (EDF) EUR 2.6 billion Subject matter of our audit 33 Under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
It will also promote sustainable development and the integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the global economy.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and are subject to their own financial regulation and are managed by the European Commission outside the EU's general budget.
The environment in which external assistance financed by the EDF is implemented is highly risky, in particular because the activities are geographically dispersed and the partner countries do not have sufficient institutional and administrative capacity.

Yes Estimated error rate: 3.4% (2012: 3.0%) Failure to comply with procurement rules was the cause of around half of the estimated error rate (see example).
Another significant source of error is the lack of supporting evidence.
Example: non-compliance with procurement rules by the beneficiary The Court examined a call for tenders for IT equipment for a business information centre, financed by a micro and small business support programme.
The test showed that the contract was not awarded to the tenderer with the lowest price offer, although the lowest price was the award criterion.
The error was not detected by the auditor who audited the programme in accordance with the relevant framework agreement with the Commission.
A closer look at revenue and expenditure sectors 34 The EDFs also provide budget support for payments directly into the budget of a developing country, provided that specific conditions are met.
The Court found errors in the transactions relating to budget support, where the fulfilment of the conditions had been misassessed and where the wrong exchange rate was applied for the conversion of the payment into the local currency.
The Commission's Directorate-General for EuropeAid manages not only the bulk of external aid expenditure from the EU budget, but also almost all expenditure under the European Development Fund (EDF).
The EuropeAid systems studied are assessed as conditionally effective.
However, in May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main shortcomings identified.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should recover interest on pre-financing. ο The Commission should review the quantification of the benefits of the controls carried out. ο The Commission should report on progress made in implementing the action plan to remedy shortcomings in the control system.
Full information on the Court's audit of the European Development Funds can be found in the Annual Report on Activities under the eighth, ninth and tenth European Development Funds (EDFs) for the financial year 2013.
Background information 35 The audit approach at a glance The Court's audit opinions in the context of the Statement of Assurance are based on objective evidence obtained, in particular through audit procedures carried out in accordance with international audit principles.
The EU budget is complex.
The Commission's Directorates-General each year arrange hundreds of thousands of entries based on data from many different sources (including the Member States).
The Court shall examine whether the accounting procedures function properly and whether the resulting accounting data are properly recorded and duly presented for the purposes of determining whether they are correct. ο Analytical audits of accounting data in order to determine whether they are consistent and plausible. ο Direct verification of a sample of accounting entries in order to determine whether the underlying transactions are actually present and correctly recorded. ο Audit of annual accounts in order to determine whether they represent the financial situation properly.
1 Payments recorded as expenditure are interim payments, final payments and advance payments.
The implementation of the EU budget provides millions of payments to beneficiaries within the EU and in the rest of the world.
Most of this expenditure is managed by the Member States.
In order to obtain the necessary evidence, the Court conducts direct audits of revenue and expenditure and assesses the systems by which payments are processed and controlled.
Further information on the audit process with regard to the preparation of the Statement of Assurance can be found in Annex 1.1 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Background information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the independent audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It employs around 900 staff from all EU nationalities, composed of auditors and staff in horizontal services.
Since its establishment in 1977, it has raised awareness of the importance of EU financial management and contributed to its improvement.
The Court's audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain.
Our results are used to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's budget management accountable, in particular under the discharge procedure.
This is mainly the Commission, but it also affects the other EU institutions, bodies and agencies.
Member States also play an important role in shared management.
Our main tasks are: ο audits of the accounts and compliance audits, mainly with regard to the statement of assurance; ο economic audits on issues selected in such a way that we achieve the greatest possible impact with our work; ο opinions on legislation related to budgetary management and other important issues.
We strive to use our resources to strike a balance between our different areas of activity in order to achieve sound results and to effectively cover the various areas of the EU budget.
Background information 38 Our results We present the following results: ο Annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds; the annual reports mainly include the audit opinions in the context of the Statement of Assurance and the relevant results and will be published annually in November; ο Special annual reports on the audit opinions on the accounting of the various agencies and other bodies of the EU; 53 reports to be published in 2014; ο Special reports on selected audit topics, to be published throughout the year; these are mainly economic audits; about 25 reports to be published in 2014; ο Opinions to be used by the European Parliament and the Council in adopting EU legislation with significant implications for financial management; six opinions to be published in 2014; ο Landscape analyses on selected areas of EU policy in which major challenges and long-term trends will be analysed; ο The annual activity report, information and explanations on our activities in the year concerned.
With our work, we contribute to raising awareness about EU financial management and increasing transparency in this respect by providing a assurance of the state of financial management and by making recommendations for further improvements.
This is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union.
Information on the Court's audits of the agencies and other decentralised bodies of the European Union can be found in the specific annual reports for the financial year 2013, available on the Court's website.
The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the EU - Guardians of EU finances In its annual reports on the EU budget and the European Development Funds, the Court gives an audit opinion (declaration of reliability) on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This briefing provides an overview of the main findings and conclusions.
The full text of the reports is available on the Court's website and will be published in the Official Journal of the European Union.

As regards the financial year 2011, the period from 8 March to 31 December 2011 was therefore examined.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) Union competence under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) Responsibilities of the Agency (Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council; Commission Regulation (EU) No 838/2010; Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) Responsibilities and activities The European Parliament and the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, shall adopt measures for the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the establishment and functioning of the internal market.
The Union's energy policy shall pursue, in a spirit of solidarity between Member States, the following objectives in the context of the achievement or functioning of the internal market and taking into account the need to preserve and improve the environment: (a) ensuring the functioning of the energy market; (b) ensuring security of energy supply in the Union; (c) promoting energy efficiency and savings, as well as developing new and renewable energy sources; and (d) promoting the interconnection of energy networks.
The European Parliament and the Council shall adopt, in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, the measures necessary to achieve the objectives.
These measures shall be adopted after consulting the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.
Objectives The purpose of the Agency is to assist national regulatory authorities in carrying out the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and, where necessary, to coordinate their actions.
Tasks - complement and coordinate the work of national regulatory authorities - participate in the development of rules for European networks, - under certain conditions, make binding individual decisions on the modalities for access and operational security of cross-border infrastructures, - advise the European institutions on energy-related issues, - monitor developments in energy markets and related reporting, - draw up a proposal addressed to the European Commission on the annual compensatory amount for cross-border infrastructures under the ITC mechanism, - cooperate with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities to monitor wholesale energy markets, - evaluate the functioning and transparency of different categories of marketplaces and different forms of trade, - make recommendations to the Commission in relation to market rules, records of transactions, trade orders, standards and procedures which could improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.
Board of Directors Composition: The Board has two members appointed by the European Parliament, two members appointed by the Commission and five members appointed by the Council.
Each member shall have an alternate.
Tasks: The Management Board shall adopt the Agency's annual work programme, adopt its budget and monitor its implementation.

During the first year of its operation, ACER had to hire a large part of its staff, which was connected with problems and led to job vacancies being filled late; this was clearly reflected in the use rate of the Agency's budget.

COMMENTS ON BUDGET MANAGEMENT 11.The Agency has carried over EUR 1.9 million or 56% of the total committed appropriations under Title II (Buildings of the Agency and associated costs), which are mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
This is an operational, multiannual activity which would have been terminated under Title III of the budget.
12.In addition, the Agency has transferred EUR 3.1 million or 91% of the total committed under Title III, also in connection with the implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
The exceptionally high transfer rate of Title III is primarily due to an increase in appropriations of around EUR 3 million by means of an amending budget approved on 31 October 2013.

Our aims are to obtain sufficient certainty as to whether the annual accounts of the agency are free from material misrepresentations and whether the underlying proposals are correct and orderly, as well as to the European Parliament and the Council or other competent discharge authorities on the basis of our examination to submit an explanation about the reliability of the accounts as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying proposals.
False representations and understandings can be intended or unintended and will be considered essential if they can be expected individually or collectively to influence the economic decisions made by users on the basis of this annual accounts.
12. A review includes the execution of proceedings in order to obtain evidence for the values and other information contained in the annual accounts as well as for the legality and regularity of the underlying decisions. The selection of proceedings is at the discretion of the examiner. To this end, the assessment of the risks of essential or unintended misrepresentations in the annual accounts as well as of material or unintended misrepresentations in the underlying decisions, as well as of essential intentional or unintended misrepresentations, is carried out against the legal provisions of the European Union.
In assessing these risks, the expert takes into account all the internal controls relevant to the establishment and appropriate overall presentation of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, in order to plan practices that are appropriate among the relevant circumstances, but not with the aim of giving a judgment on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit shall also include the assessment of the adequacy of the accounting policies applied, the representativeness of the underlying assets identified by the management in the accounting and the assessment of the overall presentation of the annual accounts.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the urgent need to clarify roles and responsibilities and to analyse the workload of the contracting authority in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures.
The IAS also concluded that planning and monitoring of procurement must be significantly improved.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY AFFAIRS 18. The Agency transferred EUR 4.9 million and 86 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: EUR 1.4 million and 59 %).
As in previous years, these transfers were mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation on the Integrity and Transparency of the Energy Wholesale Trade Market(7) and amounted to 4.7 million euros in 2016 (2015: 1.1 million euros).
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency transferred EUR 1 million or 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million and 35% respectively).
19. The increase in appropriations is alarming and is contrary to the budgetary principle of annuality.
The higher transfer rate is directly linked to the conclusion and signing of procurement procedures and parts of contracts towards the end of the year, which leads to a shift of deliveries and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 sales were signed in November and December (5 976 122.47 euros and 40 % of the total value of the 2016 closed sales).
The Agency may adopt separate budgets in order to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of the activities as well as inevitable delays between contract signatures, deliveries and payments.

1), as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1946/93 (OJ L 298, 20.10.1993, p.
The Court examined the financial statements of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training for the financial year ending 31 December 1995.
Pursuant to Article 18(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76,
15), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board.
In accordance with Articles 65, 61 and 68 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93, the latter is also responsible for drawing up and presenting the financial statements in accordance with the financial rules.
The Court of Auditors is required to examine these financial statements in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki.
In order to facilitate this move, certain changes have been made to the conditions of employment of staff, some of which were not in line with the regulations in force.
The exact circumstances are explained in paragraphs 46 - 66.
In addition, a number of other cases have been identified where payments were not fully in line with the current regulations.
5. On the basis of the Court's audit, it is reasonable to conclude that the financial statements for points on page 10 11 12 are reliable for the financial year ending 31 December 1995 in so far as they accurately reflect the revenue and expenditure for 1995 and the financial situation at the end of the year.
Apart from the important exception in the area of expenditure mentioned in the previous paragraph, the underlying transactions were, as a whole, lawful and proper.
General comments Background 6. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 as a European Community satellite body and is intended to promote vocational training at Community level.
Cedefop began its work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995.
The aim of the Centre, as defined in that Regulation, is to'support the Commission to promote and develop vocational training and continuing training at Community level', to contribute 'to the implementation of a common vocational training policy' and, in particular, to promote the exchange of information and experience.
In the field of vocational training, the Centre's task is in particular to 'create documentation, contribute to the development and coordination of research, ensure the dissemination of appropriate documentation and information, promote and support initiatives which can lead to a coordinated solution (in particular in the alignment of training levels and mutual recognition of certificates) and set up a meeting place for the parties concerned'. 8. The Centre is managed by a board of 48 members (in 1995 costs of ECU 334 000 were incurred in this context).
The Board of Directors shall elect a Chairperson and three Vice-Chairmen from among its members for a period of one year.
At the time of the audit (May 1996), the Chairman of the Administrative Council was the Director-General of DG XXII — Education, Training and Youth.
The Director of the Centre shall be appointed by the Commission on the basis of a list of candidates submitted by the Management Board.
9. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Director is responsible for the daily management of the Centre, while the Board of Directors bears overall responsibility.
The Management Board shall take decisions, adopt the work programme and the annual report, draw up the revenue and expenditure plan for the previous year and the estimate of revenue and expenditure for the coming year.
10. The Commission's role, as set out in the basic Regulation, is not only to represent the Commission's interests within the Management Board, but also to adopt the work programme, to examine the annual report and the revenue and expenditure plan, and to forward the estimates of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament.
In accordance with Article 23 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 * of 30 June 1993, all commitments and payments made by the Centre prior to the actual payment must:
For the 1995 financial year, the Centre had a budget of ECU 16.50 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 10.11 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 4.67 million, with the remaining amount of ECU 1.72 million being cancelled.
From the appropriations carried over from the previous year, ECU 2.16 million was disbursed and ECU 0.29 million cancelled.
Annex 1 to this report gives an analysis of the use made of appropriations for the financial year and of the appropriations carried over from the 1994 financial year.
Annex 2 gives an overview of the budget accounts for the financial year 1995 and the balance sheet of assets and liabilities as at 31 December 1995.
Comments on implementation of the budget Separation of activities 15. Following the move to Thessaloniki, the Centre had not yet put in place adequate procedures to separate the activities of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the imprest administrator until the date of the audit (May 1996).
For example, it was observed that the accounting officer was involved in the activities of the imprest administrator.
The proportion of payments made without the approval of the financial controller is still high (in 1995 it was 60% excluding salaries).
The strong use of the paying agency procedure is not in line with the spirit of the financial rules.
A more acceptable practice would be to handle only current expenditure and expenditure in a small amount, where the risk of irregularity is comparatively low, through the paying agency.
Transfers of appropriations within the budget 17. Transfers of appropriations between different budget lines amounted to ECU 922,000 in 1995, i.e. 5.6% of the initial budget compared with 10.9% in 1994.
No. C 81/4 EN........................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................
18. The Centre did not carry out any transfers of funds between different titles in 1995.
The Court's remark (2) was therefore taken into account last year.
Transfers and cancellations of appropriations 19. The practice of transferring large amounts of appropriations already observed in previous years (3) continued to increase in 1995.
In 1995, only 61% of the final available appropriations were disbursed compared with 73% in 1994.
The proportion of commitments carried over to 1996 was 28% (compared to 23% in 1994).
The proportion of appropriations lost was 10 %, compared with 5 % in 1994.
Table 1 shows by title the appropriations carried over from the original 1995 budget and their subsequent use.
The transfers in operational expenditure amounted to 53% of the initial appropriations compared with 40% in 1994.
Since 8% of operational expenditure was spent, this means that the Centre paid only 39% of its 1995 operational budget in 1995.
At the end of the first quarter of 1996, only 34% of the appropriations carried over from 1995 were paid out under Title 3.
The large number of transfers within the budget and of cancellations and the large amount of transfers to the next financial year suggest that the work programme has not been implemented as planned and that the principles of economic management have been jeopardised.
This fact and the lack of staff (see paragraphs 42 - 45) will have a serious impact on the implementation of the 1996 budget.
The first tranche of 2 300 000 ECU was disbursed on 6 February 1995, followed by further tranches of 2 400 000 ECU on 20 April 1995, of 2 500 000 ECU on 28 June 1995, of 2 800 000 ECU on 5 October 1995, of 5 875 000 ECU on 22 November 1995 and of 525 000 ECU on 1 December 1995.
As in previous years,4 this rate of payment is not in line with the Court's annual report for 1994.
(3) Annual reports of the Court on the financial years 1992, 1993 with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation for the Centre, according to which payments are to be made in the first half of each quarter and adapted to actual needs.
Expenditure 23. After a decision had been taken to move the Centre to Thessaloniki, a new Deputy Director was appointed in 1994, who at that time lived and worked in Thessaloniki.
Staff moved to Berlin and received an establishment allowance equal to twice the basic salary. Not once a year later, i.e. after the move of the centre to Thessaloniki, the same staff member again received an establishment allowance equal to twice the basic salary.
As the transfer of the Centre took place quickly, the stay of the operator concerned in Berlin was only of short duration (11 months); moreover, he spent part of this time in Thessaloniki, and he also received the full daily allowances (including weekends) ; the Court considers that these decisions are not in line with the principle of sound financial management and are contrary to the principles of Cedefop.
24. The contract of another deputy director, who had already moved from Berlin to Madrid in July 1995', was signed by the Board of Directors with effect from 31 January 1995.
The staff member received a payment of ECU 71 030.
The Court considers that this decision of the Board of Directors is not in line with the principles of economic governance.
25. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993, allows the award of a contract on a voluntary basis, provided that the total amount of the contract does not exceed ECU 12 000.
I n at least 12 cases have been awarded over a higher amount than ECU 12 000 without complying with the procurement procedures described in Article 45 of the said Regulation.
26. Almost 40 % of commitments under the pilot studies and projects budget line for the 1995 budget (ECU 300 000) have been made in the last two months of 1995.
The budget heading 'Exchange of officials and experts' involved an amount of ECU 150 572 for the remuneration of an expert who started his work at Cedefop on 1 February 1.996 and for another expert whose contract was signed on 22 December 1995.
These commitments were made overburdened in order not to make the appropriations fall short.
27. The rent for Cedefop's temporary premises for January 1996 (22 750 ECU) has already been included in the 1995 budget.
As these expenditures relate to the 1996 financial year, they should also have been charged for the 1996 financial year and for 1994.
The Court urges the Centre to draw up an up-to-date inventory as soon as possible, as required by Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993.
29. The balance sheet shall show an outstanding amount of ECU 3 134 for an invoice issued in 1991 among outstanding receivables from the previous financial year.
The Court's comment made last year (5) was not taken into account, although the Centre had given an assurance in its reply.
The Court recommends that the Centre write off this amount until there is reason to believe that this amount will be recovered.
At the end of the year, the Centre had a remaining cash equivalent of ECU 5.9 million.
The Centre is therefore responsible for managing large amounts of cash, although it has little expertise in this area.
The Court reiterates its remark made last year (6) that this situation should be avoided by bringing the Centre closer into line with the Commission's actual cash needs on a quarterly basis. - At the same time, the Commission should ensure that the Centre receives a realistic liquidity forecast before making its payments.
The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki in Greece (7).
32. The actual transfer to Thessaloniki took place in August 1995, and in September 1995 the Centre began its activities in Greece.
According to the Court's calculations, the 1995 budget accounts contain some ECU 3 300 000 for removal expenditure.
33. Since 1 September 1995, the Centre has been housed in a building of the Institute of Agriculture and Industry of Thessaloniki.
At the latest from 1 September 1999, the Greek State will provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation facility.
The Centre has signed four agreements—(i) Annual report of the Court for the 1994 financial year.
(6) Annual report of the Court for the financial year 1994.
(7) Council Decision 93/C 323/01 of 29 October 1993, OJ C 323 of 30.11.1993, p. 1.
The basic agreement between Cedefop and the Greek State was signed in Thessaloniki on 22 June 1995.
The three other agreements, including an agreement between the Greek State and the organisation responsible for the whole construction, form part of this basic agreement.
Provisional accommodation 34. An annual rent of 273,000 ECU is payable directly to the owner for the provisional building of the Centre.
35. In accordance with Article 1 of the Agreement between the Greek State and the Centre, the Greek State shall make available to Cedefop the temporary premises, including all associated installations, as from 1 September 1995.
The Greek authorities are responsible for electrical and electronic cable connections and telephone connections.
36. At the handover of the building, the Centre did not raise any written objections.
However, during the first four months of Thessaloniki (September to December 1995), the Centre had to invest ECU 120 000 to make the temporary premises of the building workable.
Among other things, electronic and electrical cable connections as well as telephone connections had to be installed.
37. These investments were fully borne by the Centre and the corresponding costs were included in the 1995 budget.
The agreements do not give a clear indication of who is to take over these investments.
The Greek State is obliged to provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation building by 1 September 1999 at the latest.
Cedefop will pay the Greek State a total amount of 6 879 750 ECU for the construction of the building, which will be paid in four equal instalments of 1 719 937 ECU each.
For the first three instalments, the payment dates were 1 September 1995, 1 September 1996 and 1 September 1997.
The final instalment shall be paid at the final handover of the building.
39. The Centre has not ensured that these payments are linked to the actual progress of the works.
The Centre will have paid ECU 5 159 811 more than two years before the building was handed over.
The Court recommends that the Centre should ensure that interest is used for the first tranche in favour of the Fund.
No. C 81/6 EN  the Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 41. The Centre should ensure that the Employee Accommodation Organization (O.E.K.) is responsible for the overall implementation of the work undertaken by Cedefop.
Staff: General comments 42. The 1995 establishment plan provides for 79 posts, including 24À,11LA,15B,26Cund3D. At the time of the audit (May 1996) 37 persons actually worked for Cedefop (14 A, 7 B, 14 C and 2 D), 11 had been taken over by other EU institutions, 14 had left the centre before moving to Thessaloniki and 17 had decided to stay in Berlin.
In 1995 and 1996, many new employees had to be recruited, and this development will continue in 1996.
43. The 17 persons remaining in Berlin are free to work for public and private institutions or other EU institutions, while continuing to receive their salary for up to a maximum of 18 months, depending on their seniority at Cedefop (each year is equivalent to one month's salary and the minimum service period must be 6 months).
At the end of this period, the parties concerned may either move to Thessaloniki or seek another solution.
This situation means that Cedefop cannot fill these 17 posts (May 1996) because they are blocked in the budget and cannot be filled, since those concerned may decide at a later stage to move to Thessaloniki.
44. It is unclear what should happen to those of this group of 17 people who do not wish to move to Thessaloniki after the specified duration of their stay in Berlin.
Article 20 of the Staff Regulations provides that 'the official must take up residence in or at such distance from that place that he is not disabled in the performance of his duties'.
Irrespective of this, three cases of staff not ready to move to Thessaloniki have already been brought to the EU Court of Justice.
This situation, in which 17 important posts foreseen in the budget are blocked by staff who are not currently working for Cedefop, had a significant impact on the Centre's work back in 1995 and will continue to do so in 1996 and 1997.
Staff: Amendment to Article 13 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 of 10 February 1975, as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995, states: 'The staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Centre shall exercise over its staff the powers delegated to the Appointing Authority.
The Management Board of the Centre shall, after consulting the Commission, lay down the relevant implementing rules."
Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 also repeals Council Regulation (ECSC, EEC, Euratom) No 1859/76 of 29 June 1976 laying down the conditions of employment for the staff of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training.
The amendment was necessary in order to 'consistently manage the staff of the various decentralised bodies (...) at Community level' (8).
While the staff of the Centre have been appointed officials, the staff of the other decentralised bodies are temporary staff.
47. The Court examined the changes to employment conditions and other agreements between the Board of Directors and staff, and noted a number of irregularities; the most serious irregularities from the Court's point of view are described in paragraphs 49-66.
48. The Management Board has not submitted these agreements to the Financial Controller for approval.
Nevertheless, all the appropriations resulting from these agreements were settled through the paying agency procedure and subsequently received the financial controller's endorsement.
In the context of the move to Thessaloese niki, the Centre has taken the following measures to adapt the situation of its staff: — a first step, on 1 March 1995, was the appointment of all members of staff as temporary staff (Article 2(b) of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Communities), in the same grade and grade as those employed as contract staff; — a second step, these staff were recruited as EU officials as of 1 April 1995, by means of an internal selection procedure, which had finally been "ared" on the basis of qualifications.
Infringement of the Staff Regulations relating to seniority classification in the initial appointment of Cedefop's former contract staff at a time of 50 years. At the initial appointment of Cedefop's contract staff to temporary staff on 1 March 1995, none of the staff should have been classified in a higher seniority than level 3 (or in step 4 in grade A 1 (8) Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 amending Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 establishing Cedefop, fourth recital).
Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/7 to A 4, LA 3 and LA 4) (see Article 32 of the Staff Regulations, which are applicable to temporary staff in accordance with Article 15 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants).
51. Nevertheless, 33 of the 59 staff appointed as temporary staff were classified as higher than level 3.
The Centre published 15 linked job vacancies and announcements of internal competitions on 1 March 1995.
Under the Staff Regulations, the purpose of a selection procedure is to organise a competition between several candidates so that the vacancy can be filled with the best qualified candidate (Article 27(1) of the Staff Regulations).
A selection procedure is therefore by definition linked to a competitive situation and the risk of non-existence (10).
This has the effect that appointment decisions should be considered illegal following a selection procedure in which the abuse of discretion exists ( n ).
The Commission's Legal Service came to the same conclusion as was confirmed by its memo of 4 January 1995 (12).
57. Since the selection procedures in question have had a different objective than those laid down in the Staff Regulations, it is to be assumed that the selection procedures carried out by Cedefop have been subject to abuse of discretion, which is why they must be considered illegal.
Infringement of the Staff Regulations relating to the classification in grade when appointing Cedefop's former contract staff as officials 58. In accordance with Article 31 of the Staff Regulations, the staff of Cedefop should have been appointed as officials as from 1 April 1995 as follows: — officials of category A or of the Special Language Service (LA): in the initial grade of their category or their special career (i.e. A 7 or LA 7) (Article 31, paragraph 1); — officials of the other categories: in the entrance grades corresponding to the posts for which they were recruited (i.e. Β 1, Β 3 or Β 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4) (Article 31, paragraph 2); — in the case of up to half of the appointments, except for certain staff members in the next higher grade group, this applies to six posts to be filled within each grade group (Article 31, paragraph 2 b).
59. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, 32 out of 43 staff were appointed in a higher grade than the initial grade of their career (13).
10. Judgment of 29 September 1976 in Case 105/75 GI UFFRI DA v RAT, ECR p. 1395. (n) Judgment of GI UFFRI DA, see above.
(12)A selection procedure involves, by definition, the risk of non-existence and there are obvious legal reasons why this risk margin should remain.
(13)Of 17 staff members appointed in category A, 13 were appointed in a higher grade than A7 (the Staff Regulations provide for a limitation to six appointments); all five staff members were appointed in a higher grade than LA7 (the Staff Regulations do not provide for such a possibility); of 18 staff members in category C, 12 were appointed in a higher grade than the initial grade of their careers (the Staff Regulations provide for a limitation to six appointments); two out of three staff members in category D were appointed in a higher grade than in the initial grade of their careers (the Staff Regulations do not provide for such possibility).
No C 81/8 EN Official Journal of the European Communities 13.3.97 Failure to comply with probationary obligations 60. Before a member of staff can be appointed as a permanent official, he must successfully complete a probationary period (Article 34 of the Staff Regulations) and, following the probationary period, an objective retrospective evaluation of the official must therefore be carried out on a probationary basis.
In accordance with Article 38 of the Staff Regulations, only officials who have successfully completed the probationary period can be transferred to other institutions, i.e. officials who have already completed the probationary period.
65. This means that a system has been established whereby up to 50% of the remuneration of staff is transferred in a currency to which a higher correction coefficient applies (namely the correction coefficient of 111.4 % applicable to Germany) is to be regarded as Thessaloniki (a correction coefficient of 80.2% applies to Greece ).
Inequality in treatment with other officials through the introduction of special mobility provisions 66. The Commission committed itself to introducing specific provisions on mobility to the Centre.
These provisions are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all officials.
Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 clearly provides that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants shall apply to the staff of the Centre.
This means that all the provisions contained therein shall apply to the staff of the Centre, including the subparagraph (c) of Article 29(1) which concerns the taking over of officials by other institutions.
There is therefore no justification for special treatment in relation to mobility. Summary, 67. The Court's audit has shown that the Centre's work programme has not been carried out as planned due to substantial staff shortages.
This led to large carry-overs and cancellations.
The audit also showed that no functioning administrative and accounting procedures have yet been set up.
68.Two Deputy Directors received remuneration corresponding to the basic salary for four months; these payments and a payment of ECU 71 030 to one of the Deputy Directors were not in line with sound financial management and the interests of the Centre.
69. At the time of the Court's examination, there were 79 approved posts, but only 37 persons were actually employed at the Centre.
17 staff had been appointed as EU officials,' although they did not wish to move to Thessaloniki, nor had they been taken over by any other Community institution.
Conclusion 71. It is understandable that efforts were made to keep staff in the institutions of the EU and to reduce the complex problems associated with the move to Thessaloniki.
The problem, however, is that the regulatory framework "within which the move had to be carried out was not compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff, even after changes to the employment arrangements, and did not allow for the smooth transfer of Cedefop without undermining its activities.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 21 November 1996.
