The Management Board will follow the structure of the Court of Auditors' observations and conclusions.
3. The Management Board has the right to expect that all institutions and decentralised bodies will be treated in the same way and on the basis of the same technical standards and procedures that ensure equal treatment.
The Management Board considers that the uniform presentation of the problems fails to mention essential facts which could be summarised as follows: — The decision of the European Council of 29 October 1993 was taken without prior assessment of the effects of such a transfer.
At his first meeting with the staff, he expressed his firm determination to carry out the move to 1 September 1995, a timetable which CEDEFOP maintained despite the problems encountered by the transfer of the Centre. — The Chairman of the Board of Directors sent a letter to the Commissioners responsible, Mr van Miert and Mr Ruberti.
On 18 November 1994, the Chairman and Vice-Chairmen of the Management Board of CEDEFOP were received by the members of the Commission.
The Chairman called on the Commission to draw up social accompanying measures, in particular for those staff who were unable to leave Berlin.
In the light of the regulations in force, the Commissioners stated that they were prepared to examine the specific problems of some staff in a positive and pragmatic spirit.
They also expected this from the other institutions of the Community (European Parliament, Council, etc.) — At its meeting on 8 and 9 December 1994, the Governing Council was unable to decide on the date of the transfer, since it did not appear acceptable for workers who could not move to Thessaloniki without simply dismissing a modern social plan.
At the same meeting the Management Board instructed the Director to prepare a Council Decision (adopted at an extraordinary meeting on 27 January 1995) which provided for a socially acceptable transfer of the Centre to 1 September. '— In the second half of December 1994, the Council began to examine the Commission's proposal to amend Article 13 of the Regulation applicable to CEDEFOP, which provided that the staff of the Centre were subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Director adopted this amendment on the basis of the framework agreement on social support for the transfer of CEDEFOP to Thessaloniki.
On 23 January 1995, the framework agreement with the staff was signed.
The preparations were carried out in close cooperation with the European Commission, which proved to be very helpful throughout the transition period (1994-96). — The Management Board decided to accept the framework agreement and to move the Centre to Thessaloniki on 1 September 1995.
Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/13
Under the framework agreement, staff who could not leave Berlin decided to make themselves available to other EU institutions or public/privat organisations and to receive a salary from the Centre for at least six months, with a monthly salary paid for each year of service begun.
The principle of paying a monthly salary for each year of service is largely in line with the social plans and usual procedures in Germany and neighbouring countries. — Early retirement was considered in 1995 for 17 staff (aged over 55 years with 10 years of service and over 50 years with 15 years of service).
These measures were not part of the framework agreement and were finally not proposed by the Commission, following the decisions of the Council of Ministers of 17 November 1995 to accept the'release' of officials in connection with the accession of new Member States only to officials of the European Parliament.
The Management Board will respond in more detail in its opinions on points 46-66.
In general, it should be stressed that the political aspects must be taken seriously and that a subsequent criticism must be avoided.
The introduction of a complete Community body within the restrictive framework of a large number of different regulations and given a considerable amount of social and individual problems is indeed unique in the history of the Community.
5. The Board of Directors will return below in this reply to the exception mentioned in the last sentence.
The costs of the meetings of the Board of Directors in 1995 are due to the fact that two additional meetings (in January and June) had to be held in connection with the transfer.
In addition, the December 1995 meeting caused higher costs as a result of the official start of activity in Greece.
Only two meetings are planned for 1996.
13. The Management Board regrets that the Court did not respond to the European Parliament's decision to postpone discharge for the 1994 budget.
This raises serious questions, since — the discharge for 1994 in connection with the Court of Auditors' report for 1994 and the Council's recommendation on granting discharge should be seen and be in line with the usual rules and procedures; — the European Parliament's assessment of the 1995 financial year without the Court of Auditors' report for 1995 on which the Management Board could have given its opinion leads to the mix of very different situations; — the Centre was transferred to Greece in 1995.
The transfer was carried out smoothly and under acceptable conditions.
This transfer requires a transitional period, which can only be completed in 1997, as a result of the interruptions to which staff members have been exposed.
15. In this respect, there is a marked improvement.
In the early phase in Thessaloniki, staff helped each other to carry out the work.
16. As has been pointed out last year, the increased use of the paying agency procedure was made at the request of the financial controller, who justified this by the cost-benefit ratio.The previous system caused high rapid delivery costs and led to delays.
Similarly, the financial controller had to act more frequently.
The use of the paying agency procedure for all expenditure that could require provisional commitments limited administrative costs and avoided delays.
The situation is even more difficult due to the payment arrangements in Greece (most payments are made in cash or by cheque).
Invoices indicating bank links are rare; contractors collect their claims themselves.
The geographical distance to the financial controller and the lack of reliability of the mail delivery must also be taken into account.
In addition, DHL express deliveries may only be made once a week for cost reasons (3 000 Bfrs per shipment).
An amendment to the decision to set up the paying agency procedure will shortly be submitted to the Management Board in order to take better account of the Court of Auditors' wishes.
17. The transfers over the last two months are explained by the need to make optimum use of the budget (of which ECU 2 000 000 were deferred and were only released shortly before the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki) and by the decision of the Management Board (7/8.12.1995) to hire national experts seconded to the Commission (also to promote the Centre's work).
The Management Board was aware that 1995 and 1996 would be years of transition and renewal.
A certain reduction in productivity is inevitable in this international transfer, which the Board of Directors believes has been carried out in an acceptable and smooth manner.
The Centre is still facing problems caused by the transition phase.
20. Since the centre was relocated with a greatly reduced number of employees, the work of the administration and all other services slowed down.
Therefore, a non-automatic transfer of appropriations was requested and approved.
The Administrative Board notes that the Commission is making every effort to comply with the rules laid down in Article 26 of the Financial Regulation for the Centre and to pay the grant according to actual needs during the first two weeks of the quarter.
This was improved in 1995 compared to 1994.
However, due to the long internal procedures (in which the instructing authority, the financial controller and the accounting officer are involved) and the length of the bank's credit transfer procedure, a total delay in the processing period (on average 12 days in 1995) cannot be completely avoided.
Nevertheless, three payments would have been made in 1995 almost in accordance with the provisions of Article 26, since they arrived at the Centre less than four days after the end of the first two weeks of the quarter.
If the processing period for all payments (between 9 and 22 days) had been in line with the average period of 12 days, all payments would have been made in accordance with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation.
The first payment was not in line with the rules, but this payment must be preceded by the commitment of appropriations, which requires a certain amount of time.
23. The Deputy Director moved from Thessaloniki to Berlin because there was uncertainty about the actual date of the transfer of the Centre.
At the time of the appointment (1 October 1994) no decision had yet been taken on the date of the move (which could have been postponed even further).
It was to be hoped that his stay would be short, but his final duration was still unknown at that time.
For the usual family reasons, he moved to Berlin under the conditions of his status.
Daily allowances for missions were granted in accordance with the same procedure as for other servants.
With regard to the second set-up aid, the Deputy Director paid this sum back to the Centre after the audit, although he would have had full entitlement.
24. At its meeting in June 1995, the Management Board announced its contract on 31 December 1995 and instructed the Director to implement this Decision and to arrange for payments in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
The Management Board was pleased that the Deputy Director was prepared to participate in the implementation of the 1995 work programme and to support the Centre at its new start in Thessaloniki.
The compensation (the payment of one third of the basic salary from the date on which his duties expired until the expiry of his contract) was in accordance with his contract and Article 47 of the BBSB.
25. In view of the difficulties of the initial phase and the large number of new contracts, the Centre was not able to carry out the usual tendering procedures in every case.
In the case of longer-term contracts, tendering procedures are currently being carried out or planned for 1996.
In addition, in order to ensure balanced budgetary management during the year, the Management Board will prefer the adoption of the work programme so that the services can have the time to tender, make commitments and conclude contracts in the first months of the financial year.
The 40% of commitments under the pilot studies and projects budget line (ECU 300 000) were made in the last few months of the year, as a result of the late release of the appropriations in the 1995 budget by the budgetary authority and the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki.
The Centre had to act logically and consistently, leaving it with no other choice, since it was first obliged to fulfil its financial obligations under Titles I and II and was only able to make further commitments under Title III after the appropriations set aside had been released.
The possibility of seconding national experts was granted by the Management Board at its meeting in December 1995 and could only be financed by the resources deferred.
The Director had to act quickly and within a short period of time to prevent funds (which became available very late) from falling.
The application of the (Austrian) expert (officially supported by the government) was made early in 1995.
27. The reason for recording the rent for January 1996 in the 1995 financial statements was purely practical.
According to the contract, the rent must be paid in advance in two instalments on 1 January and 1 July.
Since the first payment was only made in October 1995 and it would have been difficult to pay again immediately on 1 January 1996, the first payment was made for a period of five months, including January 1996.
28. The inventory is being updated.
29. This will be complied with.
The Centre shall ensure that it submits to the Commission a realistic statement on the cash flow.
The last payment in the year should be the largest, since it must also be used to cover the first months of the following year in which larger payments are normally to be made.
31. See comments on point 4. 32. The management of the Centre shall assess the costs of the transfer and assess developments in order to gain a comprehensive picture of the costs and benefits of the transfer to Greece.
Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/15 36.-37.
Since it was expected that the Centre would resume its work immediately after the move, some additional investments and changes were needed.
As has been stated, the agreements do not provide a clear statement of this, because the centre needed more power connections and stronger computer cables than the existing ones.
Other investments concerned additional security requirements and communication facilities, such as Europe by Satellite, in order to receive broadcasts directly through the institutions.
However, the Centre has put questions relating to the provisional building on the agenda of the Steering Committee dealing with the new and (if necessary) the provisional building.
The Board is aware that the content of the agreement on the new building gave the Greek Government a great responsibility, which is currently fulfilling the agreement.
Two points of particular concern are: — securing the provision of a high quality building at a reasonable price; — securing the timely completion of the building (if possible before 1 September 1998).
The fact that large payments were made in advance (half of the building has already been paid, although construction has not yet started) may also have a positive effect, as the actual construction work (after selecting the construction plan and the construction firm in October/November 1996) could progress rapidly due to the immediate availability of the necessary financial resources.
In general, the Board of Directors fully understood the Court's concerns, which were shared by Members of the European Parliament, Mr Kellet-Bowmann and Mr Tappin, who visited the Centre on 1 and 2 May and 14 and 15 May respectively.
The Management Board is prepared to act on this issue in accordance with the Commission's recommendations.
The results of the various social support measures were very complex, but all those on the CEDEFOP payroll who were not made available to other organisations or who were seconded in Berlin were working for CEDEFOP and its work programme.
43. The Management Board has taken a decision on the social accompanying measures relating to the transfer (Framework Agreement) in order to take "appropriate measures as soon as possible" (see the declarations in the minutes of the Council).
The evaluation of the measures must therefore take into account their political background.
The Centre is located in Thessaloniki and the Management Board and the Director decide on the organisation of the work.
Certainly, some posts are blocked as long as the social accompanying measures are effective.
However, at the end of 1996, almost all the measures will expire, and then CEDEFOP will be able to operate with full capacity on the basis of medium-term priorities (adopted by the administration in November 1996) and the 1997 work programme, which will also be based on these priorities.
CEDEFOP will therefore move forward with a revitalised and new approach from 1997.
44. Persons who, for social or personal reasons, cannot leave Berlin when the fixed duration of their stay in Berlin ends have three alternatives.
In this regard, the President of the Court of First Instance declared three decisions rejecting the requests for transitional proceedings.
Such persons must move, withdraw from the service of the Centre or find solutions in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
45. The impact in 1996 is, of course, serious, but will be minimal after the first months of 1997.
The transfer had its consequences and costs.
However, when compared with a similar transfer at national level, such as that of the Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches sur les Qualifications (CEREQ) from Paris to Marseille (where only 21 of the 120 employees moved with the Centre), CEDEFOP did not have an overly negative effect given an international transfer over a distance of almost 2 000 km.
Precautionary cost estimates indicate that cost neutrality will be achieved in 2000 and that work will be even more cost-effective thereafter (mainly due to lower labour costs in Greece). 46.-66.
(c) Following the decision of the Management Board of 27 January 1995, on 6 February 1995 (Regulation (EC) No 251/95), the Council amended Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 so that 'the staff of the Centre are subject to the rules and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities'.
In spite of the lack of transitional provisions, as in the case of the adoption of Council Regulation (EEC, Euratom, ECSC) No 269/68 (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the European Communities)
(d) Since the Community legislation did not provide for transitional measures, the Management Board had no choice but to act on its own responsibility in order to safeguard the rights and interests of CEDEFOP staff. (e) It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95, which moved the seat of CEDEFOP from Berlin to Thessaloniki, meant a sudden change in the place of service listed in the employment contracts: Berlin had been the only seat of CEDEFOP since 20 years, and at no point since 10 February 1975 there was any slightest indication that this seat could be transferred, let alone to another, distant Member State.
(f) In view of these circumstances, the Management Board was obliged to: — provide staff with a high degree of security with regard to their place of work (appointment as life-long officials); — maintain their category, grade and step; and — assist staff wishing to find another job. (g) The Management Board would also like to point out that posts approved by the budgetary authority were permanent posts.
(h) In addition, the wording of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 ('the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and arrangements applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities') clearly provides for the employment of officials.
Since the positions filled by the staff are of a permanent nature, the decision on the status of officials was appropriate and justified rather than on temporary contracts.
The Board of Directors would also like to comment on the individual points raised by the Court: 46. (last sentence) The Board of Directors had the choice to appoint its staff either as life-long officials or to offer them two-year contracts (see opinion (g) above).
It was considered unacceptable to require staff to move from Berlin to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract.
Although it is true that the Board of Directors has not officially submitted the agreements to the Financial Controller for approval, the latter has nevertheless been informed of the decisions taken.
At the time of signature of the agreement, the outstanding individual decisions of staff members did not yet determine the exact financial impact of the agreement.
It provided a framework that provided the basis for individual decisions and received the full approval of the financial controller during his visit to Berlin.
50-51.
In view of the argument referred to above (e), the decision taken (see remark, second indent) was the only possible one.
The report also conformed to the Commission's clear statement (see last sentence of the declaration for the Council's minutes in the Annex) that 'there must be no deterioration in the conditions of employment of CEDEFOP's staff'.
The considerations of the Commission's legal service, which are quoted only in part in paragraph 56, leave sufficient room for such a decision.
The Management Board reiterates that Article 29 of the Staff Regulations entitles the appointing authority to conduct internal competitions for the purpose of filling vacant posts in an institution (point lb).
The competitions were conducted in full compliance with Annex III to the Staff Regulations.
The Management Board had the aim and the duty to ensure that as many CEDEFOP staff as possible agreed to move to Thessaloniki.
It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95 amended the provisions applicable to staff with effect from 1 March 1995 and that the move to Thessaloniki took place in August of that year.
The Management Board's approach was based on the following considerations: — it was unthinkable to require the staff to move to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract (recital (g) and (46) above); — there was not enough time to carry out a general selection procedure before moving to Thessaloniki, and even here it would not have been realistic to expect the staff to move without a secure commitment to employment.
13. 3. 97 I EN  the Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/17 56.-59./ The Administrative Board has already explained (see above, remark (e)) that the move to Thessaloniki meant a sudden change in the place of employment, which inevitably caused social problems and for a certain period affected productivity.
To ask the staff to move after a low grade or step has been allocated would have aggravated their situation even further.
The Commission's Legal Service note, mentioned in paragraph 56, provides sufficient arguments under point (d) to justify the position adopted by the Centre. 60.-61.
All officials who applied for appointment as life-long officials completed the probationary period laid down in Article 34 of the Staff Regulations.
62. According to note (f), 3rd indent, above, the Management Board considered it its duty to assist staff in an acceptable manner.
This view was also taken by the Commission's Legal Service.
65. The rules governing the transfer arrangements of part of the remuneration allow for the possibility of increasing this percentage from 35 % to 50 % in individual cases where there are justified reasons in accordance with Article 4 of the Regulation.
The framework agreement, in individual cases and in the case of certain liabilities provided for in the Staff Regulations which were received before 29 October 1993 (the date on which the European Council decided to transfer the Centre), enabled the transfer of a higher percentage (> 35 %' according to the Staff Regulations but < 50 %).
The application of these rules is quite different in the case of CEDEFOP and concerns only a limited number of persons with high liabilities in Berlin.
66. The Management Board would like to thank the Commission for the assistance it has provided in a number of cases in the search for alternative employment opportunities for staff who were unable to move to Thessaloniki and for any other assistance it has provided to the Centre almost daily during the move.
68. See comments of the Management Board on paragraphs 23 and 24. 69.-70.
See in particular the general comments under points 46-66.
71. The Administrative Board regrets that the legislator has not introduced any transitional legal provisions in Regulation (EC) No 251/95 in order to resolve the difficult staffing problems caused by the move to Thessaloniki.
In view of the lack of appropriate instruments, the Management Board was all the more obliged to support CEDEFOP's staff to the fullest possible extent.
The Board of Directors believes that, in the present and truly unprecedented circumstances, it has acted in the only acceptable manner.
In the end, it was obvious that he had to make such an effort (as the Court acknowledges) since his duty as an employer is to carry out the international work of an entire institution in a socially acceptable manner.
The Board of Directors, the Director and the staff acted in this positive spirit, possibly taking some risks, but not having exercised any abuse of power, nor having acted unlawfully.

The Dublin Foundation began its activities in 1976.

Financial data 7. For the 1995 financial year, the Foundation had an appropriation of ECU 12.5 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 9.3 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 3 million, with the remainder of ECU 0.2 million cancelled.
Of the appropriations carried over from the previous year, 1.9 million ECU was disbursed and 0.2 million ECU annulled.
Annex 3 to this report contains an analysis by title of the use of appropriations for the financial year and of the appropriations carried over from 1994.
Follow-up to previous observations Separation of duties 8. The Court reiterates its earlier comments that the tasks of the authorising officer and the accounting officer are not sufficiently separate.
This is contrary to Article 15 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76, which states that the principle of ‘separation of powers of authorisation and accounting' applies and that ‘the activities of the authorising officer, the financial controller and the accounting officer [...] are incompatible'.

The extent to which the paying agency is used is not within the meaning of the financial rules.

The following exceptions were found: — a contract worth ECU 533 072 for the implementation of a Europe-wide survey on working conditions was awarded free of charge. — In a sample of 26 contracts selected for examination, six contracts were awarded on the basis of Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of 1 June 1976, Council as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93.
In order to avoid the tendering procedure, Article 46 was used in three cases (supply of computers in one case and study contracts in the other).
20. In two cases it was established that expenditure had already been invoiced before the commitment was made.
In one case, accounts for November and December 1994 were taken into account for the commitment made in 1995, although the framework agreement between the Foundation and the contractor only began on 1 January 1995.

The Court held that, in the following cases, documents had been amended with the help of correction fluid: — the date of an invoice faxed to the Financial Controller of DM 45 365 (23 817 ECU) was overwritten with correction fluid and changed by hand from 17 January 1995 to 17 December 1994.
The financial controller gave his endorsement on the basis of this fax, and the change in the date'resulted in the expenditure accounting for the 1994 transfers and not for the 1995 appropriations. — The amount in a recovery order was overwritten with correction fluid and changed by hand from ECU 1 680.16 to ECU 4 741.97.
It is not clear what the financial controller's endorsement refers to.

Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/25 ANSWER 8. The Foundation has introduced a series of measures to separate the duties of authorising officer and accounting officer.
The Court of Auditors has taken note of these initiatives in previous reports.
The only problem that remains in practice is the procedure whereby the authorising officer records expenditure in the existing integrated accounting system.
This problem will be solved once the Foundation has acquired a new accounting system.
Following the consultations in 1995, the Foundation, together with other EU agencies, took part in a joint tendering procedure for the acquisition of an appropriate accounting system.
The result was, however, that none of the candidates met the requirements of the institutions 100%.
After close contact with the Commission's services, it is expected that the Foundation will acquire an appropriate accounting system from the Commission in the course of 1997 after work on an appropriate system that meets the technical and legal requirements of the agencies has been completed recently.
The Foundation has established links with the Commission's services with regard to solutions to the identified problem. 9.
The Foundation has now been informed that this issue will be discussed between the Commission and the European Parliament in the context of the ongoing dialogue on the financial regulation of the agencies.
10. Following the Court of Auditors' last report, the Foundation asked the Commission services to clarify the Foundation's Financial Regulation as regards the transfers in question.
The Foundation is now informed by the Directorate-General of DG XIX that the transfers have been carried out in accordance with the Foundation's Financial Regulation (see also paragraph 16).
11. All missions to the Foundation were documented and approved by the authorising officer after he had made sure that they were in conformity with the Foundation's work programme or administrative requirements.
The Foundation will review its procedures for recording and finding the necessary documentation on missions.
The Regulation establishing the Foundation requires that the European institutions be consulted and that the social partners be involved in their work.
Although in recent years there has been a deepening of the exchange of FOUNDATION with the relevant EU bodies in Brussels, the number of missions to Brussels has not increased.
No missions are made when other means of communication can be used.
As far as possible, telephone, Internet, e-mail and other electronic tools are used. In November 1995 a videoconferencing pilot project was also launched.
Similarly, experiments with com-puter conferences have been carried out.
14. On the basis of a proposal submitted by the Irish authorities, lawyers are currently preparing a revised lease.
16. As stated in paragraph 10 above, the Foundation has been informed by the Commission that the transfers in question are in full compliance with the Financial Regulation, which has enabled the Foundation to make the most efficient use of the funds made available to it by the decisions of the budgetary authorities.
However, the Foundation appreciates the position of the Court of Auditors and Parliament and endeavours to carry out such transfers only in urgent cases.
These contracts essentially concerned studies with implementation periods of 12 months or more.
The Foundation will remind the Commission's services once again that the grant payments must be made by the 15th of each quarter.
19. In the Treaty establishing a European inquiry into working conditions, the file in question shows that the contract had been concluded between the European Commission and INRA (Europe) under the framework contract for the 'Eurobaromètre-Stan-dard' drawn up on the basis of an open tendering procedure.
The award of contracts was entirely in accordance with the procedure laid down in Article 46 of the Financial Regulation of the Foundation and the criteria to be observed in this regard. These were followed and Article 46(d) was applied to the supply of computers.
Only one supplier had the required software as well as the special multi-spractious tastatures and provided local support: the other two contracts refer to research proposals.
At its meeting on 25 March 1994, the Foundation's Board of Directors approved the introduction of new procedures, which should be fully operational during 1995, for contracts based on calls for expressions of interest published in the Official Journal and for tenders.
The two contracts were concluded during the transitional period laid down by the Management Board.
20. The Foundation operates a decentralised ordering system.
The two invoices were part of a number of orders placed by an operational entity whose total orders exceeded the committed appropriations.
Appropriate measures will be taken to prevent this happening again.
The provision of a new calculation system should ensure the automatic implementation of the necessary controls.
21. Monitoring of the implementation of the study contracts shall be carried out on a monthly basis on the programme management basis.
22. The appointment was placed for the departments concerned on 11 October 1994.
The change in the date on the invoice itself had no influence on the transfers.
Nevertheless, the official concerned was reprimanded.
Any necessary manual corrections will be signed and dated in the future.

Accounting for budgetary operations 1.6.

This additional use of the paying agency procedure is contrary to Article 45 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, which provides for this procedure only for certain types of expenditure. 1.8.
In addition, the Agency did not start accounting for this expenditure until September 1995.
At the end of the financial year on 31 December 1995, some ECU 937 000 had to be settled.
General bill 1.9.
The accounts and budget records were not made until September and December 1995 because of the handling by the paying agency.
This is contrary to accounting practices.

13. 3. 97 I EN Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/31 REPLY OF THE EMEA 1.6.
The commercial accounting systems available on the market do not take into account the specificities of Community financial rules.
For this reason, in 1995 the agencies published a call for tenders for a system adapted to their needs.
Until the introduction of the new system, the Agency works with a spreadsheet system.
Although this system can be used to make subsequent changes to the accounts, it would not be possible for them to be found in the accounts of budgetary operations.
However, these amendments are to be found in the general accounts.
All budgetary operations are documented in the case.
During the start-up period, until the appointment of the financial controller in the house, a paying agency was indispensable for the proper functioning of the Agency.
This is the only way to speed up the decision by the Member States on the establishment of the Agency.
With the entry into service of the financial controller, the paying agency was less used and closed at the end of July 1995.
75 % of the payments made by the paying agency were settled on 1 December 1995.
Even if a large amount could not be settled until 1996, the Agency achieved a satisfactory final result and did its best in difficult circumstances.

Transfers and transfers 1.7.
The appropriations carried over to 1996 represent 46% of the budget and relate primarily to computer equipment (Titles II and III of the budget).
The appropriations available were also transferred from Title I (staff) to Title II (technical expenditure) totalling ECU 2,529 million (25 % of the budget).
The inventory is kept only in terms of quantity but not in terms of value.
It is therefore not possible to coordinate with the amounts shown in the Office's balance sheet.
The administrative system set up by the Office does not guarantee adequate separation of tasks and proper implementation of the provisions relating to revenue, commitments and payments (authorising officer, financial controller and accounting officer).
The office is currently housed in a building of the Spanish government.

No C 81/36 p 5. Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 REPLY OF THE AMTES Commission grant 1.5.
The need for a recovery order was not known to the Commission or to the OHIM.
The OHIM has taken note of this observation by the Court of Auditors and has caused a recovery order for the 1996 financial year to be issued without delay for the total amount of the grant less the provisions.
Accounting for budgetary operations 1.6. It is true that the accounting system currently used by the OHIM allows subsequent changes to the accounts.
For the period up to the introduction of the Sincom2 system developed by the Commission, OHIM has provided organisational arrangements for additional security guarantees for the use of the current system.
Until then, OHIM has no other option but to wait for the Commission's accounting system, which is likely to be available before the end of the year, because the development of such a system means a great financial burden that an office cannot bear on its own.
In 1995, the Office's budget was adopted in the light of a provision of ECU 2 million requested by Parliament for an overall budget of ECU 10.1 million.
The provision was cancelled in two stages: — ECU 1 million in October 1995, — the balance in November 1995.
The temporary blocking of funds has, of course, had an effect on their use, in particular the funds under Title I (personnel), as there was uncertainty as to whether the provisions would be effectively repealed.
OHIM could not, under any circumstances, engage in recruiting staff as long as payment of salaries was not guaranteed by the end of the financial year.
Following the release of the provisions, measures were taken to make use of the appropriations released, in the budget lines where time limits for the commitment procedures still allowed and where there was real need.
For this reason, the Office has requested a transfer from Title I to Title II in order to create mainly computer material which was particularly needed during the start-up phase of the Office.
It should be recalled that OHIM began its activities on 1 April 1996 and that more than 30 000 trade mark applications have been received since then, while the workload was estimated at 15 000 applications for the whole financial year.
Inventory 1.8. At the time of audit by the Court, OHIM had only just received from the Commission the software for computerised management of the inventory; it was just installed at that time.
Division of tasks 1.9.
A question to the Court of Auditors made it clear that this item concerns the order of signatures which must be respected in the budget commitment and payment procedures.
It is therefore not a confusion as to the duties of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the financial controller.
This approach had the advantage that, in the initial phase of the Office, when there was not yet a fund manager, it was ensured that the funds were available before an operation was signed by the authorising officer. Since the OHIM now has a fund manager, the sequence of signatures given below can be observed in the various budget documents: 1. Budget manager, 2. Authorising officer, 3. Financial controller, 4. Accounting officer.
Property, plant and equipment 1.10.
There is an agreement (see copy in Annex) between the Minister of Industry of the Spanish Government
On the basis of this agreement, the Spanish authorities shall make available to the Office free of charge a building (temporary seat), the building in which the Office is currently situated.
Under this agreement, the Spanish Government will take measures to provide the Office with a permanent seat.
The decision on the site and the specifications for the invitation to tender for the building to be constructed was taken by the Spanish authorities on 3 July 1996.
This specification shall be published on 30 July of this year in the Official Journal of the European Communities (S series — Calls and Tenders).
Following these recent developments, the Office will take the necessary steps without delay.

Main comments on the implementation of the budget of the European Training Foundation for the 1994 and 1995 financial years Accounting for budgetary operations 1.5.
This system and the systematic implementation through the paying agency can lead to overruns of funds.
Paying Agency 1.6.
The Foundation carried out all payments through a paying agency in 1995.
This is not compatible with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation for the Foundation, which provides for this procedure only for certain types of expenditure.
In addition, the accounts for this expenditure were delayed as the relevant documents had to be sent to the financial controller for approval in Brussels.
The Foundation has allocated a total of ECU 0.4 million to make use of the resources still available at the end of the financial year.

Accounting - The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
It has also played a crucial role in the establishment of a single system for the management of the budget and the accounting system in all departments.
Discussions are under way with the Commission's departments responsible, which will enable us to overcome all the concerns expressed by the Court of Auditors by introducing a new system for the management of the budget, which will enter into force on 1 January 1997.
In this context, it should be stressed that none of the budget allocations had been exceeded over the period under review.
1.6. Management of advance payments It must be stressed that the advance payments had not been used for all purchases of equipment or for the participation in real estate, which represented a significant part of the budget.
In addition, the use of the general advance payments has at present been reduced in accordance with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation and all invoices of a given month will be sent to the auditor in Brussels within the 10th and 20th of the following month.
Contracts On the one hand, the contracts under discussion, closely linked to the activities and projects of the Foundation's work programme, represent an extremely small proportion of the Foundation's activities, both in terms of number and budget.
On the other hand, it is true that the inclusion of the competition that led to these contracts was informal.
This procedure was chosen at the time mainly on the basis of urgency.
In addition, the contracts under discussion had the task of organising conferences and seminars on behalf of and on behalf of the Foundation and under its strict control.
The budget was divided into two parts: the fixed part of the remuneration (less than ECU 12 000) and the operational part, which was pre-defined by the Foundation and reimbursed on the basis of the supporting documents.
On the basis of these elements, the Foundation considered that the actual contract amount would not exceed ECU 12 000.
When it became clear at the beginning of 1996 that the Court of Auditors did not share this view, this system was abandoned.
Accountants The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
This report shall be submitted to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in accordance with Article 13(4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 19901.
The Court has examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
In accordance with Article 13(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the budget was implemented under the reply of the Executive Director.
The Court of Auditors shall also be responsible for drawing up and presenting the accounts (2), in accordance with the internal financial rules provided for in Article 14 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 0; in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community, the Court of Auditors shall be required to examine these accounts.
The Court has carried out its audit in accordance with the generally accepted audit standards to the extent that they are applicable to the Community context.
It has carried out audits of the accounts and applied other audit procedures considered necessary in this context.
The financial statements for 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions are guaranteed overall.
Main comments on the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 Commission assistance 1.5.
During the 1995 financial year, the Agency has only part of the legislation contained in its budget (i1) OJ L 120, 11.5.1990, p. 4.
(2) In accordance with Article 13(3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all the Agency's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 1995 were drawn up on 20 June 1996, signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and forwarded to the Commission, the Management Board and the Court of Auditors.
The accounts were received by the Court of Auditors on 29 June 1996.
The tables in the annex to this report show these financial statements in abridged form. The Commission grants (budget: ECU 12 million — appropriations recovered: ECU 6.2 million).
The Court considers that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the 1995 financial year for the outstanding balance (ECU 5.8 million) in order to meet the commitments carried over to the 1996 financial year (ECU 7 million in total).
Titles I (staff expenditure) and II (technical expenditure) of the budget have identified a number of overruns of some ECU 0.4 million in total.
This amount, which could not be charged to the 1995 budget, is shown on the assets side of the balance sheet in a depositary account and must be charged to the 1996 budget (in breach of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Paying agency 1.7.
Almost all payments to be charged to Titles I and II of the budget have been settled through a paying agency.
The use of this paying agency is not compatible with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation as the imprest administrator at that time was both the accounting officer and the budget manager of some budget lines.
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of supporting documents have not been complied with and the availability of committed appropriations for payments has not been verified.
This seems to be the main reason for the above-mentioned excesses.
Transfers 1.8.
As at the end of 1994, a very large proportion of the available appropriations was carried over at the end of 1995 (7 million ECU — 57.2% of the total).
Most transfers concerned Title III (operational expenditure) (ECU 6.4 million — 90.3% of the appropriations entered in this Title).
A large part (ECU 1.8 million) of the ECU 8.5 million carried over from 1994 to 1995 had to be cancelled (21% of the carry-overs).
Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Subsequent referral to the Financial Controller 1.9.
Several commitments totalling ECU 0.5 million were submitted to the financial controller after the end of the year.
I n these cases, the financial control authority has refused to give its approval, which the Board of Directors has disregarded.
The Court underlines the obligation to comply with the Financial Regulation, according to which "for all measures that could lead to expenditure at the expense of the budget" (Article 27 of the Financial Regulation for the Agency), a prior application for commitment must be made in accordance with the rules.
The division of tasks was not respected in the administrative department of the Agency.
The lack of accounting staff meant that the same person was also the accounting officer, the administrator and the manager of some budget lines.
Accounting systems 1.11.
Two independent systems are used for the accounting of budgetary operations and for general accounting.
Moreover, the accounting system for budgetary operations does not provide for any spe cialities if the available or committed appropriations are exceeded.
Financial controller 1.12.
The Management Board has appointed the financial controller of the Commission as financial controller.
On the basis of the current functioning of the Agency, the Court considers that it is appropriate to assign it a financial control body, which was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 28 October 1996.

• The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on the seat of the Agency had been delayed, work had to be carried out particularly quickly at the beginning of the work of the Environment Agency.
Projects were identified and commitments made before the end of the year thanks to a large amount of labour, but for obvious reasons the implementation of commitments could hardly begin before the end of 1994.
In 1995, the Agency faced the difficult task of implementing not only the 1994 budget but also a new budget of ECU 10.5 million for 1995, before the regular staff of the Agency began their duties.
The Agency's vacancies were advertised in November 1994 and, after a lengthy selection procedure with over 7 000 applications, the first selected candidates began their work in the summer of 1995.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work programme and practically two budgets, but had only a very limited number of staff for this task.
Nevertheless, the work progressed and in 1995 major projects such as the Dobris Management Report and the revision of the 5th Environmental Action Plan were completed.
Five European thematic contact centres were set up and the development of EIONET was progressing.
The Agency's regular staff increased by 1 person on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, such as national experts and auxiliary staff) and reached the level of 22 regular staff on 31 December 1995 who continued to support 10 temporary staff.
The administrative machinery of the Agency has gradually been expanded as the same open recruitment procedure has been applied.
Nevertheless, in 1995, the Agency was clearly not sufficiently equipped to cope with the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
As far as the financial side is concerned, only one person was available in the first half of the year to deal with the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme.
In June 1995, the Head of the Administrative Department began his service and only at the beginning of 1996 did the other staff for financial and contract matters come in.
The Agency did its job, but in the area of finance and budget, some mistakes were made in relation to the prescribed procedures.
Overruns Some budget lines have been overrun.
On the one hand, this was because the Agency's budgetary control system did not function satisfactorily and on the other hand some payments made were not accounted for, as the Agency's financial department was clearly understaffed.
As a result, the clearance of accounts showed a discrepancy between the accounting system and the payments actually made, which appeared as an overdraft of certain budget lines.
As there will no longer be any settlement between different budget lines after 1 January, these amounts will have to be included in the 1996 accounts, i.e. financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996, expenditure and appropriations available under Titles I and II (i.e. the 1995 problem points) were carefully monitored to avoid an expenditure surplus.
Unobserved procedures (subsequent referral to the financial controller) A work programme was drawn up during the establishment phase of the Agency and its implementation started before the administrative procedures were clearly defined and a corresponding administrative structure was available to monitor compliance with the procedures.
In some cases, this led to work being commissioned and carried out, excluding certain procedural rules.
In particular, work was commissioned without the approval of the financial controller in Brussels having been obtained before, which is a prerequisite for this type of operational expenditure.
The error was purely procedural and was justified in the fact that work had to be done, but that the necessary administrative structures to ensure compliance with the rules laid down by Brussels had not yet been set up.
There has been a clear delegation of powers and staff are informed of the procedural rules.
Separation of tasks As in all public institutions, certain functions of a financial technical nature should also remain separate with the Environment Agency.
One of the basic principles is that commitments and payment orders should not be made by the same person.
However, during the construction period of the Agency in Copenhagen, the number of staff was so low that this principle could not be adhered to.
This fact is rightly objected to by the Court of Auditors.
In the case of the Environment Agency, the financial controller of the Agency and that of the Commission shall be one and the same person established in Brussels.
This would significantly impede the work of the Agency.
The way out of this dilemma is to set up a paying agency.
I m principle, it works like a small cash reserve, although the amounts dealt with above are quite significant.
Instead of obtaining the prior approval of the financial control, the agency orders the payment and sends once a month the establishment of the procedures by the paying agency for subsequent approval of the financial control.
On the one hand, this will facilitate the work of the paying agency, but on the other hand, it is also a two-dimensional sword, as internal control of the agency and the financial department must be able to meet this additional responsibility.
The Court of Auditors' complaint is understandable in this respect, but as long as the financial controller is based in Brussels, the Agency does not see any alternance as an extensive claim of the paying agency. · For this reason, the Agency has taken the Court of Auditors' recommendation with great interest that the Agency's Commission be able to appoint a financial advisor.The Environment Agency would welcome such a step.
Computerised accounting system The Court of Auditors stresses the need for the Agency to implement a modern accounting system covering both general accounting and budgetary control.
Such a computerised system is essential for the EU's complicated financial system if we are to avoid large amounts of money being tied to finance and budgetary work.
The Environment Agency wholeheartedly supports the Court of Auditors' conclusions.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has repeatedly tried to find a solution to this problem.
It will, by the way, be in the same form for the other EU agencies.
In 1996, the agencies issued a joint call for proposals, which however remained unsuccessful, i.e. no satisfactory system was found.
The Agency is currently examining the possibility of using the new Sincom 2 budgetary control system.
The plan states that it should be installed and operational in good time in order to implement the 1997 budget.
But there will continue to be a soft spot for budgetary control and another for general accounting.
Payments will also not be integrated into the software. The agency will continue to look for a suitable solution to these problems and try to coordinate this work with the other agencies.

The following remarks concern the Court of Auditors' most important comments on the implementation of the EMCDDA budget for 1994 and 1995 (points 1.5 to 1.11 of the Court of Auditors' observations).
The EMCDDA shares the Court's view that it would have been more appropriate to issue a recovery order for all the appropriations entered in the balance sheet as a grant to the Commission, and that the 1996 budget was managed accordingly. b)The Portuguese Government (point 1.6 of the Court's observations) The EMCDDA acted in accordance with the Commission's financial control rules (which is also the EMCDDA's financial controller). within the meaning of Article 54 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities and Article 82 of the implementing rules for the same (in accordance with the spirit of Article 142 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities) the EMCDDA first used the payment account for the expenditure referred to in Article 54 of the abovementioned implementing rules.
However, the EMCDDA is aware that this can only be a provisional system (based on Excel) and that it needs a more efficient accounting system.
In this context, the decentralised agencies (including the EMCDDA) launched a call for proposals at the end of December 1995 under the coordination of the European Training Foundation in Turin with the aim of equipping themselves with an integrated computerized system for general accounting and accounting.
No. C 81/54 - EN - 97 - Official Journal of the Communities 13. 3. 97 For the following financial years, the EMCDDA is implementing a plan for the programming and control of the implementation of the budget and its work programme, which is intended to improve the use of the appropriations allocated and, in particular, to limit transfers to exceptional cases. f) Separation of tasks (point 1.10 of the Court of Auditors' observations) C Due to its very limited staff in 1994 and 1995, the EMCDDA was unable to fully ensure compliance with the principle of separation of tasks, as the Court of Auditors pointed out.
The separation of the duties of authorising officer, financial controller and accounting officer as required by Article 16 of the OEDT Financial Rules for the duties of authorising officer has been fully complied with.
The EMCDDA is already working to ensure that the various tasks involved are separated.
In this context, it shall take into account, as far as possible, the requirements communicated by the Court of Auditors in defining their short-term personnel needs, in order to ensure that the administrative tasks referred to by the Court of Auditors (payment management, accounting, management of staff or contracts) are carried out by different persons.
Such proposals will be submitted to the EMCDDA's Management Board. g) Financial Controller (point 1.11 of the Court of Auditors' observations) The EMCDDA's Management Board opened a negative decision on the delegation of the tasks of the financial controller to an EMCDDA staff member when the EMCDDA's financial rules were adopted in June (in particular on the basis of the European Commission's objections).
Since the European Commission's financial controller is also the EMCDDA's financial controller, it would also be up to the Commission to review the feasibility of the possible designation of a financial controller on the spot, taking account of the rules on this issue in the other decentralised agencies.

EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 1 of 5 Avis juridique important 31997Y0313(06) Report on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies Official Journal C 081, 13/03/1997 P. 0043 - 0048 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 81/06/) (For the period from 1 September 1994 to 31 December 1995) 1.1.
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in agreement with Article 13 (4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Court of Auditors has examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director in agreement with the requirements of Article 13 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. His responsibility includes the preparation and presentation of the accounts (2) in agreement with the internal financial provisions set out in Article 14 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community requires the Court of Auditors to audit these accounts.
This report constitutes the first audit of the Agency.
The Court conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are applicable in the Community context.
The Court carried out checks on the accounts and records and also applied search additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary in this context.
The main observations resulting from the Court's audit are presented in the second part of this report.
The financial statements for the financial years 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the underlying operations were carried out, on the whole, in agreement with the rules concerning legality and regularity.
Main observations concerning the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 The Commission subsidy 1.5.
During the financial year 1995 the Agency used only part of the Commission subsidiary provided for in the general budget (ECU 12 million, of which ECU 6.2 million was drawn down).
It is the Court's opinion that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the financial year 1995 for the balance remaining due (ECU 5,8 million) in order to meet the commitments that were carried over to the financial year 1996 (totaling ECU 7 million).
Spending in excess of available approvals 1.6.
Several cases of expenditure in excess of available appropriations, spending to approximate ECU 0.4 million altogether, were found under headings I (staff expenditure) and II (administrative expenditure) of the budget.
This http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 2 of 5 amount, which could not be charged to the budget for 1995, was entered on the assess side of the balance sheet in a suspense account, and had to be charged to the budget for the financial year 1996 (contravention of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Imprest account 1.7.
Almost all payments charged to the budget under tits I and II were made via an imprest account.
The utilization of this account was not in agreement with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, since the administrator of the imprest accounts was, at the time, both the Accounting and the Authorizing Officer for certain budget heads.
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of supporting documents were not met and the availability of approaches committed was not verified before payments were made.
This situation seems to be the principal cause of the cases of spending in excess of available approaches pointed out out above.
Approvals carried forward 1.8.
At the end of the financial year 1995, as was already the case at the end of the financial year 1994, the percentage of approvals carried forward was very high in relation to the approvals available (ECU 7 million - 57.2% of the total budget).
The majority of these carryovers concern title III (ECU 6.4 million, representing 90.3% of the appropriations under this title).
A large share (ECU 1.8 million) of the approvals carried over from 1994 to 1995, totalling ECU 8.5 million, had to be cancelled (21% of the approvals carried over).
A posteriori referral to the Financial Controller 1.9.
Several proposals for the commitment of funds totalling ECU 0.5 million were submitted, a posteriori, to the Financial Controller for his approval.
In these cases, the Financial Controller withheld his approach, but this refusal was overruled by the Management Board.
The Court wishes to emphasize the obligation to respect the Financial Regulation and to submit proposals for commitments in due form prior to 'any measure of a child which might lead to expenditure from the budget' (Article 27 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Separation of duties 1.10.
The separation of duties within the administration of the Agency has not been observed.
Due to a summer of staff in the financial accounting department, the same person was, at one and the same time, Accounting Officer, administrator of the imprest accounts and Authorizing Officer for certain budget heads.
Accounting systems 1.11.
The budgetary accounting and general accounting are carried out on two independent and unrelated computer systems.
The budgetary accounting system is, moreover, not programmed to refuse entries in the event of approvals available, or approvals committed, being exceeded.
The Financial Controller 1.12.
The Management Board appointed the Commission's Financial Controller as their own Financial Controller.
The Court considers it would be advisable, in respect of the Agency's present mode of operation, to appoint a full-time Financial Controller for the Agency.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg at the Court meeting of 28 October 1996. http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 3 of 5 For the Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President >TABLE> >TABLE> >TABLE> (1) OJ No L 120, 11.5.1990, p. 4.
(2) Contrary to the requirements of Article 13 (3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all revenue and expenditure of the Agency in respect of the financial year 1995 were not prepared until 20 June 1996, the date on which the accounts were signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and sent to the Commission, to the Board of Management and to the Court of Auditors.
These accounts were received by the Court on 28 June 1996.
The abandoned version of these financial statements is presented in the tables annexed to this report.
THE AGENCY'S REPLIES The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted already on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on where to locate the Agency had been delayed a fast start was needed.
Through a significant effect, projects could be identified and the budget committed before the end of the year, but for previous reasons the execution of the commitments could be well started before the end of 1994.
Thus, in 1995 the Agency faced the daunting task of executing, not only the budget from 1994 but also a new budget for 1995 of ECU 10.5 million, and this before the regular staff of the Agency had taken up duty.
The vacant posts in the Agency were published in November 1994 and the selected candidates started coming on board in summer 1995 after a long selection procedure involving more than 7 000 applications.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work program and virtually two budgets to execute, but very limited staff for the task.
Despite this, work went ahead and in 1995 the Agency finalized major projects, like the Dobris assessment, the review of the fifth environmental action plan.
Five European topic centres were established and the build-up of the EIONET advanced.
The build-up of the Agency progressed with regular staff increasing from 1 on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, for example national experts and auxiliary staff) to 22 on 31 December 1995, still supported by 10 temporary staff.
The Agency's administration has progressively developed since the same open procedure to recruit was applied.
Nevertheless, it was clearly too understaffed in 1995 to handle the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
On the finance side only one person was available to handle the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme during the first half of the year.
In June 1995 the Head of Administration took up duty, and only in the beginning of 1996 did the rest of the finance and contract staff come on board.
The Agency rose to the challenge, but some mistakes of a procedural nature were made in the areas of finance and budget.
Overspending There was overspending on some budget lines.
The season was, on the one http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 4 of 5 hand, that the Agency's budgetary monitoring system did not function in a satisfactory way and on the other hand some executed payments were not introduced due to the fact that the Agency was seriously understaffed in the finance department.
As a consequence, when the accounts were closed, the discrepancy between the accounts and the payments actually made, showed up as overspending on some budget lines.
Since no adjustment between budget lines can be made after 1 January, this has to be booked on the 1996 accounts, i.e. be financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996 the expenses and the availability of approvals in titles I and II, which was where the problems occurred in 1995, were carefully monitored in order to avoid overspending.
Procedures overlooked (Saisine a posteriori) During the build-up of the Agency, a work program was established and started being executed before administrative procedures had been well established and an administration in place to monitor that procedures were followed.
In some cases this led to work being ordered and carried out without all the procedures being observed.
In particular, work was contracted without the Financial Controller in Brussels having given his visa which is a prerequisite for this kind of operational expenditure.
It was not a question of finances being lost or that the finances were not there.
The mistake was procedural and reflected that work had to be done and the procedures to ascertain that this was done according to Community rules were not yet in place.
Procedures are now in place to avoid similar problems.
A clear delegation of authorizing powers have been established and staff informed of the rules.
Separation of functions In the financial framework of the Agency, as is the case in all public institutions, certain functions should be kept separate.
A basic principle is that the same person should not commit money and order payment.
However, during the period of establishment of the Agency in Copenhagen the number of staff in the Agency was so small that it was not possible to observe this principal.
This is legally criticalized by the Court of Auditors.
However, once the staffing of the Agency started to increase this was corrected and these functions have been rigorously separated in the Agency since 1995.
Extensive use of imprest accounts The normal procedure forcommitting and ordering payments in the EU system is to have prior approval by the Financial Controller in practice all cases.
In the case of the Agency, the Agency Financial Controller is the same as the Commission's and located in Brussels.
To send all financial transactions to Brussels for approval before they could actually be executed would be an excessively tiresome procedure.
It would seriously obstruct the working of the Agency.
The way out of this dilemma is the imprest account.
It works in principle as a petty-cash reserve oldough the amounts involved are important.
Instead of seeing prior approval from Financial Control, the Agency executes the payment and once a month the imprest account is sent to the Financial Controller to have the ex post approval of the payments which have been made.
On the one hand this facilitates the functioning of the Agency, but, on the other hand, it is a double-edged word since the Agency's internal controls and the financial department must have the capacity to handle this additional responsibility.
Thus, the criticism by the Court of Auditors is understandable, but as long as http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 5 of 5 the Financial Controller is located in Brussels there is, in the Agency's view no alternative to an extensive use of the imprest account.
It is there with great interest that the Agency has noted the recommendation by the Court of Auditors that the Financial Controller of the Commission should place a Financial Controller in the Agency.
The Agency would welcome this step.
Computerized financial system The Court of Auditors underlines the need for the Agency to find an up-to-date computerized financial system which can integrate the accounting side with the budget monitoring side.
In the complicated financial system of the European Union such a computerized system is crucial to avoid having to tie down a lot of resources in financial and budgetary work.
The Agency supports whyheartedly the conclusion by the Court of Auditors.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has again and again tried to find a solution to this problem.
It is a problem which the European Environment Agency shares with the other EU Agencies.
In 1996, the Agencies launched a joint call for tenders to find a solution but this call for tenders has not been successful, i.e. no satisfactory system has been found.
Thus, the Agency is at present pursuing the possibility of using the new budget monitoring system Sincom 2. The plan is to have it installed and operational in time to execute the 1997 budget on the basis of this system.
There will be still one software for the budget monitoring system and another for the general leather.
Nor will the imprest accounts be integrated in the software the Agency will continue to look for an efficient way of solving these problems and will endeavour to coordinate this work with the other Agencies.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/25 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Environment Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Agency's mission is to set up an environmental monitoring network to provide the Commission, the Member States and the general public with reliable information on the state of the environment.
This information should give the European Union and the Member States, in particular, the ability to take measures to protect the environment and to assess the effectiveness of these measures.
2. Table 1 summarises the Agency's capabilities and capabilities.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 provide information on the main elements of the Agency's financial statements for the financial year 2006.
This declaration is submitted to the European Parliament and the Council pursuant to Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (2). It is based on an examination of the Agency's accounts, which the Court must carry out pursuant to Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The Agency's annual accounts for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (3) were drawn up in accordance with Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 by its Executive Director, and forwarded to the Court, which gives an explanation of the adequacy of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
5. The Court carried out its examination in compliance with the guidelines for financial control and the INTOSAI Code of Obligations and Code of Conduct as well as the international professional principles for the final examination of IFAC, if these are applicable in the Community context.
The examination was planned and carried out with a view to obtaining adequate assurance that the annual accounts are reliable and that the underlying assumptions are correct and orderly.
6. The Court shall have an adequate basis for the following accrual declaration. The financial statements of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 shall be subject to all substantive provisions.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's declaration of sovereignty.
COMMENTS 7. About 30 % of the commitments of the financial year had to be transferred.
Operational expenditure (Title III and assigned revenue) was carried over more than half of the appropriations.
These transfers were partly not justified: in the last two months of 2006, the agency made commitments of EUR 1.3 million, but transferred the corresponding payments to 2007.
A sampling (4) of these transfers showed that they were all related to 2007-to-2007 activities.
The budgetary principle of prudence has therefore not been strictly applied.
8. The authorising officer, who was subordinated, not only carried out ex-ante controls, but also managed the access rights to the electronic accounting system, which constitutes a violation of the principle of separation of duties.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 27 September 2007.
For the Court of Auditors Hubert WEBER President (1) OJ L 120, 11.5.1990.

(4) The value of the sample is around EUR 500 000.

C 309/28 EN Official Journal of the European Union 19.12.2007 ANSWER OF THE AGENCY The higher proportion of transfers to 2007 is mainly due to exceptional events in 2006, which led us to postpone interim payments to thematic centres until the satisfactory delivery of the services.
The reasons for the commitments received were the obligation to conclude licensing agreements before 1 January each year in order to maintain the continuity, as well as the time needed to define and negotiate the costs and time limits for complex new work.
The Agency will continue to reduce the proportion of transfers in this context.
The risks associated with the described situation were assessed by the management and controls were carried out to reduce the risks.
The remaining risk is considered acceptable.
This situation is being reassessed as part of a safety-sensitive task to be carried out in mid-2007.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/41 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Agency for Reconstruction (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EC) No 1628/96(1), as last amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 756/2006 of 28 November 2006 (2).
The agency, which was established in 2000, was originally responsible for managing the European Union's aid programmes in Kosovo.
It was also extended to Serbia-Montenegro and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
The Agency implements programmes to promote institution building and good governance to support the establishment of a market economy and basic infrastructure for civil society.
The Agency's mandate is in principle to expire on 31 December 2008.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 provide information on the main elements of the Agency's financial statements for the financial year 2006.
This declaration shall be submitted to the European Parliament and to the Council in accordance with Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (3).
It is based on a review of the Agency's accounts, which the Court must carry out in accordance with Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
4. The Agency's annual accounts for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (4) were drawn up by its director in accordance with Article 8(2) of Council Regulation (EC) No 2667/2000 (5) and transmitted to the Court, which makes a statement on the solvency of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual accounts of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 shall be valid in all material respects.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's powers.
COMMENTS 7. The budget implementation rate was satisfactory.
However, the Agency will be made aware of the extent of the still to be committed resources, which will require a special monitoring of the Agency's programmes, as its mandate expires at the end of 2008.
8. With regard to the accounting system and the internal control system, the Court noted improvements over previous years, in particular regarding the monitoring of funds managed by external bodies and the application of procurement procedures.
