EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/5 INTRODUCTION 1.1.
The Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (1) is the European Court of Auditors of the European Union's external representatives.
In this capacity, the Court plays the role of independent authority for the financial interests of the Union's citizens, in particular by contributing to the improvement of EU financial management.
More detailed information on the Court's work can be found in its annual reports and annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget, as well as in its special reports, landscape analyses and opinions on new or amended EU legislation or other decisions affecting financial management (2).
In the context of its mandate, the Court shall carry out the annual accounts and the underlying reports of all the institutions, agencies and other bodies of the Union (3).
This report contains the results of the Court's investigation into the financial year 2017 of the EU agencies and other bodies of the Union (together with the agencies).
The report is structured as follows: Chapter 1 gives a review of the agencies and the type of audit of the Court. Chapter 2 presents the overall results of the audit. Chapter 3 contains for each of the 41 agencies a declaration of compliance, together with the Court's rulings and observations on the reliability of the accounts of the agencies, as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying income and payments.
EU AGENCIES Different types of agencies contribute to shaping and implementing EU policies 1.4.
Agencies are separate bodies with their own legal personality, which have been established by a secondary act in order to perform specific technical and scientific tasks or administrative tasks, thereby helping to shape and implement the policies of the EU institutions.
Many agencies are clearly visible and have significant influence on important areas that are important for the daily lives of European citizens, such as health, security, freedom and justice.
With their assurances in chapter 3, a brief description of the tasks carried out by each agency is included.
This report uses their respective chapters for the agencies, which can be taken from the list at the beginning of this report.
There are three types of agencies: decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other bodies.
Its main features are explained below.
The number of agencies has increased over the years and in 2017 was 41 agencies as shown in Figure 1.1.
(1) Articles 285 to 287 (OJ C 326, 26.10.2012, p. 169-171).
(2) Available on the Court's website: www.eca.europa.eu (3) Three defence agencies (the European Defence Agency, the Institute of the European Union for Security Studies and the European Union Satellite Centre) financed from contributions from the Member States are not operated by the Court but by other independent external experts.
EN C 434/6 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 1.1 Increase in the number of agencies Source: European Court of Auditors.
The Commission's executive agencies are based in Brussels or Luxembourg, like the Commission itself.
Decentralised agencies and other bodies are located throughout the EU and are spread across 23 different Member States, as shown in the list of groups and illustration 1.2.
The seat of the agencies shall be decided by the Council or jointly by the Council and the European Parliament.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/7 Illustration 1.2 Headquarters of agencies in the Member States Source: European Court of Auditors.
Decentralised agencies deal with specific policy needs 1.8.
The 32 decentralised agencies (4) play an important role in the preparation and implementation of EU policies, in particular with regard to technical, scientific, operational and/or regulatory tasks.
The main aim here is to meet specific policy needs and to strengthen European cooperation through the exchange of expertise and expertise between the EU and national governments.
The decentralised agencies have been set up indefinitely by regulation of the Council or the European Parliament and the Council.
Decentralised agencies shall operate under the control of a Management Board composed of representatives of the Member States, the Commission and some agencies, including other parties.
The Management Board shall define the operational frameworks to be followed by the agencies, such as the multiannual and annual work programme, budget expenditure and posts carried out under the responsibility of the respective Executive Directors/Directors.
Each decentralised agency is subject to its own discharge procedure with regard to the implementation of its budget covering staff, administrative and operational expenditure. In most cases, discharge is granted by the European Parliament and the Council (5).
(4) Cedefop, Eurofound, EEA, ETF, EMA, EMCDDA, CdT, CPVO, EUIPO, EU-OSHA, FRA, EASA, EFSA, EMSA, Eurojust, ECDC, ENISA, ERA, Frontex, GSA, EPA, EFCA, ECHA, EIGE, ACER, B such as BEREK, Europol, EASO, EBA, EIOPA, ESMA and eu-LISA.
(5) Two self-financed agencies (CPVO and EUIPO) are subject to the discharge procedure by their Board of Directors.
EN C 434/8 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 The Commission's executive agencies carry out EU programmes by 1.10.
The six executive agencies of the Commission(6) are entrusted with implementing and operational tasks relating to one or more Union programmes and their duration is limited in time.
They have been established by Commission Decision and operate under the supervision of a steering committee appointed by the Commission.
Their work is based on multiannual and annual work programmes, which are drawn up and implemented under the responsibility of an Executive Director.
They are subject to individual discharge procedures by the European Parliament and the Council for their own budgets.
Unlike decentralised agencies, their budgets cover only human resources and administrative expenditure, while all operational expenditure they do come from the Commission's budget and are therefore part of the overall relief granted to the Commission.
The own budget of the executive agencies therefore corresponds only to a very small part of the budget which they actually carry out.
The other institutions have special tasks 1.11.
The three other bodies are the EIT, the Euratom Supply Agency and the SRB.
The EIT in Budapest is an independent, decentralised EU institution, which creates resources in the fields of science, economy and education to strengthen the Union's innovative power by providing financial support.
The Institute was established indefinitely by the European Parliament and the Council.
It is managed by a director and supervised by a board of directors, and is subject to its own discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council.
The Euratom Supply Agency in Luxembourg was established by the Council for an indefinite period to support the objectives of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community.
It is subject to a separate discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council.
An Advisory Council composed of members from the Member States shall assist the Euratom Supply Agency in carrying out its tasks by delivering opinions and providing analysis and information.
The Director-General of the Euratom Supply Agency shall operate under the supervision of the Commission.
The SRB is the central settlement authority in the banking union and has its headquarters in Brussels.
The SRB's mission is to ensure that banks insolvently affected by insolvency is handled in an orderly manner, with as little impact as possible on the real economy, the financial system and public finances of the participating Member States and beyond.
The SRB is represented by its chairman, who also plays the role of employee.
The Chairman of the SRB shall be subject to a separate discharge procedure by the Committee, which shall request members of the national resolution authorities of the participating Member States.
Agencies are financed from different sources and under different MFF headings 1.15.
The budget of all agencies (excluding the SRB) amounted to EUR 3.5 billion in 2017 (2016: EUR 3.4 billion), representing about 2.7% of the total EU budget for 2017 (2016: 2.4%), as can be seen from Figure 1.3.
The agencies with the highest increase in 2017 were the GSA and the EIT, which are financed under the MFR (7) sub-heading 1a (competitiveness for growth and employment), and Frontex, the EMA and EASO, which are financed under the MFR heading 3 (security and Union citizenship).
In addition, the SRB's 2017 budget of EUR 6.6 billion (2016: EUR 11.8 billion) (8).
It consists of contributions paid by credit institutions to the Single Resolution Fund.
(6) INEA, REA, EACEA, ERCEA, Chafea and EASME.
(7) Multiannual EU financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
(8) The 2016 revenue budget consisted not only of the contributions of credit institutions to the Single Resolution Fund for 2016, but also of the contributions for 2015, which were collected by the national resolution authorities in 2015, but only forwarded to the Fund in January 2016.
Therefore, the total budget for 2017 is much lower than the budget for 2016 (6.6 billion against 11.8 billion euros).
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/9 1.17.
The budgets of decentralised agencies and other bodies cover human, administrative and operational expenditure, whereas the executive agencies carry out programmes financed from the Commission's budget and cover their own budgets (a total of around EUR 241 million) only human and administrative expenditure.
The Commission's operational expenditure, which was paid by the six executive agencies, amounted to around 6.8 billion euros in 2017, more than double the total budget of all other agencies together without the SRB.

The other agencies are financed entirely or partially by fees and fees as well as by direct contributions from participating countries such as Member States, EFTA countries, etc. The total EU budget amounted to around 2.5 billion euros. In addition, 1 billion euros came from fees and fees as well as direct contributions from participating countries.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/13 The network of EU agencies promotes the agency's extensive cooperation and communication with stakeholders 1.21.
The EU Agency Network (EUAN) was established by the agencies as an agency-wide forum for cooperation to increase the visibility of the agencies, to identify and promote possible efficiency gains and to create added value.
The EUAN works on the basis of the priorities set by the agencies in a 5-year strategy agenda (2015-2020) and the annual work programmes, which define the activities and the results to be achieved.
An important role of the EUAN is to ensure effective communication between the agencies and the stakeholders, mainly to the EU institutions.
THE PRESENTATION OF THE HOFES The mission of the Court is to examine the annual accounts and the management of the agencies 1.22.
Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) has been amended by the Court (a) the annual accounts of all agencies consisting of the annual accounts(10) and the financial implementation reports (11) for the financial year ending 31 December 2017 and (b) the legality and regularity of the accounts underlying those accounts.
On the basis of the results of its deliberations, the Court shall submit to the European Parliament and to the Council or to the other discharge authorities referred to in Chapter 3 of this Report, for each agency, a statement concerning the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
Article 208(4) of the EU Financial Regulation (12) amended the accounts of 32 agencies receiving contributions from the EU budget by independent external experts.
The Court examined the reliability of the results of this survey in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing and considered these when drafting its own judgments.
The Court's examination of the risks identified is a 1.25.
In order to achieve sufficient security, the Court has designed its audit to shed light on the most important identified risks. In general, there is a low risk 1.26 as regards the reliability of the agencies' accounts.
Overall, the Court considers that the risk associated with the reliability of the accounts for all agencies is low.The accounts of the agencies are drawn up using the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer, which are based on internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector.
The number of major errors identified in the past was small.
Title I (Staff expenditure) 1.28.
The Commission's administration of the PMO (Office for the determination and implementation of individual requests) is reviewed by the Court as part of its specific assessments of administrative expenditure.
No significant errors have been identified in relation to staff expenditure in recent years.
However, if the agencies need to recruit large-scale additional staff in the short term, there is a medium to high risk for the legality and regularity of recruitment procedures.
(10) The annual financial statements include the balance sheet, the financial results overview, the cash flow statement, the table of changes in net assets, as well as a summary of the underlying financial statements and other explanations.
(11) The budget implementation reports include the overviews that summarise all revenue and expenditure forecasts, as well as explanations.
(12) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (OJ L 343, 20.12.2012, p.
DE C 434/14 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Title II (Administrative expenditure) 1.29.
The procurement of various services (with increasing IT concerns) includes complex procurement rules and procedures, and the agencies' administrations sometimes do not achieve satisfactory transparency and not the best price-performance ratio.
Serious award errors affecting the conditions for payment were generally one of the main reasons for closed judgements and Court observations.
Title III (operational expenditure) 1.30.
There is a low to high risk.
This depends on the agency concerned and the nature of its operational expenditure.
In general, the risks associated with procurement are similar to those covered by Title II, but the risks may be more severe.
As regards the financial assistance under Title III of the budget, earlier inspections found that, despite overall improvements, the agencies' controls were not always fully effective.
There is a medium risk in terms of budget efficiency, which was mainly identified in the areas of IT and public procurement procedures.
The Court has already reported on its findings on different IT landscapes in the agencies, weaknesses in IT project management and on procurement procedures that did not guarantee the best price-performance ratio.
In general, the large number of small agencies (see illustrations 1.4 and 1.6) equipped with their own administrative structures and procedures poses a risk in terms of administrative efficiency.

EN C 434/16 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 INTRODUCTION 2.1.
This chapter contains a review of the results of the annual reviews carried out by the Court by the agencies for 2017 and further work in connection with the agencies carried out by the Court in the course of 2017.
THE RESULTS OF THE AGENCIES' ANNUAL PRINTS FOR 2017 ARE TOTAL POSITIV 2.3.
Overall, the Court's audit of the agencies' annual accounts for the year ending 31 December 2017 and the revenue and payments underlying those annual accounts confirm the positive results from previous years.
The Court has given unrestricted opinions on the annual accounts of all agencies.
According to the Agency's assessment, the agencies' annual accounts represent their financial situation as at 31 December 2017 and the results of their accounts and cash flows for the year ending on that date, in compliance with their respective financial rules and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer (13) in all relevant respects.
In order to highlight a matter, statements are fundamental to the understanding of annual accounts 2.5.
With regard to EASO, the Court pointed out that the personnel situation in the company deteriorated exponentially.
At present, the company does not have the administrative capacity to fill the many vacancies.
Overall, the continuation of the activities of the B"ros to the present extent is considerably supported by the personnel situation.
In the case of the SRB, the Court pointed out that the contributions to the Single Resolution Fund are calculated on the basis of the information provided by credit institutions to the Committee on national resolution authorities.
However, the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework to ensure that this information is sufficient.
The Court also noted that the methodology laid down in the legislation for calculating contributions is very complex, which involves risks for accuracy.
For reasons of confidentiality, the Committee may not disclose the data of credit institutions used for the calculation of the contributions to the funds, which reduces transparency.
With regard to ECHA, the Court stressed that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a fee from each company applying for the registration of chemicals, as provided for in the REACH Regulation(14).
The calculation and billing of fees is carried out by the Agency on the basis of the information provided by the companies at the time of the application.
The ex-post inspections carried out by the Agency have shown that the total amount of these corrections was not known at the end of 2017.
This finding shows the limitations of a system which is too high based on self-disclosures of the applicants.
With regard to GSA, the Court pointed out that the outcome of the public procurement procedure was contested by one of the bidders for one of the Agency's most important contracts (framework agreement worth EUR 1.5 billion).
As regards the two London-based agencies (EMA and EBA), the Court pointed out that they will leave the United Kingdom in 2019 and that their annual accounts, along with additional explanations, were prepared on the basis of the information available at the time of their signature.
The Court also pointed out the impact of the current London lease agreements and the possible decline in revenues resulting from the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the EU.
Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2006 on the registration, evaluation, authorisation and restriction of chemical substances (REACH) (OJ L 287, 12.10.2006, p. 1).
(OJ L 396, 30.12.2006, p. 1).
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/17 Unrestricted opinions on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the accounts of all agencies 2.12.
For all agencies, the Court has issued unreserved judgments on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts for the year ending 31 December 2017.
According to the Court's assessment, the revenues in all essential matters were legal and orderly.
Unrestricted judgements on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the agencies' annual accounts (except EASO) 2.13.
For 40 agencies, the Court has issued unrestricted judgments on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts for the year ending 31 December 2017.
According to the Court's assessment, payments in all essential respects were legal and orderly.
Since the understandings are systematic, the internal control system is obviously inadequate.
The cumulative error due to the irregular payments concerns at least EUR 7.7 million or 10.3% of the total payments made by the B sucho in 2017.
Paragraphs referring to other matters deal with issues of particular importance 2.15.
Paragraphs referring to other facts should point the reader to important points which are not presented or stated in the annual accounts, nor concern the legality and regularity of revenue and payments.
As regards the EIT, the Court noted that the original reimbursements for Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) were raised towards the end of the period.
Furthermore, two KICs have added some new activities to the annual business plans.
For one of the KICs, this resulted in a significant change in the original grant decision.
Substantial changes can affect the equal treatment of the KICs and are not in line with the Financial Regulation.
In the case of Frontex, the Court has repeatedly reported since 2014 that the cooperating states often provide insufficient evidence of the expenditure they claim.
This was also confirmed by this year's results.
In response to the recommendation of the Court in 2016, Frontex is currently implementing a simplified reimbursement model.
With regard to EBA, EIOPA and ESMA, the Court pointed out that their budgets are partly financed by European Union funds and partly by direct contributions from the supervisory authorities and/or the supervised bodies of the EU Member States.
The United Kingdom's decision to leave the EU has led to a reduction in the revenues of the authorities in the future.
With regard to GSA, the Court reported that the Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom, which may need to be relocated.
As regards the CdT, the Court pointed out that several agencies increasingly resorted to in-house or other alternative translations, which meant that the capacity of the centre was not used to the maximum.
Furthermore, at the European level, there is a double burden on the development of translation systems and on-going costs.
In December 2016, the Board of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (BEREC's Bureau) commissioned the CdT to translate four calls for expressions of interest in order to draw up reserve lists, despite the fact that all posts approved by the budgetary authority were filled in the Bureau's establishment plan.
According to the Court, the translation order issued in December 2016 was not justified.
The payment made on this order in March 2017 amounted to 2.5% of the 2017 budget.
EN C 434/18 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.1 Annual Court of Auditors rulings 2014-2017 on the annual accounts and opinions of the agencies Source: European Court of Auditors.
The Court's observations cover a wide range of topics 2.22.
The Court made a total of 145 comments concerning 37 agencies in order to highlight important issues and identify areas where there is a need for improvement.
These comments in Chapter 3 are summarised below.
Large risks lead to significant vulnerabilities in EASO 2.23.
In the case of EASO, the Court pointed out the major risks that arise from the nature of its activities, as well as the extraordinary challenges posed by the migration crisis.
These risks were not mitigated by a sound governance structure and effective controls, leading to numerous significant violations of legislation.
Since 2014, the B的ro has been struggling with a high staff turnover. Recruitment procedures were suspended in December 2017.
In addition, neither an internal audit office nor a legal service is set up at the office, and legal documents are not systematically superseded.
Almost all the services provided, which were based on public procurement or recruitment procedures, were systematically accused of being subject to considerable constraints in connection with the determination of the needs of the person concerned, the elaboration of specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the evaluation and award procedures, the changes and extensions of contracts, the execution of contracts and the overhaul of the services provided, etc.
These rules are contrary to the principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/19 Progress towards a more unified IT landscape 2.26.
The operational activities of the agencies are broad and require appropriate IT solutions, sometimes tailor-made.
However, central operational and administrative activities are carried out on the basis of the same legal framework, which suggests that their procedures are flexible and that similar IT solutions can be used to support these procedures.
While the agencies made very great progress with regard to the use of similar systems for budget and accounting management, the Court reported on this in its 2016 summary report on the results of inspections at the agencies, and in other core areas such as human resources management and procurement and management, a large number of IT resolutions were still used.
The agencies have agreed to further standardise IT solutions in these areas, especially in order to increase cost efficiency, reduce the risks associated with internal control and strengthen IT governance.
In 2017, a number of progress was made in IT tools for human resources management when 20 agencies concluded agreements with the Commission on the use of the SYSPER II tool, which will create a more unified IT landscape in this area.
The majority of the agencies are to use the Commission's tool from 1 January 2019, while some agencies will use it from the third quarter of 2018.
In this fragmented IT landscape, the use of similar electronic tools for the procurement of supplies and services (electronic procurement) would also be an important step towards a more unified IT framework among agencies.
The Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation, which entered into force in 2012 and 2013 respectively, are designed and implemented by all EU institutions and agencies to the extent possible by means of a common area for electronic data exchange for applicants, candidates and tenderers (15), (16).
While no target date has been set in the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation for the introduction of electronic procurement, the 2014 EU Directive on public procurement(17) prescribes the use of electronic means for public procurement in the EU Member States by 2018, and in accordance with the 2014 EU Directive on electronic invoicing(18) must allow all public bodies to receive electronic invoices by 2019.

EN C 434/20 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 2.29.
All agencies publish their tenders electronically via TED (Tenders Electronic Daily), the online version of the EU Official Journal for public procurement. In addition, the Commission launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). Most agencies had introduced electronic invoicing and the electronic invitation to tender for certain procedures by the end of 2017, but not the electronic submission of tenders.
Improvement in IT consulting and project management at EMA and eu-LISA IT consulting and project management at EMA 2.30.
In the course of the audit carried out in the previous year, the Court analysed how the Agency manages advisory services.
The use of consulting firms has led to a critical independence of external expertise.
The Court also reported that the control of project development and implementation was insufficient and that the projects were subject to serious delays and cost increases.
During 2017, the Agency took several measures to improve the situation.
However, it will take time to reduce the critical nature of the agency's consulting firms, and the impact of the measures taken will not be apparent until the years have passed.
IT consulting and project management services at eu-LISA 2.32.
Due to the nature of its activity, the Agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects.
In 2017, the Agency's IT projects were implemented within the financial and time frame.
The Agency uses an outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by three contractors.
Although the IT projects are the property of the agency and are under its control, a model in which the development capabilities for so sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent, entails the risk of an excessive dependence of the contractors.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/21 2.34.
At the same time, the low number of employees in operational key meetings creates a risk for the continuity of the operation.
Public procurement is designed to ensure competition between economic operators and to achieve the most economically viable purchase, in a transparent, objective and consistent manner, on the basis of the current legal framework.
The Court identified Ms in the field of public procurement at 14 agencies (Beuro des BEREK, EPA, Chafea, eu-LISA, EASO, EBA, EEA, EFSA, EIGE, EUIPO, ERA, EASA, FRA and SRB), mostly in the field of services that entail risks for optimal use of funds.
Among the most frequently identified obstacles are the lack of a balanced relationship between price and quality aspects of award criteria, the lack of optimal design of framework agreements, the use of framework agreements allowing the procurement of services, the description and/or price of which were not sufficiently defined and the use of intermediate services.
Most agencies analysed the impact of Brexit 2.36. On March 29, 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, five agencies (ACER, Béro des BEREK, EPA, ENISA and EU-OSHA) did not carry out a comprehensive analysis of the potential impact of Brexit on their organisation, their operations and their accounting.
Job advertisements could be published on the EPSO website 2.37.
Most agencies (ACER, Cedefop, EPA, Chafea, EASA, EBA, ECHA, EEA, EIGE, EIOPA, EIT, EMA, EMCDDA, EMSA, ENISA, ESMA, eu-LISA, Eurojust, Europol, Frontex, GSA and SRB) publish job advertisements on their own websites and on social media, but frequently not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
A publication on the EPSO website would increase transparency and publicity and allow the citizens to view job advertisements of all European institutions and bodies.
The main reason for the agencies is that the EPSO requires the publication of job advertisements in all the official languages of the EU, with high translation costs.
Less comments on the legality and regularity of payments 2.38.
The number of comments on the legality and regularity of payments went back to eight (2016: 11), which illustrates the continuing efforts of the agencies to comply with the legal framework, in particular the provisions of the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation and the Staff Regulations.
While five comments were made on procurement procedures (EASO, EASA, EIGE and Frontex), three were related to recruitment procedures (EASO, Cedefop and Frontex).
The budget management has improved 2.39.
Under certain conditions, budget appropriations granted for a given year may be transferred to the next year (19).
Although the Financial Regulation does not set ceilings for this type of transfer, the multi-annual nature of the transfers is largely justified. Nevertheless, transfers may be an indication of delays in carrying out the work programmes or contracts and may also run counter to the budgetary principle of legality.
Illustration 2.4 shows how many agencies the Court reported in 2017 and in previous years on high transfers of funds.
The return to only two agencies (Chafea and EU-OSHA) in 2017 is due to the fact that the transfers from the agencies were better and more transparently explained and supported, but also to the changed approach of the Court for reporting 2017.
(19) The conditions for transfers are laid down in Article 13 of the Financial Regulation.
EN C 434/22 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.4 Fewer comments on higher or higher amounts Source: European Court of Auditors based on information provided by the agencies.
Furthermore, the Court noted that two agencies (Frontex and EUIPO) had cancelled budget transfers from previous years.
This was an indication of the overestimated need for funding, in particular on the part of the public authorities of Member States and other cooperating countries.
Accounting could be further improved 2.42.
In the course of this year's audits, the Court also examined the accounting of agencies, which plays an important role in the preparation of reliable annual accounts.
Each agency has its own accountor in accordance with the Financial Regulation. This has resulted in a total of 37 accounts being held responsible for 2% of the EU budget.
The principal tasks of the accountant are the performance of payments, the acceptance of revenue and the recovery of receivables, the preparation and presentation of the annual accounts as well as the accounting management, the establishment and validation of the accounting systems and the treasury management.
In order to improve efficiency, the Commission's accountant asked all agencies to delegate their accounting function to him on a contractual basis in 2012.
The first agency to accept this proposal was the EPO in 2014.
By the end of 2017, only three other agencies (GSA, B to BEREC and ACER) had joined this scheme.
The hierarchical position of an accountant within an agency may affect his independence.
In particular, accountants must be independent of persons who are (subordinately) entitled to make commitments, to enter into legal commitments and to instruct payments.
This observation concerns a total of 13 agencies (CdT, EACEA, EASA, EASME, EEA, EFSA, EIOPA, EMA, EMCDDA, ERA, EU-OSHA, Eurofound and FRA).
The appointment and annual assessment of the accountant should also fall within the scope of responsibility of the Board of Directors.
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, the auditors must confirm that the agencies' accounting systems function reliably (validation).
While the validation of the accounting systems of most agencies is up-to-date, the Court noted that the accounting systems of seven agencies (ACER, B的ro des BEREK, EPA, EASME, EIT, EMA and GSA) could require a timely revalidation due to extensive changes.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/23 Illustration 2.5 The independence of the auditors of the agencies and the revalidation of the accounting systems Source: European Court of Auditors based on information provided by the agencies.
In three agencies (EASO, CPVO and REA), award, grant and recruitment procedures were poorly documented.
Three agencies (ACER, EIT, and Frontex) have identified internal controls for the implementation of the emergency rules.
These angels could represent a significant risk for the maintenance of business operations in the event of disasters, as data could be irrevocably lost.
Agencies continue to monitor findings from previous years 2.47.
If applicable, the Court reported on the state of play in the follow-up actions taken by the agencies on the basis of comments from previous years.
Figure 2.6 shows that the corrective measures relating to the 170 observations not yet implemented at the end of 2016 were completed or in progress in most cases.
Of the 13 outstanding comments, the corrective measures required in relation to three observations were not subject to the Agency's control.

The Court will forward fraud to OLAF 2.48.
OLAF is then responsible for investigating and prosecuting these cases, if necessary in cooperation with national judicial authorities.
In 2017, the Court identified three cases of mutagenic fraud that it reported to OLAF in the context of its investigation of about 1,000 proposals and 150 procurement procedures with regard to the decisions on the agencies.
The Court provides information on Commission Internal Audit Service (IAS) reports and external evaluation reports 2.49.
The Court also referred to IAS audit reports and external evaluation reports prepared on behalf of the Commission for information purposes.
In 2017, 26 IAS reports were prepared and an external evaluation of an agency was carried out in nine cases.
The Court did not exercise the corresponding examination or evaluation processes.
PROCESSING RESULTS FROM OTHER REPORTS WITH THE AGENCIES IN THE COOPERATION CONCERNED BY HOF 2017 SHALL BE RAPID Case Review by the Court for the implementation of the post dismantling by 5 % 2.50.
In 2017, the Court carried out a rapid analysis (20) of how the institutions and agencies of the European Union have implemented their commitment to reduce the staff allocated to them by 5% in the period 2013-2017 (for agencies 2014-2018).
The Court concluded that the agencies had implemented the reduction of staff by 5%, albeit with some delays.
While decentralised agencies with traditional tasks managed to reduce their staff by 8.9%, the number of employees in certain decentralised agencies and executive agencies entrusted with new tasks and responsibilities increased by 19.9% and 42.9% respectively.
Figure 2.7 shows the resulting percentage changes in posts in the posts of all institutions, bodies and agencies.
(20) Rapid Case Review for the implementation of the post reduction by 5%; published on 21 December 2017.

Special Report of the Court on the SRB 2.51.
The Single Resolution Committee (SRB), headquartered in Brussels, was established in August 2014, as part of the political response to the financial crisis.
The task of the Committee is to resolve insolvency-threatening banks, which fall within its scope of responsibility.
In January 2017, SRB was responsible for 139 banks, including 130 banking groups (21).
In the context of the survey (22) it was examined whether the committee was required to handle banks effectively. Particular attention was paid to the quality of resolution planning for individual banks and to the question whether the committee was prepared to meet the legal requirements in the area of resolution planning and had sufficient human resources to carry out its tasks.
The Court identified deficits in all these areas. However, as the establishment of the Committee as a completely new structure was a huge challenge, the weaknesses in this context need to be seen.
The Court made a number of recommendations to the Committee with a view to drawing up resolution plans and implementing its rules and guidelines, as well as increasing staff and improving procedures in the area of human resources management.
(21) On 1 January 2018, the number of banks and 119 banking groups decreased.
(22) Special Report No 23/2017: ăSingle Resolution Committee: First steps have been taken on the challenging path to the Banking Union, but there is still a long way to go, published on 19 December 2017.
DE C 434/26 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Special Court Annual Report on Contingent Liabilities resulting from the performance of the Single Resolution Committee 2.54.
Under the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation (23), the Court must draw up a report on all contingent liabilities resulting from the fact that the Committee, the Council and the Commission perform their duties under this Regulation.
As of 31 December 2016, the contingent liabilities of the Committee resulting from the contributions collected in advance amounted to EUR 842 million, which rose to EUR 1 420 million as of 30 September 2017.
In 2016, the Committee did not initiate bank resolution and, consequently, no contingent liability related to resolution decisions had to be reported for the financial year 2016.
At the time when the Court's 2016 report was published on contingent liabilities resulting from the Board's performance of its duties, 90 legal proceedings had been brought against the Board by the end of October 2017 on the basis of the resolution decision taken in June 2017 concerning Banco Popular Espa-ol S.A. and 46 complaints had been lodged with the SRB's Appeals Committee.
The Commission and the Council were informed of proceedings brought before the Court on 26 which were related to the above-mentioned resolution decision.
Other special reports by the Court relating to one or more agencies 2.55.
Apart from the audit reports dedicated specifically to agencies, during 2017, the Court prepared a series of special reports and analyses on the implementation of EU policies, which concerned a number of agencies (see illustration 2.8).
(23) Article 92(4) of the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation.

EN C 434/28 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE NETWORK OF THE EU AGENCIES The agencies welcome the Court's positive conclusions about the reliability of its annual accounts and the underlying accounts.
The network would like to express its concerns that, given that the Commission is only providing them with a basic package of modules in Sysper, the agencies will be forced to do so and will continue to be forced to use separate tools for assessment, teleworking, flexitime and personnel reporting.
The IT landscape in the area of human resources management will therefore only partially become more uniform and even much less so as the Commission can provide services.
The agencies are also able to implement a joint consultation for the services concerned in order to support recruitment procedures which are not currently covered by Sysper.
As far as procurement is concerned, over the past two years there has definitely been a trend towards harmonisation of electronic tools.
This development began in 2015/2016, when the tools for e-PRIOR/electronic procurement designed by DG DIGIT in cooperation with DG BUDG were developed.
Since then, this series of electronic modules has become more and more a standard for all phases of the procurement cycle to which the agencies adhere.
This trend continued in 2018 when new modules for electronic submission and the ABAC LCK module were introduced and submitted to the agencies.
Gradually, the agencies are setting up the use of their own isolated tools, some quickly, some less quickly, but regardless of how rapidly this development will take place, the trend in itself is no longer in place.
The proposed increases in efficiency, which could be achieved by transferring accounting tasks to the European Commission, are difficult to achieve in practice.
The necessary workload not only depends on the balance of the budget, but also on the fact that the annual accounts must be completed at the beginning of each year in a narrow window of time.
Experience shows that for more than one package of annual accounts (i.e. additional funding for delegation agreements), almost twice as much staff is required, even though the corresponding amounts are smaller (and the financial resources are lower).
When these activities were transferred to the Commission, each agency would still require an accounting team, as accounting tasks still have to be carried out.
As long as this is the case, any savings in staff would not correspond to a full-time equivalent.
In addition, the annual fee has to be paid.
For this reason, only a few agencies have decided to transfer this task to the Commission.
The network should point out that no investigation or risk assessment has yet been carried out, which could justify the conclusion that the independence of the accountant would be strengthened if he were directly under the authority of the authorising officer and not a authorised authorising officer.
Some agencies have decided to adopt a charter of accountants, which includes, among other things, arrangements for reporting to the board, if necessary.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/31 3.1.
We have carried out our inspection in compliance with the International Standards on Auditing (ISA) as well as the professional behavior requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions (ISSAI) of INTOSAI.
Our responsibilities according to these standards are described in more detail in the section ăVerantwortlichkeiten des Präfers.
We are independent in compliance with the Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants of the International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (IESBA Code) as well as with the relevant professional behavioural requirements and we have fulfilled our other professional behavioral obligations in compliance with these requirements and the IESBA Code.
We believe that the evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our judgment.
Responsibility of management and responsible for monitoring 3.1.2.
The management is responsible for the preparation and presentation of the annual accounts on the basis of internationally recognised accounting grounds for the public sector and for the legality and regularity of the accounts underlying these accounts.
This includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures, as necessary for the preparation and presentation of an annual financial statement that is free from material, intended or unintended, false representations.
The management of the agencies carries the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the accounts underlying their financial statements.
In the preparation of the annual accounts, the management is responsible for assessing the ability of the agencies to carry out business, applying the accounting principle of continuing business, unless management intends to either liquidate the establishment or discontinue business, or has no realistic alternative.
Responsibilities of the officer for the audit of the annual accounts and the underlying results 3.1.5.
Our objectives are to obtain sufficient certainty as to whether the annual accounts of the agencies are free from material misrepresentations and whether the underlying statements are correct and orderly, as well as to the European Parliament and the Council or other competent discharge authorities on the basis of our examination of the reliability of the accounts of the agencies as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying statements.
False representations and interpretations can be intended or unintended and will be considered essential if they could be expected individually or as a whole to incorporate the economic decisions made by users on the basis of these annual accounts.
3.1.6.
With regard to revenue, we shall examine the grants received by the agencies from the Commission or cooperating States and assess their procedures for collecting fees and other revenue, if relevant.
3.1.7.
As regards expenditure, we examine the payment arrangements after the expenditures have been paid, recorded and accepted.
Advance payments are made after the beneficiary has proven their proper use and the agency has accepted the proofs by billing the advance payment in the same year or later.
3.1.8.
As part of a review in agreement with the ISA and ISSAI, we exercise discretion during the whole review and maintain a critical attitude.
In addition, we identify and assess the risks of essential intentional or unintentional misrepresentations in the annual accounts, as well as of essential intentional or unintentional misrepresentation of the legal framework of the European Union in the underlying projections, plan and carry out preliminaries in response to these risks, and obtain evidence of trial that is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our judgements.
The risk that material misrepresentations or misrepresentations arising from non-doing acts will not be exposed to legislation is more likely than a misrepresentation resulting from misconduct, as non-doing acts may involve fraudulent interaction, executions, intended imperfections, misleading representations or the imposition of internal controls;
C 434/32 -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If we conclude that there is a substantial uncertainty, we are obliged, in our note of the final report, to draw attention to the relevant information in the annual accounts or, if this information is inappropriate, to modify our opinion.
We draw our conclusions on the basis of the evidence obtained up to the date of our final report.
We are responsible for the guidance, monitoring and execution of the inspection.
EN 3.1.9.
We exchange with the management, among other things, the planned scope and timing of the inspection as well as important inspection findings, including any significant regulations in the internal control system, which we recognize during our inspection.
3.1.10.
We determine from the facts that we have exchanged with the agencies, those facts that were the most important for the examination of the annual accounts of the current period and are therefore the most important examination facts.
We describe these facts in our note of the final expert, unless laws or other legal provisions exclude the public statement of the facts or we determine in very rare cases that a fact is not to be communicated in our note of the final practitioner, because it is expected that the negative consequences of such a communication will exceed their advantages for the public interest.
(24) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012.
AGENCY FOR ENERGY GOVERNMENT COOPERATION (ACER) INTRODUCTION 3.2.1.
The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Ljubljana, was established by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council (25).
Under the REMIT Regulation (26), the Agency and the national regulatory authorities have been entrusted with additional tasks in terms of monitoring the European energy wholesale market.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF ACCOUNTS 3.2.8. In the course of this year's audit of EU agencies, the Court analysed accounting, including the aspect of the timely (re)validation of accounting systems.
In October 2017, the Agency delegated its accounting function to the Commission's invoicing officer.
Despite this drastic change, the accounting system was last validated in 2011.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.2.9.
In 2011, the agency received an additional task in connection with the monitoring of the energy wholesale market (REMIT).
In 2017, for the first time, all the elements provided for by the REMIT monitoring framework were implemented.
However, the site originally set up in Maribor, Slovenia, was relocated to the Agency's main data center for disaster recovery in April 2017.
As a result, the backup data is now stored at the same location as the original data.
This represents a considerable risk for maintaining business operations in the event of disasters. COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY SURVEILLANCE AND SERVICES 3.2.10. On 29 March 2017, the United Kingdom (UK) informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, the agency did not undertake a comprehensive analysis of the potential impact of Brexit on its organisation, operations and accounting.
3.2.11.
The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), which would increase transparency and publicity and enable the citizens of Europe to consult job advertisements issued by the various European institutions and agencies.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/35 3.2.12.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (30) (31). As a requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT package covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
The agency had not introduced any of these tools by the end of 2017.
REPORTS OF THE INTERNAL AUDIT SERVICES 3.2.13.
In 2017, the Commission's Internal Audit Service presented a staff management report to the Agency(32). The Agency prepared an action plan to address areas where there is a potential need for improvement.

The Agency transferred EUR 4.9 million and 86 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: EUR 1.4 million and 59%).
As in previous years, these transfers were mainly linked to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation on the Integrity and Transparency of the Energy Wholesale Trade Market and amounted to 4.7 million euros in 2016 (2015: 1.1 million euros).
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency transferred EUR 1 million and 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million and 35% respectively).
The higher transfer rate is directly linked to the conclusion and signing of procurement procedures and parts of contracts towards the end of the year, leading to a shift of deliveries and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 sales were signed in November and December (5 976 122.47 euros and 40 % of the total value of the 2016 closed sales).
The Agency may carry out the implementation of a separate budget in order to better meet the multi-annual nature of the activities, as well as inevitable delays between contract signatures, deliveries and payments. EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/37 AGENCY REPLY 3.2.8.
The Agency agrees with the outcome and clarifies that the Agency records all financial transactions in the financial system provided by the European Commission, updated, maintained and validated by the Commission.
With the outsourcing of Service Accounting to the Commission from October 2017, the Agency will accept the validation of the accounting system provided by the Commission in 2018.
Since the ARIS prime location and the site for disaster management migrated to the internal ACER data centre at the beginning of April 2016 and was integrated into a single site in June 2017 to optimize and improve performance and address increasing space requirements, it is no longer possible to maintain operations.
However, it should be noted that the current situation, in which the maintenance of the holding cannot be ensured, has been imposed on the Agency by the serious reduction in its budget over the last two years.
The Agency has repeatedly warned the Commission and the budgetary authorities about the serious consequences of budgetary constraints, but without achieving any result in terms of additional resources.
The Agency will continue to demonstrate the ability to restore a site for disaster management for ARIS, but without providing the necessary resources in 2018.
The restoration of the site for disaster management would require additional financial resources from the Agency.
Given that the risks associated with BREXIT were considered to be low and limited, the management only carried out an informal analysis of Brexit in 2017.
At the beginning of 2018, the Agency published a comprehensive analysis of the impact of Brexit on the organisation management, operation and financial sectors, highlighting the impact and the necessary measures.
In 2014, the Agency's Management Board adopted Decision AB No 15/2014 on the Agency's language regime.
Nevertheless, the Agency still needs to translate the vacancies published on the EPSO website into all official EU languages.
Due to the very limited financial resources that have been repeatedly shown to the budget authority, the Agency is unable to raise the translation costs for each individual job advertisement in all official EU languages for the publication of this call on the EPSO website.
In 2017, four of the nine job advertisements, including two public calls, were published on the EPSO website and therefore translated into all official EU languages.
The remaining five tenders of positions in operational departments were published only on the Agency's website, since they were mainly of interest for applicants who are already active in the field and who usually follow the Agency's actions on our website.
This approach reflects a pragmatic emphasis between contact with potential candidates and efficient use of limited resources.

The financing of 2018 activities from the 2017 budget is in contradiction with the budgetary principle of annuality.
In August 2015, the B sucho launched an invitation to tender for a multi-service framework agreement in the cascade system, covering an estimated market volume of EUR 3 million for the organisation and planning of events such as meetings, workshops, conferences, etc.
Furthermore, the competitive procedure only covered the bidder's administrative fees, but not the potential event costs.
The award procedure thus did not lead to appropriate price competition, which might not have led to the most economically viable offer.

Cedefop uses the EPSO platform in some cases.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.5.8.
The Court considers it necessary for the purposes of strengthening the independence of the accountant by directing it to the Director (administrative concerns) and to the Board of Directors (functional concerns) of the Agency. COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER OF THE PROPOSALS 3.5.9.
Framework agreements are concluded with companies to determine the terms and conditions applicable during the period of the agreement for certain procurements (individual contracts).
The Agency used a framework agreement with three contractors in the cascade system to provide IT services of up to EUR 22 million.
In this procedure, the contractors are placed in a ranking (the cascade) following a competitive procedure, which must be respected in all individual cases.
However, the terms of the framework agreement were not specific enough to allow fair competition and to justify the establishment of a ranking of contractors for all future individual contracts.
Under the provisions of the Financial Regulation(54), individual contracts must be awarded under these conditions by means of a competitive procedure between the selected contractors.
3.5.10.
The Agency's financial regulations (55) must be approved by the Board of Directors, either in the Agency's annual work programme or through an ad hoc financing decision.
An IT framework agreement with a maximum amount of EUR 15 million was tendered and signed, although the financing decision covered only EUR 5 million.
In 2014, the Commission entered into a framework agreement on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including EASA) with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software as well as maintenance and support services (IT services).
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can provide the IT services.
Most of these IT services and the prices were defined in the framework agreement concluded on the basis of the competitive award procedure, but this also includes the procurement of non-specialised IT services.
In case of a paid payment of about 300 000 euros, the agency had acquired via the contractor IT services without competitive process.
In 2017, a total of EUR 2 million was paid to the contractor of the framework agreement.

3.5.9.
In order to prepare this procedure, the Agency carried out a market analysis and concluded that the main IT service providers supported all the necessary services under this procedure.
As a result, the Agency has concluded that a multi-framework agreement with a renewed call for competition would lead to a high administrative burden, which was considered to be immediate compared to the benefit that might result from it.
As with tenders with a high contract value and as a result of the Court's comment, the Agency will take steps to reopen competitions in the future in order to promote competition.
The aim of this framework agreement is to support the proof of concept and the initial phase of a new project (Data4Safety), whose financing and structure have developed over months with a number of parties.
The order value amounted to 15 million euros, but the financial obligations in the end amount to a maximum of 4 million euros.
Thus, the possibility of making payments beyond this amount escapes.
3.5.11.
The Agency considers that this approach, when using the existing interinstitutional framework agreement, is in line with the principle of sound financial management.
In the present case, a remuneration of EUR 24 816.60 was considered appropriate compared to the volume of the purchase and the required cost.
This facilitate was provided for in the framework agreement and the agency used it for compatibility purposes.
In 2015, the Agency's Management Board (Decision No 08-2015) decided that the working language of EASA is English in relation to the recruitment and selection procedures.
This decision was notified to the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), which does not accept the decision as an exception to its rules for the publication of job advertisements in all languages, and the decision does not meet the Agency's needs.
The network of agencies has recently set up an online platform that allows the agencies to publish their job advertisements on a wider scale.
EASA regularly publishes external job advertisements on this new platform.
3.5.13.
The Court noted that last year the instrument for the electronic submission of procurement procedures was introduced.
For electronic invoicing, the business specifications were completed in 2017, and the Agency's resources and priorities are looking for an IT solution.

The European Chemicals Agency (hereinafter the Agency), based in Helsinki, was established by Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council (68).
Its main task is to ensure a high level of protection for human health and the environment and to ensure the free movement of substances in the internal market while at the same time improving competitiveness and innovation.
The Agency also promotes the development of alternative assessment methods for risks associated with substances.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/57 Highlighting a case 3.7.5.
Without questioning the judgment in paragraph 3.7.4, the Court would like to stress that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a fee from any company applying for the registration of chemicals, as provided for in the REACH Regulation (72).
The applicable charges are based on the size of the enterprises (smallest enterprises, small, medium and large enterprises) and on the quantity of registered chemicals (various quantity thresholds).
3.7.6.
As provided for in the Financial Regulation(73), the Agency calculates and invoices the fees on the basis of information provided by the companies at the time of the application.
Since the first registrations in 2009, around 30 % of companies have reported that they are micro-enterprises, small or medium-sized enterprises.
The agency has made considerable efforts to set up a system for ex-postberprüfungen which will provide the information of these applicants on the enterprise size of the enterprise.
The Agency was thus able to establish that, on the basis of the operations completed so far, some 55% of the above-mentioned companies, which, according to their own figures, were micro, small or medium-sized enterprises (16% of all enterprises), had wrongly indicated their size, leading to lower costs.
To remedy this situation, the agency has charged around 16.4 million euros for the correction of expenses over the years as a result of ex-post inspections.
However, the overruns are considerably in decline, and the remaining amount of necessary fee corrections was not known at the end of 2017 (74).
This finding shows the limitations of a system that is too high based on self-disclosure by the applicants.
The REACH Regulation states that the quantity declared by the undertakings is the responsibility of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement.
The agency is therefore not involved in the supervision of this second element for the calculation of the costs.
Payments Jurisdiction of the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.7.8.
According to our assessment, the payments underlying the annual accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2017 are legal and orderly in all essential respects.
3.7.9.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.7.10.
The agency's ex-post surveys have shown that more than half of the companies that registered and reported chemicals were micro-enterprises, small or medium-sized enterprises that were incorrect in terms of size (see the paragraph highlighting a situation in point 3.7.5).
This can be explained in part by the Commission's complex rules for determining company size (75) and in part by the financial incentive to indicate too little size, since registration fees for companies are far higher.
Since the original registration fees are collected on the basis of the enterprise size indicated, false information can have a significant negative impact on the Agency's revenue if it is not discovered.
Although the agency is responsible for the specified size of the smaller companies in the context of ex-post processing, the overruns are considerably at the bottom of the list and only by 2012 (for the years with the largest registered quantities of chemicals).

3.7.12.
The exercise of the powers of enforcement is the responsibility of the Member States responsible for the enforcement of the quantities declared by the undertakings and the Agency has no powers of enforcement (see paragraph 3.7.5).
The measures taken by the enforcement authorities of the Member States are coordinated by the Forum for the exchange of information on enforcement.
On 6 December 2017, the Forum adopted new strategies and minimum criteria for the enforcement of chemical regulations (ăStrategies and minimum criteria for enforcement of chemical regulations), which provide a framework for the development of national enforcement strategies.
The Agency's ability to fulfil its mission depends on the effectiveness of the implementation of this framework by national authorities.
In its general report for 2017, the Agency states that around two thirds of companies did not update the registered information on the quantities of chemicals they handle.
This concerns the effective implementation of the REACH Regulation and also the accuracy of the calculation of costs.
COMMENTS ON THE EFFECTIVENESS OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.7.13. The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.7.14.
The Agency's revenue from fees is linked to the registration periods for chemicals in the EU, which are set out in the REACH Regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018).
The agency therefore does not impose any regular charges and has to struggle with a mismatch between relatively stable expenditure and more fluctuating, less predictable revenues, which makes budgeting more difficult.
The Agency is supported in dealing with this situation by a grant which it receives from the Commission.
As the third and final registration period for chemicals expires in 2018 under the REACH Regulation, revenues from fees and charges are expected to fall from 2019 and the Agency will be dependent on the EU budget to finance its operations.

In progress (1) In progress Outgoing ANNEX Follow-up of comments from previous years Statements by the Court The expenditures for procedures related to a new specific activity of the Agency, the implementation of the regulation on biocidal products, were in principle covered by charges for the evaluation of the application for registration of these products.
However, the fees collected in 2014 only covered 17% of this expenditure, so that the rest of the budget was actually financed by contributions from the Union (6.3 million euros) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euros) to the Agency's budget. At 10.1 million euros and 39% (2015: 7.3 million euros and 32%), the rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year was still high for Title III (operational expenditures - REACH). In Title IV (operational expenditure - biocides), it was even higher at 1.3 million euros and 68% (2015: 1.5 million euros and 74%).
Such a high transfer rate is contrary to the budgetary principle of legality. The agency can draw in agreement to use more and more separate budgetary resources to better cope with the multi-annual nature of the activities as well as inevitable delays between contract signings, deliveries and payments.
ECHA contributes to the functioning of the market for biocides and biocidal products.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the structure and practical implementation of the ECHA's internal control system in relation to the Agency's processes and activities under the Biocidal Products Regulation is effective and efficient.
Although no serious findings have been made, the IAS still sees a need for improvement.
Unlike most other agencies, ECHA's regulation does not explicitly require periodic external evaluations of their activities, which are essential for performance assessment.

EN C 434/60 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.7.10.
The relevant legislation (REACH-Gehrenverordnung (EC) 340/2008) does not stipulate that the Agency should carry out an ex-post verification of the size of all SME registrants.
The Agency's Board of Directors approved a concept in which SME registrants with the largest financial impact (i.e. with most registrations within the largest volume range) are given priority.
The agency 你berpr的ft currently the enterprise size of SME registrants, who submitted their dossiers until 2015. In 2017, the agency also focused on SME registrants from the United Kingdom, in order to overstep their enterprise size before the United Kingdom leaves the European Union.
In the future we will carry out the agency over the size of SMEs more on the basis of the cost-benefit principle.
3.7.11.
REACH Regulation (EC) No 340/2008 does not provide the Agency with any tools necessary to enforce the collection of excessive administrative charges.
The Agency proactively reminds debtors of their obligation to pay. If this is not successful, it commissions local law firms to apply the outstanding fees and charges directly in the Member States.
The law firms have so far contacted 74% of the companies that have to pay overfllige administrative fees. The result of this initiative is then subjected to a cost-benefit analysis to determine the next steps.
Member States have the primary responsibility for the enforcement of the REACH and CLP regulations, in particular the obligation to register chemical substances.
The ability of the agency to carry out its mission and to generate revenues from the fees to an appropriate extent depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of enforcement strategies by the national authorities.
Discussions are being held with the Commission to address this problem.
3.7.13.
The Agency takes note of the previous comment, which is a horizontal matter which concerns a number of agencies.
The Agency publishes job advertisements similar to other agencies on its own website, on social media and on the website of the EU Agency Network (EUAN) (https://euagencies.eu/).
In order to increase transparency and publicity and to enable the citizens to view job vacancies, the Agency recommends that the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) refer to the EUAN website.
3.7.14.
The previous remark is correct.
The Agency shall be financed by a combination of revenue from fees and charges and from a compensatory subsidy from the European Union.
The Agency has submitted a number of alternative financing proposals to the Commission, including the introduction of regular fees, as with some other EU agencies.
The Agency points out that, according to its Communication on the review of the REACH Regulation of 5 March 2018 (COM(2018) 116 final), the Commission will implement all possible options to ensure sustainable financing of the Agency in the future.

EUROPEAN INNOVATION AND TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE (EIT) INTRODUCTION 3.9.1.
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter referred to as the Institute), based in Budapest, was established by Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (82).
The aim of the Institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increase competitiveness by strengthening the innovation capacity of the Member States and the European Union.
The Institute provides financial support to an increasing number of Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) that combine higher education, research and the economy and thus foster innovation and entrepreneurship.
The KICs coordinate the activities of hundreds of partners.
