Other comments 3.9.7.
In December 2016 的 shortly before the end of the promotion period (1 January 2016-31 December 2016) 的 the EIT signed changes to the individual grant agreements with the KIC EIT Digital, InnoEnergy, Health and RawMaterials.
The modification of the individual grant agreement with Climate KIC was signed even in January 2017, after the end of the funding period.
The increase in individual reimbursements agreed in these changes allowed the KICs to receive an additional 15 million euros in EIT financial support (6.0 million euros in addition for Climate KIC, 5.6 million euros for EIT Health, 2.2 million euros for KIC InnoEnergy and 1.2 million euros for EIT RawMaterials).
This approach is contrary to the intention to encourage the KICs to develop sources of finance and to encourage them to gradually reduce their financial dependence from the EIT.
It could also affect fair competition between the KICs, as the co-financing of expenditure also plays a role in the annual grant decisions.
3.9.8.
Also due to changes in the business plans of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital, some of the non-provisional activities in the original business plans were added to the total value of around 3.3 million euros and 0.6 million euros respectively.
In the Court's view, the activity added in the case of KIC InnoEnergy constitutes a substantial change in the original business plan, on the basis of which the maximum amount of financial assistance has been obtained.
As the amount of the grants awarded to each KIC is the result of a performance-oriented over-the-counter procedure to which their originally proposed operations are subject, further substantial changes to these agreements may be considered to be the grant decisions and equal treatment of the KICs and hence an infringement of Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation.
3.9.9.
COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.9.10.
In 2017, the Institute introduced a paperless payment system.
Although this resulted in changes in his procedures and his accounting system, the accounting system has not been revalidated since 2012.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.9.11.
In order to further strengthen the internal control system for financial assistance to KICs, the EIT set up centralised ex ante controls for those KIC partners whose cost statements exceeded EUR 325 000.
The controls were carried out by two economic operators on behalf of the EIT (86) and led to certified cost statements by the KIC partners.
The results of ex post controls carried out by another EIT-managed business organisation confirm that the new approach to certified cost statements is effective and important, as most of the significant errors identified concerned cost statements that had not been subjected to these ex ante controls.
(86) In previous years, the certification was carried out by many private economic operators on behalf of the individual KIC partners whose submitted cost statements exceeded the threshold of 325 000 euros (refund of actual costs and unit costs).
EN C 434/66 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.12.
The business continuity plan and the plan for re-launching following a disaster recovery plan of the EIT were adopted in 2013 and are outdated.
For example, more than half of the members of the crisis management team no longer worked for the EIT in 2017.
An updated version of the Pl的ne has been under construction for two years, but it has not yet been adopted.
As in previous years, the KICs have not exhausted the grants granted by the EIT in full.
The total eligible cost of the KIC added value activities of the FMI, which were functional before 2016 (KICs of the first and second wave combined), were 15% lower than those adopted in the individual financial assistance agreements concluded at the beginning of 2016 (87).
The fact that the funds were not used was mainly due to the -- partly due to the late approval of the grant agreements and the multi-annual nature of the KIC activities conditional ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Some of these funds have been used to increase the costs associated with KIC-value-added activities, as originally set out in individual refund rates (see point 3.9.7).
In particular, the second wave KICs (EIT Health and RawMaterials) had to struggle with delays in starting their activities.
The performance of Climate KIC was particularly insufficient for the first wave KICs, according to the EIT assessment reports.
3.9.14.
The EIT assessed the implementation of the business plans and then calculated some corrections.
However, these corrections did not have any financial impact on the KICs.
In line with the Horizon 2020 methodology for the grant calculation, the EIT applies only the higher of the two in the case of corrections that become necessary due to financial controls and performance assessments.
While this methodology is appropriate for individual Horizon 2020 projects, it is less appropriate for the grants granted to the KICs, which finance a wide range of different activities.
It is questionable whether it is justified to set aside corrections made on the basis of performance, for example for educational activities, against corrections made on the basis of financial controls, which may, for example, affect innovation projects.
3.9.15.
In 2017, all KICs, in line with the EIT's strategies for sustainable financing, took an important step towards a greater sustainability of KICs in the future.
Nevertheless, the KICs of the first wave still generated little revenue (between 2% and 6% of the costs of the KIC value added activities) and little progress was made in 2017.
Co-financing by the KIC partners is also low (and lower than in the original individual financial assistance agreements): KIC value-added activities are still financed by 62% to 90% of EIT funding, depending on the KIC.
3.9.16.
The EIT publishes job advertisements on its own website and on the DG Human Resources and Security website, but usually not on the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) website.
3.9.17.
The agencies should define a common definition of electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (88). The Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT framework covering all stages of public procurement procedures as well as for the EU institutions.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic call for tenders in the online edition of the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.9.18.
The current interim director of the EIT took office in July 2014.
A selection procedure for the appointment of a new director was launched in 2016, but remained unsuccessful.
Since then, no new recruitment procedure has been initiated.
To fill this post over such a long period of time ad interim is contrary to the statute, according to which a post may be occupied temporarily for a maximum of a year.
3.9.19.
Article 5(1) of the Statute of the EIT shall be directly employed by the EIT staff within the framework of temporary contracts and shall apply to the staff of the EIT to the conditions of employment of other servants of the European Union.
The EIT can therefore offer temporary workers only temporary jobs with a maximum duration of five years, which can be renewed by five years.
Those employees who have started their work at the EIT shortly after its establishment in 2009 will reach the maximum contract term of ten years in 2020, which in the coming years could lead to objections to the continuity of the measures and the administration.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/69 DE Comments of the Court of Justice of the EIT-Grundungsverordnung regarding the tasks of the institute the ămobilization of funds from public and private sources and [the] use of resources according to the provisions of this regulation.
In particular, the Institute aims to raise a significant and growing share of its budget from private financial contributions and revenue generated by its own activities.
Despite this provision, which clearly refers to the budget of the EIT, the contribution from Horizon 2020 was 99% of its budget for 2015.
Although the institution may use unused funds (i.e. funds not committed or released at the end of the year) in the budget for the following three years, it has not adjusted its procedures in time to allow EUR 26.6 million available from the 2014 grant agreements in the budget for the years 2015-2017.
These funds were available because the KICs used less funding than expected.
According to the Commission's original objective, the Institute should gain its financial autonomy in 2010.
In June 2011, however, the Institute received financial autonomy only in part, as grant proposals and procurement procedures worth more than EUR 60 000 will continue to be subject to prior approval by the Directorate-General for Education and Culture (which is superordinate to it).
The Institute supports the Master School programme of EIT Digital, in which 16 European universities participate.
The model for the reimbursement of the costs of the universities is based on a combination of a lump sum of at most 8 000 Euro/students (comprising the provisions of the Erasmus Mundus programme) plus the actual costs including flat-rate calculated indirect costs.
On this basis, the universities received an average of 15 000 Euro/students in 2015 (including the lump sum).
However, the model was not fixed at any time, and it is not possible to distinguish which activities fall under the lump sum and which fall under the actual costs.
The Institute should convert the cost claim to a clear, formalised model based on a single method, such as a single lump sum based on proof of costs.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/71 EN Court's comments The financial assistance for the calendar year 2015 was awarded only in April 2015 and the grant agreements were signed in June and July 2015.
For the calendar year 2016, grants were awarded and the grant agreements were signed in April 2016.
Despite an improvement in 2016, these delays in the decisions on the award of grants and the signing of grant agreements lead to uncertainty and to the willingness of partners to commit resources at the beginning of the year and to initiate activities.
The most recent calls for new KICs, whose thematic areas were defined in the Strategic Innovation Agenda of the EIT for the period 2014-2020, will be subject to little competition.
Only seven proposals were submitted for the call for two KICs (Health and RawMaterials) launched in 2014.
Following the 2016 call for two additional KICs (food and manufacturing) three proposals were received, and the only proposal for KIC manufacturing (additional value in manufacturing) was not selected from quality sources.
The position of director has been occupied since August 2014 and another post of leadership since February 2013 is occupied by ad interim.
This is not only against the Statute, which states that the temporary occupation may not last longer than one year, but that the frequent changes and long-term interim changes are also unsettling the stakeholders and affect the strategic continuity. With a budget of 2.4 billion euros in the period 2014-2020, the Institute is an important player in the implementation of the Horizon 2020 programme.
The Commission has created a central support body for Horizon 2020 to ensure coherence between the programme-run bodies in areas such as legal services, IT tools, grant management, dissemination and exploitation of research results, etc.
However, unlike institutions such as the Commission's executive agencies and public-private partnerships, the Institute does not have direct access to the support body, but must be approved by the Commission's superordinate directorate-general.
This requirement affects the efficiency of the Institute's activities.

C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the legal entities of the KICs, which are financed almost entirely by the Institute.
The Court's examination focused on the award procedures carried out by these bodies, which it considers to be a highly risky area.
In accordance with the 2015 grant agreements, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must ensure that the best possible price-performance ratio is achieved in procurements or that the lowest price criterion is applied where appropriate.
For all contracts over EUR 60 000, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners shall, according to the grant agreements, require at least three economic operators to tender and document the award procedure to demonstrate its transparency.
The Court carried out a sample of procurement procedures worth around 7 million euros, carried out by the legal entities of the KIC and financed entirely by the EIT.
The investigation has revealed significant implications, such as direct procurement, lack of essential elements in tenders, significant increases in the original length and/or size of contracts, increases without limitation of duration and/or size, or quality/price weights, which have reduced price competition.
The Institute had also identified the organisations involved in the procurement procedures of a KIC legal entity, and had drawn up an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KIC legal entities in the future.
Despite the substantial increase in the budget from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to EUR 2.4 billion (2014-2020) and despite the fact that there have been six KICs since the end of 2016, and no longer three KICs, the number of posts approved to the Institute has hardly changed (see Table 2).
As the Court noted in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have sufficient capacity to address the increased workload.
The interim director of the institute pointed to this risk in the annual report of the institute for 2015.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/73 REPLY OF THE INSTITUTE 3.9.7.
The EIT would like to make it clear that changes to the individual grant agreements pursuant to the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements of the EIT can be submitted at any time during the period.
The amendments of the KICs were subject to a technical and financial assessment by the EIT and prior approval by the European Commission.
The changes were subsequently signed in December 2016.
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC was formally notified of the approval of the amendment application on 21 December 2016 (i.e. within the period of application).
Regarding the increase in individual reimbursements, the EIT points out that no additional amount of financial assistance was paid out to KICs as a result of the changes to the individual financial assistance agreements in 2016.
The total amount of the final financial assistance (241.8 million euros) was significantly lower than the initial amount (274.9 million euros).
As regards the call for KICs to develop their own sources of financing and to become financially viable, we refer to our response to section 3.9.15.
In the context of the assessment of the amendments, the EIT, after consultation with the European Commission, concluded that the adjustment of the individual reimbursements complies with the applicable legal basis and does not affect the equal treatment of KICs.
The possibility of adjusting the individual refund rates was open to all KICs on equal terms.
As regards the second observation, the EIT considers that the amendments complied with Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation's implementing provisions, since they did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants and did not run counter to equal treatment of applicants.
It should be noted that there is no provision for a materiality threshold that shows which change of a measure is to be considered as significant when assessing whether the change is relevant for the grant.
Whether the inclusion of new activities corresponds to that provision must be determined on a case-by-case basis on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the entire KIC business plan.
The EIT carried out the assessment before the approval of the change plans and came to the conclusion that the changes did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants.
Since each KIC had the power to include new and new activities in its changed businesses on equal terms, the equal treatment of KIC was also ensured.
Finally, the EIT points out that, in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity that could be considered was only 3.9% of the modified budget estimate of the KIC's business plan.
For EIT Digital, this share was 0.6%.
3.9.10.
3.9.12.
The updated versions of the contingency plan and the plan for re-launching following a system breakdown will be adopted by the EIT in 2018.
3.9.13.
The 2016 individual financial assistance agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed more recently than planned, as the framework partnership agreements had to be signed first.
The individual financial assistance agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, so that the KICs could start their activities in good time in the respective year.
Due to their dynamic and fast-moving nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly.
Some innovation projects or projects do not meet the expectations of their potential and must be discontinued during the implementation of the grant agreements. Moreover, some of the operational activities of the KICs, such as master's and doctoral studies or long-term research and innovation projects, are planned from the ground up for several years.
The EIT intends to address this issue after 2020 by entering into multiannual grant agreements with KICs, provided the EIT budget allocates corresponding appropriations for commitments in multi-annual tranches.
In fact, the EIT has followed the methodology laid down in the legal basis ăHorizont 2020 and will continue to comply with current legislation.
The financial sustainability of KIC is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most difficult aspects of the EIT's mission.
In the meantime, some of the innovation communities can already have a substantial co-financing, which they can do, and generate considerable revenue compared to their budgets.
EIT Digital has co-financed 26% (22 million euros) to pay the costs for the 2016 KIC value added activities. In addition, the partner organisations carried out and paid additional KIC activities of more than 200 million euros.
Another example is EIT Health: In its first operating year, KIC generated more than EUR 6 million in revenue compared to the total funding it had received from the EIT (around EUR 19 million).

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.10.8.
In 2014, the Commission entered into a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of software licenses and maintenance and support services on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency).
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can meet the needs of the agency.
For these intermediate services, the contractor of the framework agreement adds two to nine percent to the supplier prices. In 2017, the contractor of the framework agreement paid a total of 1.7 million euros.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and discounts with the offers of the companies and did not systematically check the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework agreement. 3.10.9.
Following a court decision, the EPSO decided that only job advertisements in the official languages of the EU or in the languages indicated in the Agency's legislation can be published on the EPSO website.
Because of the high translation costs of this new policy (about EUR 19000 per advertised post), EMSA and many other agencies no longer use EPSO services in their job advertisements.

EMSA would like to see a solution that would provide both sufficient transparency and comply with the principle of sound financial management.

It should be noted that most of EMSA's job advertisements are addressed to technical professionals who regularly access the EMSA website.

The rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year is high for Title II (administrative expenditure) at EUR 0.3 million and 25% (2015: EUR 0.15 million and 22%).
This high rate is mainly due to transfers of funds for Title I (staff expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is mainly related to IT investments made shortly before the end of the year and the acquisition of a service car.
As foreseen in the Agency's financial rules, external evaluations of the Agency's performance for 2014 and 2015 were carried out; the final reports were submitted in October 2015 and May 2016 respectively.
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the operational core competences undertaken under the 2014 work programme are clearly related to the Agency's legal mandate and that the Agency's effectiveness has been well assessed.
However, there was a need for improvement in the division of the agency between Heraklion and Athens, which is leading to heavy workloads and a lack of communication and cooperation.
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs meet a need for network and information security throughout the EU and in the Member States and that the Agency effectively meets the expectations of its stakeholders.
However, the report stressed that the communication between the Agency and its stakeholders, whose view is that the mandate and reach of the Agency are too limited, needs to be improved.
The Agency is currently implementing an action plan which it has subsequently agreed with the Management Board.
In 2016, the Agency moved eight more employees to Athens, reducing the number of employees in Heraklion to 14 (1).
As the Court pointed out in its 2013 report, costs could probably be further reduced by pooling the entire staff at one location.

The transfer to the new invoicer was never formalized, but informal meetings with the former current invoicer took place to pass on knowledge.
The new accountant also received an updated training on SAP to ensure a good understanding of the accounting system.
Nevertheless, ENISA will take corrective measures to ensure an adequate transfer between outgoing and new staff.
3.11.9.
All vacancies published by the EPSO must be translated into all official EU languages.
In view of its limited budget, ENISA is unfortunately unable to bear these costs.
However, the Agency uses traditional and social media and has pledged its cooperation in the creation of an agency-wide portal to reduce the risks associated with the publication of job offers, as many of the decentralised institutions face the same problem.
ENISA has not carried out a formal operational and financial impact assessment of Brexit, since it has no significant direct impact on the budget, operation and administration of ENISA.
However, internal procedures (i.e. procurement and recruitment) were revised in the context of Brexit.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.12.8.
In December 2016, the Agency's accountant was appointed interim manager of the Financial and Procurement Department in addition to this function.
In the context of this additional function, it is responsible for the management of the staff, which is responsible for initiating and supervising commitments and payments.
The financial rules of the Agency stipulate that those financial operators are under the authority of the authorising officer.
However, according to the principle of separation of duties, powers of instruction and accounting are separate functions and exclude each other.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency) with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software as well as maintenance and support services (IT services).
In case of a paid payment of around 47 000 euros, the agency had acquired IT services from the contractor without any competitive process or prior market analysis. In 2017, payments to the contractor in total amounted to 1.1 million euros.

Emphasis on a situation 3.16.7.
On 15 December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement worth EUR 1.5 billion on the operation of the Galileo satellite system during the period 2017-2027.
The agreement was awarded following a public procurement procedure.
One of the tenderers involved brought proceedings against the Agency before the Court of Justice of the European Union in order to challenge the outcome of the award procedure.
The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union will decide on the legality and regularity of the procurement procedure for the framework agreement and all associated individual contracts and future payments.
The Agency reported the situation in the 2017 annual accounts and explained that in 2017 49 million euros (7 % of the 2017 budget including the amounts received by the transfer agreements) were paid out in connection with the framework agreement.
Note 3.16.8.
Negotiations on an agreement on the details of the withdrawal are under way.
The Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom.
In the annual accounts, the Agency refers to the Commission's decision, adopted on 24 January 2018, to move the second location of the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) from the United Kingdom to Spain in the chapter ăEvents after the closing date.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/101 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Court comments The property, plant and equipment (net book value: EUR 1.0 million) are not insured.
The accounting systems were last validated in 2012.
The agreed validation of the systems has not taken place due to the expected substantial changes in the procedures and the flow of information after the relocation of the agency.
The new accountant plans the next validation for 2020.
The Agency has set up Emergency Continuity Plans for security sites in France, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.

The Agency's annual work plan for 2015 was adopted only in March 2015, and the adoption of its multiannual work programme 2014-2020 is still pending.
The late adoption of central planning documents carries risks for the achievement of the Agency's objectives.
In 2015, the agency had a high staff turnover with 14 retired and 26 new employees.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that no agency-wide annual risk assessment was carried out in 2016 and that the significant risks for the Agency are not identified in its planning documents or in its activity reports.
In addition, the IAS noted that the terminology used for the various elements of the performance measurement system is not uniform, which makes performance monitoring more difficult.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures. At 2.8 million euros and 46% (2015: 2.5 million euros and 42%), the rate of committed appropriations for Title II (administrative expenditure) for the following financial year was high.
EN C 434/102 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.16.10.
The GSA agrees with the Court's comment.
In 2015, the GSA outsourced its accounts to the European Commission, so that the Commission's invoicing officer (within the DG Budget) provided all the services, including the validation of local systems, required under Article 50 of the framework financial regulation applicable to the agencies.
The validation approach is currently being worked out and planned within DG Budget services.
3.16.11.
Publicising job advertisements on the EPSO platform requires translation into all EU official languages, whereas English is the Agency's only working language and publication of vacancies in English is considered a first step in preselection to ensure that our working language is first understood.
In addition, the translation of job advertisements into all EU official languages would mean an additional financial and time-consuming effort for the agency, so that it doesn't derive any benefit from the above reasons. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all job advertisements on the agency's cross-border portal, which the agencies consider equivalent to the EPSO and offers the EU citizens a sufficient amount of transparency.
In addition, the agency also publishes its job advertisements on specialized space websites.
Electronic communications in TED (published by the Office for Publications) are currently used in the GSA for the publication of contract notices, award notices, notices on corrections, modification notices, etc. whenever this is indicated in accordance with Article 264 of the applicable provisions.
The Agency also intends to use the e-Tendering system TED to create and publish tenders.
Against this background, GSA is currently coordinating with the Office for Publications to register and create a system account.
With regard to offers of high value (above the thresholds of Article 118(1) HO), the GSA is currently undertaking the necessary administrative steps to use the ăe Submission module of the information system ăe-PRIOR (presented by DG DIGIT) developed by the European Commission to ensure that the electronic system set up for the submission of all offers meets all the requirements of the HO and AB.
It is pointed out that the module ăe-Submission is currently supported exclusively by open procedures and the GSA is therefore allowed to use it only for such procedures.
In this context, the GSA has already held an initial coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is about to finalise and sign an agreement with it to define the framework for ăe Submission and start implementing it.

COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY ASSURANCE AND SERVICES 3.17.9.
The Agency welcomes the fact that the Court wishes to further improve its management of the ETZ in terms of both financial and operational controls.
In order to remedy a repeat of the problem encountered by the ETZ in 2017 in terms of inland, coastal and marine waters, the task was taken out of the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency.
The Agency is committed to maintaining the current level of control of grants granted to the ETZ.
The Agency confirms that it has changed the requirements relating to the financial performance of bidders in the course of 2017 and that the bidders are now required to provide information on financial indicators (liquidity, solvency and profitability); furthermore, in accordance with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the Rules of Application (AB), a minimum turnover is now required which must be at least twice the value of the estimated annual contract value.
The Agency would like to stress once again that the decision to offer framework contracts to individual contractors has been taken, aware and taking into account the fact that competition is limited to the relevant markets, as well as the nature and complexity of the services to be provided.
In the allocation of individual assignments on the basis of the framework contracts, the Agency takes into account not only the contractually agreed days, but also the number of days required for the execution of the tasks, in order to calculate a value for the budget, which must be set for a specific individual assignment.
Only then will negotiations be opened with the contractor on the details of his offer, always taking care to achieve the best price-performance ratio.
In the event of a reopening of the tender, the Agency has no control over any further negotiations about the tenderers' bids.
In line with the decision of the Board of Directors of 9 November 2015 to establish in the EEA an electronic invoicing system for procurement procedures, the Agency introduced certain procedures for electronic invoicing in the course of 2014 and is now in the process of extending the application of this module to all its procedures, whereas the electronic tendering system has been in force since 1 January 2015 for all general invitations to tender.
The integration of the electronic submission of tenders was started at the beginning of December 2017, and the first call for tenders in which this module was used was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002 ).
The Agency takes note of the Court's remark and confirms that it is currently adapting its selection/ recruitment procedures to the following points: a) The completion of the individual steps in the various stages (pre-selection, selection, interview and written examination) is confirmed in the relevant documents in addition to the time (not only with the date). b) An electronic (paperless) procedure is introduced in order to improve the reporting process.
3.17.14.
The EPSO has rejected a publication for the agency with the recognition that the precondition that all job offers are to be translated into all official languages is not fulfilled.
However, the Agency does not have the resources or resources to respond to the request of the EPSO.
In this case, not only all job offers should be translated, but also the applications should be processed in all official languages, which entails unsustainable additional costs.
As with most other EU agencies, the Agency has therefore looked for an alternative to the EPSO website and has been using a website that fulfils the same purpose since May 2018 for its announcements; it is the Job Advertisement Board set up and maintained by the network of EU agencies.
In addition, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and Facebook pages to ensure the best possible distribution.

Emphasis on a situation 3.20.8.
From the end of 2017, the personnel situation at the B的ro deteriorated exponentially.
At management level, four out of ten Head of Unit posts and 18 out of 27 Head of Division posts were not filled.
Three out of four Head of Unit posts and five out of ten Head of Division posts were not filled in the ăVerwaltung's department, which represents a serious challenge for the leadership level of the team.
Furthermore, at the end of May 2018, 129 posts were filled for temporary staff, but 78 were still open.
Of the posts of contract staff, 71 were occupied and 13 were still open.
The B sucho currently does not have the administrative capacity to fill so many vacancies (see Table 2).
On the whole, the continuation of the activities of the B such as this is largely due to this situation.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ADMINISTRATIVEITY OF PAYMENTS AND INTERNAL CONTROLS OF ENTERPRISES The nature of its activities gives rise to large risks for the company 3.20.9.
Since 2016, the B的ro has been faced with an unprecedented expansion of tasks and activities to provide operational and technical support to Member States in the context of the migration crisis.
This is reflected in an increase in budget appropriations from the original EUR 19 million in 2016 to EUR 79 million following the second change in the 2017 budget.
The number of award procedures increased from 87 in 2015 to 140 in 2017.
Payments increased by 225% from 2 578 in 2015 to 8 381 in 2017.
3.20.10.
The B-ro is one of the few institutions of the European Union which has several locations.
In addition to its headquarters in Malta, with 179 staff members, the agency manages two large-scale support activities in Greece and Italy, involving 747 experts from Member States and associated countries, 202 cultural intermediaries (interpreters), 178 temporary workers and 21 staff members of the agency.
3.20.11.
As the Court noted in its Special Report No. 6/2017 ăReaction of the EU to the refugee crisis: the Hotspot concept, the B
The efficiency of the activities is particularly stressed by the fact that Member States send their experts for a very short period of time (six to eight weeks).
The extraordinary operational challenge posed by the migration crisis was not weakened by a sound management structure and effective internal controls 3.20.12.
When Greece and Italy started to support their efforts in 2015, the bank was confronted with the fact that Member States provided insufficient resources for their deployments.
It had already made it difficult for the office to fill the posts set out in its establishment plan.
Since 2014, the court has regularly repeated its remark that the B的ro has to struggle with a high staff turnover.
In its previous annual reports, the Court repeatedly stressed that this situation represents a serious risk for achieving the objectives set out in the annual and multiannual work programmes.
Despite repeated attempts (36 recruitment procedures and 100 new assignments in 2017), the company has failed to recruit and maintain employees (see also paragraph 3.20.8).
3.20.13.
The extraordinary challenge in the operational area due to the migration crisis was not weakened by a solid management structure.
The Board of Directors did not set up an internal audit post at the company, and the actions in Greece and Italy were not subject to an internal audit.
By the end of 2017, the Board of Directors had limited oversight of the budget.
3.20.14.
In the case of the B有ro, neither an internal legal service is established nor legal documents are systematically implemented internally.
The Bureau distributes most of the legal questions (mainly personnel and procurement questions) to outside, without having clearly defined in internal decisions or guidelines, who can award which legal questions externally, to which law firm and under what conditions.
Although the B:ro uses at least eight different law firms, there is no comprehensive list of all relevant departments, cases and expert opinions.
3.20.15.
Legal services are not adequately handled by the company to ensure that they are exclusively used to defend the interests of the company and not to defend the interests of individuals.
The relevant procedures to protect against conflicts of interest are not always effective.
In general, the use of external means reduces the possibility of settling disputes before bringing an action.
3.20.16.
The facts set out in paragraphs 3.20.13-3.20.14 expose the bureau to the risk of financial losses and distortions of reputation.
These matters are currently being examined internally by the B:ro.
Many significant infringements of rules resulting from the lack of internal controls payments for auxiliary benefits 3.20.17.
In 2017, €7.7 million was paid for auxiliary services.
Since no competitive public procurement procedure had taken place, the Court found the order for auxiliary services in Greece to be contrary to the law in respect of the year 2016.
Nevertheless, in 2017 the company still made payments of EUR 4.8 million within the framework of this unlawful order.
EN C 434/120 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.18.
The procurement procedures for auxiliary services carried out in Malta in 2017 (volume of payments in 2017: EUR 1.0 million) were inadequate in their execution (e.g. short deadlines for the submission of tenders, lack of transparency in the extension of time limits), which was one of the most important reasons for the competition in public procurement procedures.
As a result, the procedures had to be repeated several times because no tenders were received.
3.20.19.
The services were insufficiently controlled for compliance with national regulations for temporary employment, which exposed the agency to significant financial and reputational risks.
Furthermore, the revision of working time certificates for temporary staff and established irregularities had considerable weaknesses.
Payments for staff expenditure 3.20.20.
The staff-related payments amounted to EUR 13.5 million in 2017. The Court found serious errors in four of the 14 recruitment procedures.
3.20.21.
For example, the B的ro did not publish a job advertisement to fill the post of senior consultant, but did the recruitment directly on the basis of a reserve list that had been prepared for the post of head of department.
The extension of the deadline was not always justified given the number of applications received by the original deadline.
3.20.22.
Some procedures for hiring AD staff were not appropriate for the advertised grade.
In a procedure for filling a management post in the ăVerwaltungstung (administrative department), the job advertisement was more restrictive than for the same posts in other departments.
In another procedure, the examination of the suitability of the applicants was not adequately documented by the B-ro.
Payments for rents and related works 3.20.23.
The total rent for all the bikes at the different locations amounted to two million euros in 2017.
The Court noted that the B的ro had signed the rental contract for the expansion of the headquarters in Malta and several new B suchos in Athens, Lesbos and Chios without having properly analysed the local market beforehand.
3.20.24.
In June 2017, the B sucho signed a lease agreement with B suchoflachen in Lesbos.
It also accepted a contract with the landlord - without any competition ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The value of the building contract (0.7 million euros during the first months of the rental contract) exceeded the annual value of the rental contract many times.
The investment of significant investments in rented buildings is accompanied by serious financial and operational risks.
3.20.25.
In 2018, the B sucho decided to contract a rental agreement with B suchoflachen in Chios and related construction services.
It is currently designed to limit the financial exposure to risk as a result of cancellation.
Payments for travel expenses 3.20.26.
The Court held an order for travel services to the value of 4 million euros for the year 2016 in violation of the law.
The contract was awarded to a bidder who did not meet all the selection criteria.
On the basis of this irregular order, the bank continued to make payments at an amount of 1.5 million in 2017.
3.20.27.
In 2017, the B sucho identified significant errors in the recognition of travel services, in particular the lack of evidence to demonstrate that the travel services concerned were actually requested or provided.
This matter is currently being examined internally by the Bureau.
Other payments 3.20.28.
In addition, other services such as cleaning services, security services, interpreting and consulting services, which were based on public procurement procedures, were systematically affected by the same rules.
The Court established considerable rules for the determination of needs for the purposes of the contract, the preparation of specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the award procedures applied, the time limits for the submission of tenders, the evaluation and award procedures (i.e. the weighting of the price criteria against the quality criteria), the changes and extensions of contracts, the execution of the contracts and the overhaul of the services provided.
These rules have an impact on the basic principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination of bidders.
The following digits contain some examples for the above mentioned angels.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/121 3.20.29.
In 2017, the B的ro awarded a service contract on advisory services related to the implementation of the Action Plan on the Greek islands.
The contract was awarded to a pre-selected economic operator without any of the procurement procedures provided for in the Financial Regulation being applied.
The procurement procedure and all related payments (EUR 992000) were therefore unlawful.
3.20.30.
Since then, the company has changed the original contract of EUR 5000 with a law firm in 2016 several times and increased it to EUR 259000 in 2018.
Payments of EUR 98332 in total were made to the contract in 2017, partly for consultancy services, which required a competitive public procurement procedure.
The changes and payments concerning these consultancy services were therefore contrary to the rules.
3.20.31.
The execution of the 2013 contract (value: 120 000 euros, 2017 raised to 132 000 euros) about the organisation of four to six large events in an international hotel for a period of four years was not in line with the original subject of the contract.
The club used the contract instead for about 50 smaller events.
The execution of the contract has therefore not taken place in accordance with the law.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY FOOD 3.20.32.
According to the agreements between the European Union and the Kingdom of Norway, the Swiss Confederation and the Principality of Liechtenstein (also referred to as associated countries) regarding their participation in the project, the associated countries are fully involved in the work of the project and are entitled to support measures of the project.
In 2016 the B-ro received financial assistance from the Commission to ensure adequate capacity building in Greece, to support the implementation of the declaration of the European Union and Turkey, and to substantially accelerate the redistribution in order to reduce the current high burden for Greece.
All these activities are part of the core business of the "B"ros, not the support of measures of common interest.
The B-ro used the financial assistance for payments (EUR 6.4 million in 2016 and EUR 1.7 million in 2017) of commitments made in connection with these activities.
However, it did not include these interests in the calculation of the contributions of the associated countries.
If these contributions were included, the associated countries would have to pay EUR 0.5 million more.

DE C 434/126 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE B
At the same time, the Court is grateful for the Court's appreciation of the difficult situation, in which the Court found itself during the period under review due to the enormous expansion of its tasks: it has also been charged with supporting Member States and contributing to the implementation of initiatives at EU level, including redistributing and explaining EU Turkey, increasing the budget, the exponential increase in payments and the increase in procurement procedures (both in terms of number and complexity).
On top of this, the company has to manage a large number of sites and numerous management positions (department heads, department heads, sector heads) are not filled.
In his reply, the Bureau will respond to some of the Court's observations, but as a whole it accepts the report and the findings contained in it.
3.20.6. and 3.20.13.
With regard to the systematic violations of the regulations in the B-ro, under the new leadership, the B-ro started with the introduction of the necessary steps to ensure that the observance of the regulations gained priority and became the central element of the culture and in the implementation of all its measures.
This includes objective, honest and open internal control, self-assessment.
The Court accepts the Court's finding that the surveillance structures and internal control structures responsible by the Court have not received the attention in the past that is necessary to ensure an adequate level of justice and order.
In this respect, too, it would like to see the structure and procedures set up for the systematic performance of lawfulness and orderliness (and correspondingly pr的zise and comprehensive reporting) as absolute priority under the new leadership.
3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12.
The Court rightly underlines the fact that the staff situation in the country has deteriorated and is insufficient and that it is also an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal control system.
The current personnel situation is one of the main challenges in the context of the resolution of the angels identified by the Court in its comments, which can be seen to a large extent as a result of the lack of resources for structured and regular work.
The Committee directly addresses this problem and, on the basis of a sound recruitment plan leading to a need assessment, is urgently engaged in recruitment procedures to fill management posts and other important (operational and administrative) posts.
In addition, the office makes efforts in the area of employee satisfaction to solve the problem of staff turnover. Although it is important to bear in mind that the low correction coefficient plays an important role in this respect compared to the relatively high cost of living in Malta, the office acknowledges that more efforts must be made to improve employee satisfaction.
Some measures such as flexible work opportunities, improved internal communication and organisation of employee events have already been introduced.
3.20.9. and 3.20.19.
The Court gives a correct description of the difficulties and the rapid increase in financial transactions and procurement procedures, expressed in absolute figures.
These figures speak a clear language, but basically reflect the balances in finance and not adequate in awarding.
These figures do not take into account other facts and measures which add to the mandatory situation in the procurement sector, such as the following two aspects: the involvement of externally funded experts (Articles 204 and 287 of the Financial Regulations), which represent a high workload for the procurement sector.
In the coming years a further deterioration is to be expected in this respect, as the B-ro [medical] experts must be involved in the support of tasks related to medical information regarding countries of origin.
Market-specific difficulties and limitations connected with our geographical areas of activity.
In the Italian and Greek regions, conditions for a competitive market for the provision of services and products are not very good.
In addition, as a customer, the company is not typical of the order size of economic operators in Malta, as they usually lack the capacity to meet the requirements related to the larger subsidiaries of the company.
3.20.10.-3.20.12. and 3.20.19.
This characteristic is essential for the understanding of the verheltnism, when it comes to implementing functioning internal control structures.
It should also be noted that due to its operational capacity, its geographically wide area of operation and (as the Court rightly notes) the restrictions on the use of Member State experts, the company is dependent on contractors to an unusually large extent.
This is a factor which has the effect of multiplying the tasks associated with the procurement and financial sector (including decentralised financial actors) since, for Greece, Italy and Cyprus,
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/127 and for hotspots in Greece and Italy are required in each case specific distributions (leasing vertrege, cleaning, safety, water supply as well as irrevocable services e.g. on the provision of auxiliary and interpreting services).
In this case, too, staff have a crucial role to play, and the company is currently (in recognition of the multiplication factor due to its capacity as a multi-site agency) able to allocate the necessary resources to ensure overall accuracy and quality in the award and financial cycles, as well as legal and regulatory capacity and to have the decentralisation carried out by a consulting firm.
3.20.14, 3.20.15 and 3.20.16.
The B sucho acknowledges the need to have internal legal expertise, and accepts this need.
In addition, the Court agrees unreservedly with the finding that legal services must always strictly represent the interests of the Court and not the interests of individuals (which does not exclude each other).
The Bureau believes that the inclusion of external legal services has not been adequately controlled.
As the Court notes in its report, the internal investigations on this matter will continue and the results will be communicated to the Court.
3.20.17. and 3.20.26.
The B sucho accepts the comments.
These remedies were immediately initiated following the Court's finding of irregularity in its 2016 audit report (initiation of the Court's report in September 2017).
Unfortunately, however, in 2017 due to the time limits and the fact that the company replaced the contracts as soon as possible after the determination of their illegality, it actually came to payments from the contract.
3.20.18 and 3.20.19.
The Committee accepts the comments and reiterates that these problems can be seen as a result of the lack of resources and the shortcomings in internal control and management that the Court calls all in its report.
3.20.23.-3.20.25.
As the Court notes in its report, there is currently an internal investigation into this matter.
3.20.29.-3.20.31.
3.20.32.

The Bureau has consulted DG BUDG on this matter in order to clarify this matter again and will take immediate measures if DG BUDG should change its previously communicated position.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF ACCOUNTS 3.22.8.
The head of the Office's accountant is the head of the Administration/Corporate Services department.
In May 2017, on behalf of nine agencies participating in the open call for tenders, the Authority concluded three framework agreements in the cascade system covering a wide range of services.
Although agency-wide procurement procedures provide a good way to increase administrative efficiency, in the case of procurement procedures where the specific services to be provided are not known at the time of the call for tenders, framework agreements where competition is again called for for each individual contract are better suited to achieving a good cost-benefit relationship than framework agreements in the cascade system.

The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment. COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER OF THE PROJECT 3.23.8.
At the end of the financial year 2017, the Institute was the defendant in four disputes relating to three procurement procedures brought before the Court by rejected bidders.
In each of these cases, the applicant applied for annulment of the award decision and for compensation.
The claim for compensation in these four cases amounts to EUR 700 000 or 9% of the Institute's annual budget.
According to the evaluation of the Institute's external lawyer, a reduction of EUR 75 000 (or 1% of the Institute's annual budget) was recorded to cover the expected losses.
The judgment of the Court of First Instance in each of these cases will determine the legality and regularity of the award procedures for these contracts and future payments.
In 2016, the Institute launched an open call for travel services.
The service descriptions and the evaluation process did not provide a sufficient guarantee for the best price-performance ratio.
The formula and the pricing mechanism were unsuitable as they did not allow for an appropriate evaluation of tenders submitted by the tenderers.
The framework agreement was concluded over a maximum duration of four years and a maximum amount of EUR 700 000.
In 2017, payments of 137,000 euros were made in Hhhe.
3.23.10.
The agencies should define a common definition of electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (180) (181). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT overview covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
According to the Commission, by the end of 2017, the Institute had introduced electronic invoicing for certain procedures, but not the electronic invitation to tender and the electronic submission of tenders.
3.23.11.
The Institute publishes job advertisements on its own website and in social media, but not on the website of the European Office for Personnel Selection (EPSO), which would provide transparency and publicity and enable the citizens to consult job advertisements issued by the various European institutions and agencies.

Management of advisory services 3.24.15.
In the previous year, the Agency managed advisory services, including two selected projects to implement the Pharmacovigilance Regulation (Regulation (EU) No 1027/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (189) and Regulation (EU) No 536/ 2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (190) which required the development of complex EU-wide networks for the extensive technical IT developments.
Since the number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan was not increased, which would enable it to build up the necessary expertise internally, the Agency drew on consultancy firms to perform these tasks.
However, the use of consulting firms has led to the agency being dependent on this external expertise in a critical manner.
3.24.16.
In order to get the projects back under their control, the agency determined which functions should not be assigned externally, but should be perceived internally.
In addition, the agency goes on to award consultant contracts no longer according to the criteria of time and resources, but on a fixed price basis.
It also set up a more appropriate procedure for approving changes to the project.
3.24.17.
It will take time to reduce the critical nature of the agency of consultancy firms, and the impact of the actions taken will only become apparent over the years.
One of the two large-scale projects examined in 2016, the pharmacovigilance project (EudraVigilance database, about unexplored drug effects), was completed in 2017 with additional costs of around 0.5 million euros.
The clinical trials project is still under way. A start-up date has not been set, but the budget was increased by another 4.9 million euros in 2017 (191).

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/151 EN ANNEX Follow-up to observations from previous years Statements by the Court In 2012, the Centre signed a framework contract with a maximum amount of EUR 250 000 to sign individual entries.
At the end of 2015, total payments under this contract amounted to EUR 382 181, i.e. the ceiling was exceeded by 50 %.
Two framework contracts with a maximum value of EUR 135 000 and EUR 650 000, respectively, dealt with the establishment of the Centre's evaluation committee, the decisions relating to decisions relating to closures and the signing of contracts as authorised authorising officers.
However, the delegation of powers granted by the authorising officer was limited to 130000 euros, and frame contracts were not expressly recognised in it.
In 2016, payments of 35 310 euros were made in the amount.
In its January 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the need for the Observatory to improve the management of IT projects.
In particular, IAS concluded that a long-term strategic overall vision for the IT systems supporting the Centre's central operational departments was lacking, that the Centre's IT project management methodology was only partially adapted to its needs, and that the system requirements management procedure was inadequate.
The Observatory and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
EN C 434/152 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OBSERVATION CELL 3.25.8. The Centre considers that the current organisational structure did not affect the independence of its accountants.
This independence was, on the contrary, consistently ensured in accordance with the relevant rules, in particular through the appointment of the auditors by the Management Board of the Observatory, the functional reporting and accountability of these auditors against the Management Board and the proper compliance with the rules on the separation of tasks of the various financial actors of the Observatory.
In this context, the Observatory is prepared to comply with the Court's recommendation, ensuring that the appropriate measures are in an appropriate way to the size of the organisation and that the effectiveness and efficiency of its functioning are maintained.

COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.26.8. In 2017, the Agency had difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of tenderers in several medium-value procurement procedures.
3.26.9.
The Agency currently manages three dedicated, non-integrated IT systems (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac), all of which process data on the EU's freedom, security and justice policy area.
This approach could prevent the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems.
The current considerations of extending the Agency's mandate over the coming years to the management of several additional IT systems underpin the increasing urgency of this problem.
The Agency should, in consultation with the Commission and the Member States, draw up a detailed cost-benefit analysis to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems.
3.26.10.
The project for the construction of a new building at the site in Stra§burg significantly declined.
Although the Agency had already paid the full price for the construction work in 2016, these were still not completed by the end of 2017 and the progress reports on the work that was done covered only around 70% of the work.
Some of the agency's staff have already taken up the new building, although the work was still ongoing.
The agency and the contractor blame each other for the delays. In December 2017, the contractor made financial demands on the agency and filed a complaint.
The agency represents its own legal claim against the contractor (205).
3.26.11.
3.26.12.

It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3.26.14.
The Agency uses an outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, whereby around 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by contractors.
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system.
Payments to these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS.
Although all phases of IT projects, from the definition of requirements and milestones to the commissioning of new system components, are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model in which the development capabilities for so sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent carries considerable risks with regard to a superior dependence of the contractors.
This is all the more true in view of the limited number of potential contractors from operational and safety areas that can handle systems of this size and these requirements.
3.26.15.
At the same time, the low number of staff in operational key meetings, in particular in the ăReferat for Application Management and Maintenance (AMM), entails a significant risk for the continuity of the operation.
In the second half of 2017, the head of the AMM unit held the post of head of the operational department and the post of head of the ăReferat for operation and infrastructure, thus uniting the three highest management positions in the operational department, which entails further risks for the continuity.
3.26.16.
The framework agreements concluded with the respective consortia for the operation of the main IT systems include not only normal maintenance but also development maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the cost estimates attached to the framework agreements.
The prices for the individual contracts are calculated by the agency using a combination of fixed price and estimates of the time and resources spent, which is aimed at a solid cost control.
For the VIS contract, the agency also relied on the IFPUG(208) method, a standard method based on the function point analysis for determining the prices of developmental abilities.
The agency could also use the IFPUG method for other systems in development.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY FOOD 3.26.17.
The Agency made global commitments of EUR 69.9 million in total to cover future expenditure on new tasks and IT systems that were originally to be transferred to it in 2017, but for which the legal basis had not yet been adopted by the end of the year (Eurodac recast and allocation system to Dublin) or only recently (Regulation on the Entry/Exit System of 30 November 2017).
The corresponding appropriations for payments were reduced by two amending budgets amounting to EUR 85.6 million, from EUR 153.3 million in the original budget to EUR 85.6 million in the final budget.

EN C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANSWER OF THE AGENCY 3.28.8.
Europol employs over 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organisations.
The common working language of Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language arrangements adopted by the Management Board lay down that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures should be carried out in English.
For this reason, Europol's job advertisements are published in English.
Europol manages an effective and transparent recruitment process with a quota of vacancies of 0% at the end of 2017. In the 89 recruitment procedures carried out in 2017, there were an average of 58 applicants per selection procedure.
For the publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), the translation into the EU official languages is required in addition to the English version.
Due to the high number of job vacancies per year, translation into the EU official languages would entail high costs and the duration of the procedures would be longer.
Europol focuses on operational needs in budgetary expenditure, which is why job advertisements are translated into all EU official languages, including EPSO publication, only in certain cases (e.g. the Executive Director or Deputy Executive Directors).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/173 3.30.
EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE FRONTEX INTRODUCTION 3.30.1.
The European Agency for Border and Coast Guard (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (the new Sanctions Regulation), repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 (229).
It has been expanded on the basis of the European Agency for the Development of Operational Cooperation at the external borders of the Member States, maintaining the abbreviation "Frontex" and the Warsaw headquarters.
The new regulation extends the Agency's mandate, and gives the Agency the task of ensuring an integrated border management at the external borders at the European level in order to effectively manage the crossing of external borders.
This implies the fight against migratory pressure and potential future threats at these borders, while at the same time contributing to the fight against serious criminality with a cross-border dimension, in order to ensure a high level of internal security within the Union, while fully respecting fundamental rights and respect for freedom in this area.

Note 3.30.7.
The Agency's expenditure on financial assistance has increased significantly from EUR 123 million (2016) to EUR 167 million (2017).
Unlike in previous years, the Agency did not carry out ex-post checks on the reimbursement of expenditure related to financial assistance in 2017.
It considers that the ex ante checks carried out prior to reimbursement have been improved and that now as soon as they reach a certain destination they offer the necessary security.
Since 2014, however, the Court has repeatedly reported that the cooperating States often do not show enough evidence of the expenditure they have claimed, which was further confirmed in this case (see points 3.30.12-3.30.13).
3.30.8.
In 2016, the Court recommended that the Agency identify the most appropriate financing mechanism in an in-depth analysis (233).
In this context, the Court notes that at the end of 2017, the Board of Directors decided to use unit costs instead of reimbursement of actual operational costs.
At the same time, a pilot project was launched in 2018 to determine the unit costs for operational resources deployed by cooperating states.
In addition, in June 2017, the Board approved a new organisational structure of the Agency, which will take effect from 2018 and includes the creation of a new inspection and control body, which will report directly to the Executive Director and the Board in order to adapt the existing organisation to the new mandate (see point 3.30.9).
3.30.9.
In view of the migration crisis facing the Union, the mandate of the Agency was substantially expanded in 2016.
The Agency's budget was increased by 75% in 2016 and the budget for 2017 was again 21% higher than in the previous year.
Personnel increased by 18% in 2016 and by an additional 43% compared with the previous year.
The adaptation of the systems and procedures to the new mandate and the new circumstances is still in progress.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment and are to be read against the background of the challenges that the Agency had to address.
COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER ACTIVITY OF THE PROJECTS 3.30.10.
Following an open call, the Agency received four offers of guidance services for the promotion of migrants within Greece.
Following the selection criteria, three offers were retained and one was excluded.
The only criterion for the award was the price.
In April 2017, the Agency signed a framework agreement of EUR 2 million for a period of three years with the company that had offered the lowest price.
However, the contractor's funding was limited on a seasonal basis and he had problems fulfilling the contract, so that the agency left the contract at the end of 2017.
In order to ensure continuity of services, the Agency for the remaining period signed a new framework agreement of EUR 1.8 million with the second highest bidder in November 2017, who had offered the second lowest price.
It did not negotiate the terms of this replacement contract with the bidders ranked second and third, but signed the new contract on the basis of the original bid submitted by the second-placed bidder.
The direct award of the replacement contract was contrary to the rules, as the original award procedure was completed and a negotiated procedure to agree the terms of the contract, which were to apply until the conclusion of a new open procedure, did not take place.
No payments were made for this replacement order in 2017.
3.30.11.
The Staff Regulations provide that in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff shall be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234).
In 2017, the Agency hired two staff members (2016: 14) in higher AST grades.
(233) Special Report No 12/2016 ăThe use of grants by agencies: not always adequate or demonstrably effective. (234) Article 53(2) of the Staff Regulations.

There is a risk that higher costs have been reimbursed than actually incurred.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The Agency again cancelled a large amount of committed appropriations carried over from the previous year for the reimbursement of expenditure incurred by states participating in joint actions, amounting to EUR 7.7 million or 16.5% (2016: EUR 5.6 million or 17.6%).
This shows that the cooperating States had again considerably overestimated the expenses to be reimbursed by the Agency.
Although funds transferred for joint actions had to be cancelled in two consecutive years, in 2017 the Agency transferred an amount of 9.6 million euros from other budget lines to joint operations, which again transferred an amount of 40.5 million euros to the following financial year.
Joint actions represent 69% of the total amount cancelled in 2017 (EUR 11.1 million) and 46% of the total amount transferred in 2018 (EUR 87.6 million).
3.30.16.
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were spent on repatriation. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available.
The Agency therefore paid back to the Commission EUR 13.5 million or 20.3% (2016: EUR 23 million or 37.5%).
In addition, the Agency paid EUR 4 million of the budget estimate under Title I of the budget (staff expenditure) to the end of 2017, as not as many new employees could be hired as planned.
3.30.17.
The Agency's original budget for 2017 amounted to 8.8 million euros for the required operational financial reserve for the financing of immediate border security operations and return operations (235).
However, in September and then again in October 2017, the Agency transferred 1.9 million euros (totaling 3.8 million euros) from the reserve to its operational budget to finance other activities.
3.30.18.
After the transfer of appropriations from other budget lines and the establishment of an amending budget, the appropriations allocated to the reserve amounted to 24.7 million euros and 8.1% of the original budget.
However, the Agency used the reserve mainly to finance standard operations (8.4 million euros) and to finance a project for remote air surveillance (drones, 7 million euros), for which it had estimated only 1.1 million euros.
The estimates and use of unmandable complaints are incompatible with the speciality budget principle and undermines the transparency of the budget.

C 434/178 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The Internal Security Fund was established for the period 2014-2020.
It comprises two instruments: the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, and the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, through which EUR 2.8 billion (foreign borders and visas) and EUR 1 billion (police cooperation) are provided to finance projects.
Under the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, the Commission shall reimburse Member States for the cost of equipment such as vehicles or ships, as well as operating costs such as fuel or maintenance costs.
The Agency shall also reimburse participants in joint actions for such costs.
There is therefore a risk of double financing (4) which is not taken into account.
The costs incurred at border crossings of participating states are determined on the basis of cost allocations, which include ăFix costs (depreciation and maintenance costs), ăvariable expenditures (mainly fuel) and ăUse costs (mainly expenses and other expenses for crew members).
The reported costs are based on actual values and conform to national standards. Consequently, the approaches of the participating states differ, which leads to a system that is particularly complex for all stakeholders.
In its Special Report No 12/2016, the Court recommended that agencies use simplified cost options whenever deemed appropriate to avoid such inefficiencies (5).
The Agency's previous advisory regulation, which was in force until 5 October 2016, provided for the funding of joint implementation actions carried out with participating countries.
However, from January to October 2016, the Agency financed national return operations with an amount of EUR 3.6 million.
These payments are illegal.

In 2016, the Agency hired 14 staff in higher AST grades.

After Frontex had decided to terminate the contract, it was necessary to ensure the continuity of the services until a new contractor was selected.
In view of the limited market for the services in question in the region (the very small number of economic operators) it was considered that the most appropriate solution to the conclusion of a cross-border agreement with the company which had cut off as the second-best supplier in the original tender for the selection of shipowners.
In this case, therefore, it is not a continuation of a tendering procedure which has already been concluded.
The agency took into account in its decision that the company already had experience in providing services for Frontex, and that the relevant feedbacks were very positive; the offered guide met all the minimum technical requirements.
The contractor agreed to provide the services on the same terms and conditions as were required and offered in the original tender.
In November 2017, an exemption was signed in which the hindsights for this decision were explained.
The agreement was signed by both parties in December 2017 and entered into force in January 2018.
The application of the price as the sole criterion had been carefully examined and was based on the experience gained by Frontex in the past two years in awarding contracts for the provision of funds for takeovers between the Greek islands and Turkey.
Due to the market restrictions in the geographical region, the very small number of operators with a limited offer of F-F-F-E was not intended to establish qualitative award criteria.
The services provided by Frontex were short journeys between Greek islands and Turkey to promote returnees in the framework of the EU-Turkey Agreement on Transfers, ensuring that these actions were carried out in a safe environment and in full respect of fundamental rights.
In line with the last sentence of Article 31(2) of the Staff Regulations (In order to take account of the special needs of the institutions, the recruitment of officials can also take account of the labour market situation in the Union.)
This decision was fully in line with the posts (which form part of the budget) and had never been questioned by the budgetary authorities.
