COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
The costs for inspection/maintenance work are defined as the costs for all inspection/maintenance work during the entire service life of the device (...).
The data reported by the manufacturer or maintenance body of the manufacturer using the device is based on the data.
This means that the hourly rate can be expressed in the form of a cost statement of the respondent, either based on the manufacturer's estimates or on a price calculated on the basis of the actual costs incurred in previous years, or on a cost statement, using reference data for similar means of use if it is a new means of use and no data are available.
Invoices (or due to the data amount of equivalent booking documents) can only be made available if the hourly price is based on the actual costs incurred during the reference year.
However, the recipient also has the ability to set an hourly rate on the basis of average reference prices if no invoices were actually issued.
This was the case with the selected payment, whereby the Icelandic K"stenwache Frontex provided an estimate of the cost of maintenance.
The documents submitted by the Icelandic Knesset Guard included the results of ex-post controls carried out by an ex-post control team of Frontex in 2015 during a visit to the maintenance centre in Iceland, where the team had submitted the documents provided by the Icelandic Knesset Guard as the basis for their calculation methods.
Therefore, the document submitted by Iceland considers that Frontex has sufficient reason to approve the issue.
The total amount of an hourly rate for all inspection/maintenance work of an aircraft with fixed wings is the result of three routes with special regulations: 有 Engine maintenance 有 The signed contract provided for a maximum amount of EUR 9 010 475.50, but the payments are based on the hourly rate for the maintenance of an engine.
The Guardia Civil calculates Frontex the hourly rate for engine maintenance according to the contractual specifications.
If less time is spent on the maintenance of the engines, the overall ceiling is not reached.
Therefore, in this case, the hourly rate is not relevant to the total value of the contract.
EN C 434/182 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 的 General maintenance work 你 Geme§ The provisions of the relevant contract are a contract for a total price (not a framework contract), with monthly invoices for the individual work of the contractor provided.
The Agency assumes that the Guardia Civil will pay the total amount indicated in the contract upon termination of the contract.
The amount of an hourly price is calculated by dividing this total cost by the number of flight hours.
不 Delivery of spare parts 的 Gem的§ The terms of the contract are, as above, a contract for a total price (not a framework contract), with monthly invoices for the concrete work carried out by the contractor.
The Agency assumes that the Guardia Civil will pay the total amount indicated in the contract upon termination of the contract.
From the above-mentioned grounds, the Agency cannot agree to the Court's risk assessment, since the reimbursements of the Guardia Civil were based on a contract on a total price which was estimated to correspond in the end to the contributions paid on the basis of concrete invoices.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The main challenge is related to the ability of commitments during a given year.
To avoid the risk of high cancellations, Frontex also asked the people to submit their requests for a final payment for the first six months of 2016 and to forward Frontex's precise estimates of the costs for ongoing operations (December 2016) or planned operations (January 2017) as part of its operational activities in 2016.
The main objective of these calls was to identify possible overburdens, to reduce the corresponding SFD allocations and to re-use the funds in 2016.
Despite some positive results of this action, the transfer of funds was still high.
Consequently, despite a proper assessment of the actual financial needs, Frontex required additional funds to ensure the financial coverage of operations in the autumn of 2016, since the cancelled funds of the terminated and ongoing operations were not available at that time.
The Agency has developed a simplified support scheme, which will be implemented from the 2018 operational cycle and in which increases of up to one year will apply significantly higher costs; the Agency not only strengthens the monitoring of the implementation of grants, but also seeks to reduce the cancellation of transfers.
Implementation Despite the repayment of funds to the Commission, the main objective of the Agency in relation to recovery operations has been achieved: it provided Member States with technical and operational support for recovery operations and carried out specific actions aimed at the period prior to recovery (to identify returnees, training/training, exchange of knowledge between Member States, etc.).
In 2017, the number of return actions coordinated by Frontex increased significantly: with an increase of 47% compared to the previous year, the number of migrants increased from 10,700 in 2016 to 14,200 in 2017.
This represents an annual 10% share of the total number of migrants actually returning from the EU to third countries (in 2014 the corresponding figure was 2%).
Recruitment Repayments of staff expenditure appropriations were mainly due to difficulties and the associated delays in recruitment procedures: lengthy procedures, long deadlines, insufficient number of applicants and a lack of geographical balance due to a low correction coefficient.
However, the Agency considers it to be a success that over 250 new employees were recruited and trained within one year.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/183 3.30.17.
In 2017, the Agency was the first year of implementation of the new ECC Regulation.
Under Article 75(13), the Agency is obliged to include in its budget 4 % of the funds earmarked for operational measures in order to finance emergency operations for border management purposes (RABIT) and return operations.
On 1 October of each year, at least a quarter of the reduction should remain available to meet a demand that will occur by the end of the year.
The required operational revision was introduced so that during the year, the agency could at any time provide a certain reserve for the execution of immediate items for border protection purposes and for the coverage of the possible costs of such an emergency operation.
The European Parliament had amended the original text of the ECC Regulation proposed by the Commission to add that by 1 October only a quarter of the gap for the remaining three months of the year must remain available.
The ECC regulation is silent on what is to be done with the remaining three-quarters of the deficit after 1 October; this point is unclear.
The first transfer at the end of September was intended for the financing of reinforced operational measures in the air and at sea and the acquisition of own air monitoring services; the second transfer took place after 1 October.
The Board of Directors was informed in the monthly report on transfers.
The Agency considers that the legislator should provide clarity.
The non-obligatory situation had already been envisaged during the preparations for the Single Programming Document (SPD) 2017-2019.
In accordance with Article 75(3ff) of the ECC Regulation, the preparation of the SPD and the allocation of revenue and expenditure in the year N-2 was started and completed in late autumn of the year N-1.
The ECC Regulation entered into force in October 2016.
The Agency had to plan the detailed annual work programme 2017 (as part of the SPD 2017-2019) for the whole year 2016 without the final outcome of the discussions on the ECC Regulation and thus without a clearly defined legal basis.
Towards the end of 2016, the SPD 2017-2019 was already completed and was available for approval to the Board of Directors, which fully supported the creation of the non-restrictive situation in view of the transition to the European Border and Coast Guard.
The Commission stated in its opinion on the SPD 2017-2019, (C92016)8722, in paragraph 63: ăThe Commission acknowledges that emergency planning has become a guiding principle for the preparation of the annual work programme and that the Agency intends to provide almost 10 % of its operational budget for the so-called ‘operational flexibilit'tÔ (...).
In this context, the Commission calls on the Agency to establish two separate actions within its budget, the first fully in line with Article 75, paragraph 13, of the ECC Regulation, and the second providing the Agency with the possibility of maintaining operational flexibility in order to deal with emergency situations which are not immediate.
Since the Agency publishes its job offers in English, while the EPSO requires translations into all EU official languages, this would mean that the cost would increase considerably and that the recruitment procedure could not be used.
Frontex distributes information on vacancies about other channels, i.e. the network of EU agencies, the board of directors, permanent representations, Eurobrussels and social media.

C 434/186 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Statements by the Court An external evaluation of the Foundation was carried out on behalf of the Commission in 2016.
This was the first step in a cross-sectional evaluation of the four agencies involved in employment, social affairs and integration(1).
The evaluators concluded that the significant restructuring of the Foundation had no significant negative effects since 2011 and that the internal and external stakeholders were mainly positive, in particular with regard to strategy and effectiveness.
The management structure of the Foundation was considered efficient and effective.
The evaluation also stresses that the Foundation has further improved its monitoring capacity since 2011, but that it needs to make its activities and achievements even clearer.
Uniformisation and simplification of indicators within a single intervention logic and the use of common terminology throughout the Foundation would help to improve them.
The Foundation developed a plan to implement the recommendations of the evaluators.
In his report on the Foundation's financial statements for 2011, the Court emphasised that the situation regarding the Foundation's shortcomings is unsatisfactory and that there is a risk that the Foundation will not be able to continue its activities continuously.

EURATOM SUPPLY AGENCY INTRODUCTION 3.32.1.
The Euratom Supply Agency (hereinafter ‘the Agency') based in Luxembourg was established in 1958(244).
Council Decision 2008/114/EC, Euratom(245) replaced the previously applicable Statute of the Agency.
The main task of the Agency is to ensure the regular supply of nuclear materials, in particular nuclear fuels, to EU users in accordance with the principle of equal access to sources of supply through a common supply policy.
3.32.2.

3.34.7.
In 2017, the Office cancelled EUR 3.2 million, or 15.9% of the committed appropriations carried over from the financial year 2016.
The Office continued to use fixed prices for services (258).
The prices used in the various services are based on unit prices (price/person's day, etc.) as defined in framework agreements and the number of units used for the service in question.
The Office will ensure that unit prices are correctly applied when it comes to price quotations from contractors.
3.34.10.
However, the list of services to be provided in connection with the framework agreement was not exhaustive in the case of a framework agreement with a value of EUR 80 million on general advisory, audit and project management services as well as studies.
In order to assess the offers, the service descriptions contained two business cases relating to the management of a project and a multi-project programme.
This framework agreement is a multi-framed mixed agreement, partly using a cascade process (general advisory and project management services) and partly a renewed call for competition (preparation and studies).
The protected units were predetermined by the Office but the bidders were asked to determine the distribution between the different profiles.
The framework agreement and also some of the associated individual agreements were therefore advertised on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not the expected number of benetigte units, which is another essential element in the calculation of a fixed price contract.
3.34.11.
Under this framework agreement, a single contract with a fixed price of EUR 145 447.50 was awarded, which mainly concerns the provision of support services for the execution of a document management project.
The necessary staff days for the provision of these services cannot be derived either from the business cases described in the service descriptions or from the description contained in the individual contract.
In the case of a fixed price as set out in this individual order, there is therefore a risk that the services will not be provided in the most economic way.
3.34.12.
If not all the conditions for the provision of services in the award of the framework agreement can be laid down, the individual undertakings will be more appropriate to reopen competition among several contractors in the framework agreement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/197 EN Year 2016 State of correction (completed/in progress/outstanding/n.e.) Completed (3) ANNEX Follow-up to observations from previous years Court observations The Office's budget implementation rate was low at 89%, suggesting an inaccurate estimate of its expenditure in the 2016 budget.
As a result of the most recent changes to the Guarantee Regulation and the Office's financial regulations, it has become more important that the Office should, if necessary, draw up a detailed budget with the help of an amending budget, since mechanisms linked with the budget estimates such as the allocation of appropriations to a claim fund(1) and a related compensation mechanism (2) are now foreseen.
In 2014, the Office launched a call for tenders for a four-year framework agreement on a protected market volume of EUR 30 million for the procurement of consulting services covering a wide range of activities, including training, project management, general advisory services and studies.
However, the procurement procedure and the subsequent use of the framework agreement were partly not adequately managed.
The objectives and the procedures had not been defined sufficiently precisely to make a precise assessment of the volume of the framework agreement.
Therefore, the resources of the framework contract were exhausted after only two years and six months.
In addition, despite the variety of services to be procured and the very different expenditures per activity, no lots had been used.
The use of lots would encourage smaller companies to participate in the low-value process.
Finally, the price competition was neutralised and the discretion obtained by the contractor, since fixed price offers were requested by a single contractor using the framework agreement.
The Office should decide to enter into agreements with several suppliers and, if necessary, to call again for competition.
The Office's charter states that the translations required for the Office's work are made by the Translation Centre for the Bodies of the European Union (CdT), which leads to the fact that the Office is the Centre's principal client.
The Office is increasingly using internal solutions such as linguistic and translation memory as well as additional software.
These instruments are designed to improve the cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the Office.
However, from the perspective of the European Union, the current situation could lead to a doubling of expenditure and corresponding costs.

EN C 434/198 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AMTS COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.34.8.
While the cancellation rate is just over 15%, the amount of cancelled committed transfers is the lowest of the last ten years (since 2008) at EUR 3.2 million.
The Office will continue to work with the national authorities to reduce the cancelled transfers through interim reports on implementation and half-yearly inspections with reinforced control measures, which form an integral part of each new cooperation agreement.
Further measures have also been implemented internally, such as awareness-raising measures through coaching, training, information notes and meetings with financial actors.
Furthermore, before the end of 2017, the Office expected that 15% of cancelled transfers would go over and proactively took additional measures to reduce transfers for the next year.
The Office took note of the Court's observations.
It should be noted in advance that the scenarios described in the procurement documents for the future uses of the contract were aimed at being as vivid and representative as possible and were not expected to be linked in detail to each specific contract.
As regards the adequacy of the re-opening of the competition mechanisms and as stated in the Office's response to the 2016 audit, this concept has already been introduced in the revised framework agreement on audits and studies.
The Office has compared the added value of this mechanism with the related administrative costs and, in view of the Office's intensive use of advisory and project management services, has concluded that this is not the most efficient way to manage the latter types of operations.
Taking into account the fact that the current framework agreement is valid until 2020, the extension of this mechanism to advisory and project management services would require a new tender at this stage, which the Office does not consider appropriate.
In the existing cascade system for consulting and project management services, the Office repeats the answer to the 2016 audit on the use of the fixed price procedures.
The main reason for choosing this option is that the Office is subject to proceedings before the Spanish labour courts in relation to a non-right-hand transfer of employees, which are inter alia related to the use of the former ăTime and Means.
In the case of a fixed price procedure (within the cascade system), the Office has experience in evaluating offers.
The EUIPO has set up a specific team, which is able, on the basis of previous practice and expertise, to include the resources required to carry out the tasks behind the fixed price services.
However, we believe that the Court's concerns can be addressed by other contractual methods than the ăfixed prize, such as the ăQuoted Time and Means, a method that the Office could use in the future to draw on individual cases.
The Office undertakes to provide further information and to document its own estimates of the resources required to carry out the tasks for fixed price services before issuing the request for assistance in order to provide proof of the above-mentioned experience of the Office in advance.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/199 3.35.
STUDENT DEVELOPING EXCLUSIONS (SRB) INTRODUCTION 3.35.1.
The Single Resolution Committee (hereinafter referred to as the Committee), also called the SRB, based in Brussels, was established by Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 on the Single Resolution Mechanism (ăSRM Regulation) (259).
3.35.2.
The Committee is responsible for the management of the Single Resolution Fund (hereinafter referred to as the Fund), which was established by the SRM Regulation and is intended to be supportive under the Single Resolution Mechanism.
3.35.3.
The Committee has its own budget, which is not part of the EU budget.

Emphasis on a point of view 3.35.9.
Without questioning its rulings in paragraphs 3.35.6-3.35.8, the Court would like to point out that the contributions to the Fund are calculated on the basis of the information sent to the Committee by credit institutions (and some investment firms).
The Court relied on this information when examining the Committee's revenue, but did not rely on its powers.
The SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework to ensure the reliability of the information.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot provide details of the contributions per credit institution calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, since the calculations are not available and include confidential information about other credit institutions.
3.35.10.
Administrative complaints or judicial proceedings between credit institutions and national resolution authorities and the Committee in connection with contributions to the Fund and the Court of Justice of the European Union brought by former shareholders and creditors of Banco Popular Espaol, S.A. following the adoption of the resolution concept, the Court disregarded its examination in order not to affect the position of the parties in these proceedings.
For detailed information, see paragraph 8 of the Committee's annual accounts.

A blatant use of such methods leads to the restriction of competition.

EN C 434/204 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE COMMITTEE 3.35.9.
The annual contributions to the Fund collected in advance shall be calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by credit institutions and certain investment firms.
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework that ensures the reliability of this information, the SRF pays any attention to this aspect.
The data provided are based on the data transmitted by the institutions in the previous year and on the data contained in the ECB database.
Deviations are reported to the national resolution authorities who are asked to clarify the facts. Thus, it was possible for the SRF to improve the quality of the data in the previous cycles.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot disclose any details of pre-investigations per institution, calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are not available and therefore confidential information about other institutions would be disclosed.
However, the SRF has disclosed the calculation method as well as detailed calibrations to ensure transparency and cooperation.
3.35.12.
In 2017, due to a combination of unexpectedly high workload, unfortunate staff turnover in the financial team and general difficulties in finding experienced employees, the financial team's capacity was not sufficient to ensure the efficient handling of all financial transactions, including invoices.
Since the fourth quarter of 2017, the team's capacity has been increased and measures have been taken to ensure the timely processing of invoices.
By this date, almost 98 % of the invoices were settled in 2018 within the set deadlines.
Every case of late payment is now being closely investigated in order to achieve further improvements in this area.
3.35.14.
The SRB for 2017's preliminary procurement plan was adopted in 2016, when the Committee was only in its second full year of existence.
At that time, no resolution cases had been dealt with and the Agency had little experience on the basis of which its procurement plan could be drawn up.
As a new agency, the SRB was able to use various interinstitutional frameworks managed by the European Commission.
This led to the fact that several procurement procedures, which were to be initiated by the SRB in 2017, were ultimately not carried out.
In 2018, the implementation of the procurement plan will be closely monitored and additional efforts will be made to improve the planning of procurement procedures.
In 2017, the SRB spent a total of 20 million euros on providing legal advice.
Almost all the negotiated procedures without prior publication of a contract notice concerned disputes (eight out of ten transactions in the total value of EUR 10.9 million), which did not fall within the scope of Directive 2014/24/EU.
This also includes a large number of disputes brought before the ECJ after the first resolution procedure of the SRB.
The SRB does not therefore consider that it uses such methods in a similar way.
As regards the economic and financial valuation of two of the two cases in 2017, the re-implementation of a competition proved to be unsuccessful. Therefore, the SRB was forced to resort to negotiating procedures.
Due to the subject matter of the contract and the need for the highest level of confidentiality, the contract notice was not published in accordance with the applicable rules.
3.35.16.
The online access to tender documents has been available to economic operators since the Committee was established on the SRB website and has been fully integrated into the electronic tender platform since the end of 2017.
In June 2017, the SRB requested that the electronic submission of offers also be made use of. However, the Commission has not yet gained access.
The SRB has found that such publications on the EPSO website do not raise the quality or the number of applications and are also very expensive due to the mandatory translation of job advertisements.
Therefore, the SRB publishes its job advertisements preferably on its own website as well as on EU_CV online and LinkedIn and informs its stakeholders (central banks, finance ministries, national authorities, other EU agencies and permanent representatives).

Note 3.36.7.
The Centre's task is to provide the EU's agencies and bodies with translation services which they can use for their service activities, and it also serves in relation to the institutions of the EU which can use the Centre's services.
Most agencies and institutions are required to make use of the Centre's translation services.
Some agencies and institutions (more than half of the Centre's revenue) are increasingly resorting to in-house opportunities or other alternatives to the rest.
However, this means that the capacity of the Centre is not used to the maximum, that there is a duplication in the development of systems and running costs at the European level, and that the business model and the business development of the Centre can be carried out.
In 2017, an external assessment of the adequacy of the Centre's business model was carried out.
The final evaluation report had not yet been adopted at the time of the Court's examination (268).

This constellation makes the seconded accountant part of the organizational structure of the superordinate DG, in our case DG EAC.
The Agency will analyse the Court's comment, taking into account potential actions taken by other EU agencies and/or Commission organisational guidelines.

The high cancellation rate of the previous year's appropriations for Title I (staff expenditure) amounted to EUR 32000, or 8.3%, shows that the appropriations needed were overestimated.

The ill-fated reports concerned the transparency of these procedures.
In its September 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the Agency has taken a number of strategic and operational measures to improve the recruitment, retention and allocation of its staff.
In this context, IAS concluded that the Agency has designed and implemented an appropriate human resources management system to enable a competent and committed workforce to achieve its objectives.
Although no critical or particularly serious problems were identified, the Agency and IAS agreed on an action plan to further improve this procedure in certain areas.
At EUR 1.3 million or 40% (2015: EUR 1.5 million or 43%), the rate of committed appropriations for Title III (operational expenditure) carried over to the following financial year remained high, mainly due to year-on-year external inspections and communication measures.
The high transfer rate is in contradiction to the budgetary principle of annuality.

EN C 434/220 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.39.8. The electronic submission of tenders is currently limited to open procedures (the threshold is set by Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement and amounted to EUR 135 000 in 2017).
Since the Agency did not initiate such a procedure in 2017, and this will not be the case in 2018, the Agency was unable to use the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
Moreover, the use of electronic submissions will become mandatory under the Commission's Roadmap at the end of 2018 for all EU institutions and agencies.
Therefore, the start-up process was started in 2018, and the agency will be able to deploy the electronic submission of tenders before the end of the year.
In the case of negotiated procedures, the Agency will use the electronic submission of tenders once the Commission has integrated this option into the module.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/227 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Statements by the Court In its December 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the Agency's overall human resources management is appropriate.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for the correction of the finding included in the report.
In another May 2016 audit report, IAS concluded that the Agency, together with the Commission, has set up an efficient internal control system for managing the grants granted under the Horizon 2020 programme.
The Agency and IAS agreed with the Commission on a plan for corrective measures to be considered to be very important.
The performance of the Agency has been subject to an external evaluation on behalf of the Commission during the period 2012-2015, for which the final report was submitted in May 2016.
The conclusion of the evaluation is that the Agency has carried out its tasks in an effective, efficient and cost-effective manner in the period under consideration, that its mission for the Commission and the managers of the Agency is still relevant for the first time and that the transfer of operational tasks from the Commission to the Agency has been successful.
The evaluation experts, however, also made possible even more effective and efficient ways of shaping the activities. The Agency and the Commission were invited to improve their internal dialogue and cooperation, communication according to requirements and certain aspects in the area of IT and human resources management.
The Agency and the Commission agreed on a plan for corrective action.
EN C 434/228 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.41.9
The introduction of the restricted recruitment procedure, where weaknesses were identified, took place in 2016. A reserve list was then drawn up and adopted in 2016, which was used in 2017 to provide a job offer.
The selection process of REA for contract staff has been revised and implemented in 2017, taking into account the recommendation of the IAS of 2016.
The revised competition for contract staff takes into account the demands for clearly documented search criteria for living life and mobility, as well as for admission and selection criteria.
The search criteria used by the selection boards for the sighting of life documents are documented in their minutes.
Thus, the weaknesses raised by the Court in the amended procedure have already been removed.
In the area of procurement, REA relies on service agreements with the Commission or on the Commission's framework contracts.
REA would only initiate a special procurement procedure if there is a special need not covered by these agreements or contracts.
In 2017, REA only carried out a procurement procedure for a low-value contract.
The current tools for electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders are only applicable for public procurement procedures, the size of which is above the 144,000 euro threshold. As the REA has not yet launched a procurement procedure, the size of which is above this threshold, it was unable to use the tools for electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
Furthermore, the introduction of the electronic tender and electronic submission of offers in accordance with the Commission's roadmap for all EU institutions and agencies will be mandatory at the end of 2018, and thus the implementation process did not begin until 2018.
The Agency is already using electronic invoicing and will also use the modules for the electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders when launching a tender procedure, as soon as these modules also cover medium and low value entries.

Emphasis on a situation 3.42.7.
The Agency's accountant has been absent since the end of November 2017.
On 13 December 2017, the Agency's Steering Committee appointed a Management Board as ad interim accounting officer, despite the fact that this Board represents the authorising officer in charge.
This is contrary to Article 28 of the Agency's financial regulations, according to which powers of instruction and accounting are separate functions and exclude each other.
3.42.8.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.42.9.
In 2017, the Agency did not provide sufficient documentation on recruitment procedures.
This could call into question the principles of transparency and equal treatment of applicants.
In 2017, the Agency had difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of tenderers in low and medium value procurement procedures.
It received only one offer for each of the tested procedures.
3.42.11.
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, the executive agencies should establish a single framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (311).
3.42.12.
The Agency publishes job advertisements for temporary staff on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), which would provide transparency and publicity and enable the workers to consult job advertisements issued by the various European institutions and agencies. COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.42.13.
The Agency's budgeting has been weak. In the case of Title III of the budget, large amounts of committed appropriations were transferred from 2017 to 2018 at EUR 1.6 million or 63% (2016: EUR 1.2 million or 48%).

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors is the institution responsible for auditing the finances of the European Union (EU) in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, we contribute to improving EU financial management while acting as independent guardians of the financial interests of EU citizens.
More detailed information on our work can be found in the Annual Activity Report, which is available on our website www.eca.europa.eu, as well as the special reports on the EU's expenditure programmes and revenue and the opinions on new or amended legislation.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget; it concerns the financial year 2014.
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately.
0.3.
The general budget of the EU is adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report, together with the special reports, forms the basis for the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, following a Council recommendation, decides whether the Commission has carried out its budget implementation tasks satisfactorily.
At the same time as transmission to the European Parliament and the Council, we are sending our annual report to the national parliaments.
0.4.
The main element of our annual report is the statement on the reliability of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union and on the legality and regularity of transactions (hereinafter referred to as ‘the regularity of transactions').
We complement this Statement of Assurance with specific assessments of all major EU activities.
0.5.
The chapter structure now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which makes our report even more relevant.
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 and is intended to determine the extent and distribution of EU expenditure for the period up to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to establish a link between the findings of our report and the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate financial statements for each of the MFF headings and, therefore, the conclusions submitted in the context of specific assessments do not form an audit opinion.
0.7.
This year's report is structured as follows: — Chapter 1 contains the Statement of Assurance and a summary of the results of our audit on the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of operations. — Chapter 2 presents our findings on budgetary and financial management. — Chapter 3 contributes to our strategic objective of improving the EU's public accountability. The focus is on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and manage progress towards Europe 2020. — Chapter 4 contains our findings on revenue. — Chapters 5 to 9 (to the MFF headings 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5)(1) show the results of our audits on the regularity of operations, as well as the audit of selected systems and annual activity reports.
0.8.
The Commission's replies (or, where appropriate, the replies of other EU institutions and bodies) to our comments are contained in the report. Our findings and conclusions are based on the replies of the audited body.
As an external auditor, however, it is our sole task to present our audit findings, to draw conclusions from these findings and thus to make an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions.
(1) We do not provide specific assessments of expenditure under the MFF Headings 3 (security and citizenship) and 6 (compensation payments).

DE C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND THE COUNCIL RELIABILITY DECLARATION OF THE COURT — REMARKS OF THE INDEPENDENT AUDITERS I. We have examined: (a) the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union, the consolidated annual accounts(1) and the aggregated financial statements (2) for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015, and (b) the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts referred to in Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
Management II's responsibility In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union on the basis of internationally recognised public sector accounting principles and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This responsibility includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements that are free from material misrepresentations, intended or unintended.
The Commission shall bear the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
Responsibility of the auditor III. Our task is to provide the European Parliament and the Council, on the basis of our audit, with a statement of the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
We have carried out our audit in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as well as the professional conduct requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions of INTOSAI.
According to these standards, we have to comply with the professional behavioural requirements and to plan and carry out the audit in such a way that sufficient certainty is obtained as to whether the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union are free of material misrepresentations and the underlying transactions are lawful and proper.
IV. An audit shall include the carrying out of audit proceedings in order to obtain audit evidence of the valuations and other information contained in the consolidated annual accounts and of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The selection of audit acts is at the discretion of the auditor, including the assessment of the risks of material — intentional or unintended — misrepresentation in the consolidated accounts and of material — intentional or unintended infringements of European Union legislation in the underlying transactions.
When assessing these risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant to the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated financial statements and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions in order to plan audit actions that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not with the aim of delivering an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit shall also include an assessment of the adequacy of the accounting policies applied, the representativeness of the estimated values in the accounting and the overall presentation of the consolidated annual accounts.
V. In the field of revenue, we use the macro-economic aggregates relevant for their calculation as the starting point for our review of own resources based on VAT and derived from gross national income and evaluate the Commission's systems of processing these data until the Member States' contributions are received and until they are identified in the consolidated annual accounts.
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine the accounts of customs authorities and analyse the tax flows until they are received by the Commission and until the amounts are recorded in the accounts.
1. The consolidated financial statements shall include the balance sheet, the profit and loss account, the cash flow account, the changes in net assets and a summary of important accounting rules and other explanatory notes (including segment reporting).
DE 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/11 VI. In the area of expenditure, we will review the payment transactions after the expenditure has been incurred, recorded and accepted. This review will take place on all types of payments, except advances, (including payments for the acquisition of assets) only after they have been made.
Advance payments shall be considered if the beneficiary provides or is required to provide proof of their proper use and the advance is settled or can be recovered.
VII. We believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our audit opinions.
The reliability of the accounts Audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts VIII. In our opinion, the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union for the year ending 31 December 2014 constitute the financial and financial situation of the Union as at 31 December 2014, the results of its operations and its cash flows and the changes in net assets for the financial year ending on that date in accordance with the Financial Regulation and the accounting rules for the public sector based on internationally recognised accounting principles in all essential respects as a whole. The legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the annual accounts Revenues Payments Audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts IX. In our opinion, the revenue underlying the annual accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 is lawful and proper in all essential respects.
The basis for the failed audit opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the annual accounts X. The expenditure booked in 2014 to the detriment of headings 1 to 4 of the multiannual financial framework (3) covering operational appropriations is substantially affected by errors.
Our estimated error rate for payments underlying the annual accounts is 4.4%.
Our conclusion is underpinned by the analysis of risk amounts presented by the Commission in the synthesis report.
Failure of an audit opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the annual accounts XI. According to our assessment, the facts underlying the annual accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 are substantially affected by errors due to the significance of the facts described in paragraph "The basis for the failed audit opinion on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the annual accounts".

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 DE OBSERVATIONS OF THE COURT INTRODUCTION EU expenditure is an important instrument for achieving policy objectives 1.1.
EU expenditure is an important instrument for achieving policy objectives.
Other important instruments include legislation, the free movement of goods, services and capital and the free movement of persons throughout the Union.
On average, EU expenditure amounts to 1.9% of total government expenditure in the EU Member States (see Figure 1.1).
According to the Treaty, our role is, inter alia, to assess whether the use of the EU budget is in line with the relevant laws and other legislation; — to give our audit opinion on the annual accounts of the EU; — to report on the economy, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU expenditure; — to submit opinions on legislative proposals with financial implications.
With our audit work to support the Statement of Assurance, we meet the first and second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that affect economy, efficiency and effectiveness.
It also provides an important input to the opinions we give on proposed financial regulations.
(4) In Article 30(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union (OJ L 347, 20.12.2012, p.
1), these terms are defined as follows: "The principle of economy requires that the resources used by the institution concerned in its [sic] activities be made available at the right time, in sufficient quantity and appropriate quality and with the lowest possible cost.
The principle of economic efficiency concerns the optimal relationship between the resources used and the results achieved.
The principle of effectiveness concerns the achievement of certain objectives and the desired results.

C 373/16 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.7.
In 2014, the Commission amended the presentation of the annual accounts several times.
These amendments are intended to take account of the new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and to achieve further alignment with international standards.
Considerable improvements have been made in the presentation of certain explanatory notes to the financial statements (8).
Points affecting the annual accounts 1.8.
The following points have an impact on the annual accounts: 1.8. a) The Commission has made progress with regard to the presentation of (a) explanatory note 6 on the annual accounts (on ‘protection of the EU budget'), as discussed in point 1.13 of our annual report on the financial year 2013 and in point 2 of this year's follow-up report (Annex 1.2).
The explanation now contains more targeted information.
In the area of cohesion, it identifies the extent to which corrections are made before expenditure is recorded, during implementation and at closure.
Furthermore, the explanation now includes a description of the impact of corrective measures (such as the creation of assigned revenue, expenditure withdrawn and replaced by Member States, etc.) on the EU budget, although not always in a quantified form (9). (b) Note 2.5.2 on pre-financing (commitments to Member States) shows that there is limited information available to the Commission on the use of the resources available for financial instruments under shared management (EUR 3.8 billion) and other aid schemes (EUR 3.6 billion).
The Commission may need to make significant adjustments at the end of the 2007-2013 programming period.
(8) Including a consolidated presentation of short-term and long-term assets and liabilities and a simplified presentation of segment reporting.
(9) In its explanatory note 6 to the 2015 financial statements, the Commission seeks to take account of the decisions of the Court of Justice of the European Union of June 2015, which annulled decisions on financial corrections amounting to EUR 457 million.
In the statement 2.10 ‘Reserves', these decisions are already treated as adjustments due to events after the closing date (Court of Justice judgment of 24 June 2015 in Joined Cases C-549/12 P and C-54/13 P annulment of two Commission decisions of EUR 94 million in connection with ERDF programmes in Germany and judgment in Case C-263/13 P annulment of three Commission decisions of EUR 363 million in respect of ERDF programmes in Spain).
These decisions were taken in connection with the expenditure under the 1994-1999 operational programmes.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.11.
Overall, the test results over the last three years have remained relatively stable at a level well above our baseline for materiality (see Figure 1.2).
REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.11.
The Commission notes that the error rate reported by the Court is an annual estimate which takes account of the accounting corrections of project expenditure made before the Court's audit is announced.
The Commission notes that it is bound by the Financial Regulation, which lays down in Article 32(2)(e) that its internal control system should ensure, inter alia, ‘appropriate treatment of the risks related to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the programmes and the nature of the payments concerned'.
In the 2014 synthesis report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, corresponding to 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
The Commission will continue to exercise its monitoring role by making financial corrections and recoveries at a level consistent with the level of irregularities and inadequacies identified throughout the period and also after the closure of the programmes.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.12.
EU expenditure consists mainly of two types of expenditure programmes which have different risk patterns (12): — programmes based on payment entitlements, for which payment depends on whether certain conditions are met; such programmes include scholarships for students and research grants (Chapter 5), direct aid to farmers (Chapter 7), direct budget support(13) (Chapter 8) and salaries and pensions (Chapter 9); — reimbursement schemes, for which the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities, include research projects (Chapter 5), schemes for investment in regional and rural development (Chapters 6 and 7), training programmes (Chapter 6) and development projects (Chapter 8).
(12) Paragraphs 1.20-1.22 detail these different risks.
(13) Budget support payments are a contribution to the general budget of a State or to the funds provided by it for a specific policy or objective (see also paragraphs 8.7 and 8.8).
THE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFE A new audit approach...
For 2014, we have redesigned our approach to quantify serious breaches of procurement rules.
This approach clarifies how we assess the impact of these infringements.
In particular, we have introduced a proportional approach to the calculation of errors related to the modification of contracts.
1.14.
In order to ensure comparability of the results presented in this report, we have adjusted the figures for 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and in Figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 in line with this new approach.
Annex 1.4 contains the unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rates for the period 2009-2013.
This adjustment reduced the estimated overall error rate by 0,2 % in 2013 and by 0,3 % in 2012.
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions we reached in relation to those years, and it continues to be a clearly significant error rate.
1.15.
In 2015, we will adapt our approach to cross compliance with the revised legal framework for the common agricultural policy.
While we will continue to report on the information provided by the Commission on cross-compliance, this element will no longer be the subject of our audit proceedings.
This year we identified numerous cross-compliance errors with regard to one in four of the farms visited.
The share of these errors in our estimated total error rate is 0.2 percentage points (2013: 0.2)(14) and the error rate for the chapter ‘Natural resources' is 0.6 percentage points (2013: 0.5).
The Commission welcomes the change in the Court's approach from 2015.
For 2014, it reiterates its view that cross compliance infringements do not affect the eligibility conditions for payments (see the Commission's reply to point 7.7).

C 373/24 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS ON THE HOFES Type of expenditure and error rates are closely related to 1.20.
We have analysed the relationship between the type of expenditure and the risk of error.
The extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on information provided by beneficiaries themselves is characteristic of EU expenditure.
This applies to the largest category of expenditure schemes based on payment entitlements: the area-related aid paid to farmers.
This is of particular importance in the area of reimbursement schemes: beneficiaries must provide information in their application in order to demonstrate that they are participating in an eligible measure and that they have incurred costs which are eligible for reimbursement.
All types of management are affected (15).

1.20.
The integrated management and control system (InVeKoS), which includes the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), contributes significantly to avoiding errors and reducing the error rate (see point 7.32).
LPIS is established and maintained by the national authorities.
Payments to final beneficiaries are only possible after their claim has been compared with the data available in the area identification system.
LPIS means that the error rate for area-related aid is lower than for all other types of aid under shared management.

C 373/26 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES The results in the various areas of expenditure show different error patterns 1.23. "Competitiveness" (Chapter 5): The estimated error rate is 5.6% and is therefore higher than the corresponding results for 2013 (4.0%(17). The majority of expenditure is based on reimbursement, and the errors in this area mainly reflect the different categories of ineligible costs (mainly personnel costs, other direct costs and indirect costs).
1.24. ‘Cohesion' (Chapter 6: The estimated error rate is 5.7%, higher than the corresponding results for 2013 (5.3% (17)).
Almost all expenditure in this area takes the form of reimbursement.
The main causes of error include serious breaches of procurement rules (around half of the estimated error rate), followed by ineligible costs in declarations of expenditure (more than a quarter of the estimated error rate).
Infringements of State aid rules and ineligible projects constitute the remaining part of the errors.
1.25. ‘Natural resources' (Chapter 7): The estimated error rate is 3.6%, which is lower than the corresponding results for 2013 (4.4 % (17).
The European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) accounts for more than three quarters of expenditure in this area, and this fund is less prone to error than the rural development sub-sector, for which we have for a long time found high error rates, particularly for expenditure on the basis of reimbursement.
Overall, farmers' excessive area or number of animals contributed about one third of the estimated error rate.
Errors related to non-eligible beneficiaries, activities or expenditure accounted for the second highest proportion (around a quarter of the estimated error rate).
The main remaining shares are cross compliance infringements (one-sixth) and administrative errors (one-sixth).

C 373/28 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Box 1.1 — Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and Citizenship" The subject of our sample was a payment by the Commission to a beneficiary who was the coordinator of a cooperation project under the "Fundamental Rights and Citizenship" programme.
The beneficiary public body assigned two permanent staff (officials) half-day to the project and charged part of its salaries in the project cost statement.
Deputies only cause additional costs where further staff have to be recruited in order to replace officials in their usual duties, and therefore actually incur costs.
As the beneficiary institution has not made provision for the replacement of officials, these costs are not eligible.
In total, the ineligible costs reported by the beneficiary entity amounted to EUR 58 000 of the total cost invoiced in the amount of EUR 237 000.
We identified ineligible costs for eight of the 25 projects covered by the sample for the MFF heading 3, which were reimbursed by the Commission.
Box 1.1 — Examples of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and citizenship of the Union" The Commission has been aware of the difficulties encountered by public bodies in complying with the eligibility rules applicable to staff costs for public bodies (which hire other personnel to replace the official staff in their normal activities).
For this reason, the Commission amended from 2011 the eligibility rules applicable to staff of public bodies, taking advantage of the flexibility provided for in the implementing rules of the Financial Regulation.
Therefore, the non-eligible costs identified by the Court in the grant mentioned above (staff costs for staff in public bodies that do not allocate a replacement) would now be considered eligible.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/29 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES There are many forms of corrective action with different effects 1.30.
Our study of "errors and corrections" aims to shed light on the complex mechanisms for implementing and recording corrective measures and to explain the various ways in which these mechanisms can guide our audit work.
In some areas of expenditure, new instruments will be available to the Commission when expenditure is incurred for the new programming period.
Corrective measures 1.31.
We seek to take account of corrective measures taken by the Member States and the Commission in advance of payment or our investigation.
We also note corrections that take place after our audit announcement. However, we cannot reduce the estimated error rate whenever the audit itself triggers the corrective action (24).
We review the application of these corrections (including recoveries from beneficiaries and corrections at project level) and, where appropriate, adjust the calculation of the error rate.
However, the impact of the corrective measures varies considerably depending on the expenditure area and on the corrective action.
1.32.
The Commission and the authorities of the Member States had applied corrective measures for 24 of the operations assessed in a sample in 2014, which had a direct impact on the operation concerned and were relevant to our calculations.
These corrective measures resulted in a reduction of our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (2013: 1.6 percentage points), which is approximately EUR 1.6 billion.
Changes in the number of operations concerned and the impact on our estimated error rate are not an indication that the corrective measures are more or less effective: since these measures apply to a relatively small proportion of our sample, fluctuations are expected from year to year.
1.30.
The Commission considers that the Court's annual representative error rate should be considered in the context of the Commission's corrective capacity in the various annual activity reports and the synthesis report.
The Financial Regulation requires appropriate consideration of the risks related to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the control systems and the nature of the payments.
1.31.

For a breakdown of the figures by policy area, see Table 1 in the synthesis report.
The Commission underlines that all types of financial corrections and recoveries exclude illegitimate expenditure from the reimbursement from the EU budget (see explanatory note 6 on the financial statements).

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.35.
The corrective measures discussed in this section of the annual report shall also include the work of the Member States' authorities and the recovery operations carried out by the national authorities and the Commission.
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES The impact of corrective measures is, to a large extent, tangible at the time when the Commission accepts expenditure 1.36.
All relevant sectoral regulations in the area of shared management contain rules on the primary controls to be carried out by national authorities or reductions in the amounts claimed by the final beneficiaries before the expenditure is certified.
In some cases, national authorities also agree to reduce or cancel certain costs which are constantly included in the declarations due to errors with long-term implications (such as ongoing payments under a contract where there is an error in the procurement rules).
Such adjustments may have a measurable impact on the amount of refund requested for individual projects or on the aid paid to individual farmers, and the correction will then help to reduce our estimated error rate.
1.37.
In the field of direct and indirect management, the ‘recoveries' covered by the Commission include the deduction of ineligible amounts for cost applications before the payment is authorised.
The eligibility of the amounts shall be established on the basis of the examination of the file of the available documents or on the basis of the results of the checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7).
This also allows us to reduce our estimated error rate.
Conformity decisions ("financial corrections" in the agricultural field) are often made on a flat-rate basis.
In general, they relate to system deficiencies rather than to errors at the level of the final beneficiaries.
In the rarest cases, they result in recovery of the farmers concerned.
Such corrective measures are an incentive for Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of operations at the level of the final beneficiaries if they lead to constant improvements in the cost statements accepted by the paying agencies (see boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
The Commission services also carry out recoveries ‘at source' by deducting ineligible expenditure (as determined in previous or current cost statements) from payments made.
1.38.
Financial corrections made by the Commission for agricultural expenditure are intended to protect the EU budget and are imposed on the Member States.
They do not directly result in the recovery of farmers, since the Commission does not pay the final beneficiaries directly, but reimburses the payments made by the Member States to farmers.
However, if these irregular payments are identifiable as a result of the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect Member States to pursue them by means of recovery measures against the beneficiaries.
See answer to Box 1.3.
Payers implement conformity decisions by reducing future applications for reimbursement by the Commission for payments to farmers.
The Commission shall record the full amount paid out to farmers as expenditure, i.e. the adjustment shall not entail a reduction in the amount of the payments recorded.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and refunds to paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26).
More than two-thirds of the "financial corrections" covered in the cohesion area in 2014 consist in replacing new expenditure,...
1.40.
In the cohesion field, "financial corrections" account for more than two-thirds of the total amount covered in cases where the authorities in the Member States withdraw expenditure declared and replace it with new expenditure.
In some cases, "reductions" do not identify any concrete projects as being withdrawn.
Instead, Member States report additional projects and thus receive a de facto lower co-financing rate.
1.40. The Commission considers that any financial corrections, including those allowing Member States to contribute new projects and new expenditure to reuse the corrected amounts, protect the EU budget against unlawful expenditure and encourage Member States to recover from beneficiaries (and thus contribute to improving management and control systems).
Nevertheless, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, in which Member States cannot reuse the corrected and recovered amounts and thus lose funds, is certainly higher.
(26) For example, if an agricultural paying agency is subject to a 5% financial correction and makes payments of EUR 100 million to farmers, the Commission will reimburse it EUR 95 million, but the Commission, for its part, will record expenditure of EUR 100 million, which will be offset by assigned revenue of EUR 5 million.
C 373/34 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS OF THE HOFES... while net corrections are less frequent 1.41.
If a replacement is not possible, the corrections for the Member State concerned will result in a loss of EU funds(27), which, although relatively rare, may occur if Member States are unable to provide sufficient eligible expenditure and if a replacement is no longer possible (28) or allowed (29).
The Commission anticipates that, as a result of amendments to the legislation, net corrections will be more widely applied in the future. 1.41.
Following the example of agriculture, the legislator has decided to apply a similar mechanism of net financial corrections for the 2014-2020 programming period to cohesion policy.
This will give Member States an additional incentive to prevent or detect and remedy serious deficiencies in the management and control systems before the financial statements are sent to the Commission.
Otherwise, and if serious deficiencies continue to be identified by the Commission or the Court following the transmission of the financial statements, the Commission must make net financial corrections under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, which means that the funds are lost for the Member State.
The Commission also considers that, under shared management, all financial corrections and recoveries have a negative impact on national budgets, irrespective of the method of implementation.
In order to avoid a loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace non-eligible expenditure with additional eligible operations.
This means that the Member State with its national budget must bear the financial consequences of the loss of EU co-financing of expenditure deemed to be ineligible, unless it recovers the amounts from each beneficiary.
(27) Either as a reduction in payments or as a return to the EU budget leading to assigned revenue (see Figure 2.2).
(28) After completion of the programmes.
(29) In the event of disagreement between Member States and the Commission (see point 1.25(b) of the 2012 annual report).
10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION C 373/35 THE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES In 2014, the Commission and Member States applied all these forms of corrective measures 1.42.
Box 1.2-1.4 illustrates different types and effects of corrective measures. Box 1.2 — Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: adjustment of the land identification system The Commission has taken measures to ensure the improvement of the system for identifying agricultural parcels (LPIS) which serves as a basis for payments to agricultural holdings, such as the single payment scheme (the largest single EU expenditure scheme).
This process took place at different stages and resulted in the ‘Eligible permanent pasture' covered by the Greek LPIS, falling from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014.
Non-legislative applications for ‘permanent grassland', which is not eligible for EU aid, has been a key factor in our estimated error rate for ‘natural resources' for several years.
We took into account the impact of corrections in respect of individual payments made to final beneficiaries, which were the subject of our sample of operations carried out by the EAGF and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Another effect is that the paying agency rejected many non-eligible applications, which resulted in the corresponding expenditure falling out of our sample.
Box 1.2 — Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: cleaning up the area identification system Other examples of the positive impact of action plans are given by the Court in Chapter 7.
Action plans are implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission monitors their implementation with great care and reports on the corrective actions taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
The area identification system shall prevent beneficiaries from claiming claims for non-existent land or not meeting the eligibility criteria, or for land for which claims have already been made by another beneficiary.
If properly implemented, it is a very effective tool to reduce the error rate.
It covers 75% of CAP expenditure.
The 2014 Annual Activity Report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development shows that the error rates for area-related payments are lower than for other measures.
C 373/36 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Box 1.3 — Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures (30) — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers In 2014, France accepted an adjustment of EUR 1.1 billion (984 million for the EAGF and EUR 94 million for the EAFRD)(31).
The national authorities stated that this would have no consequences for farmers and the amount would be disputed from the national budget.
In previous annual reports, we pointed out that such an approach does not encourage beneficiaries to correct errors (32).
The main reasons for the correction were shortcomings in LPIS/GIS (695 million euros) and the exceedance of the ceiling for payment entitlements, resulting in excessive payments to farmers (141 million euros).
A further reason, albeit to a lesser extent, was violations of the cross compliance obligation of timely notification of movements of animals (123 million euros).
All of these reasons are related to payments made between 2009 and 2013.
No adjustment was made for 2014 and the non-compliance with the ceiling for payment entitlements and the non-eligible areas covered by the LPIS of France contributed 0.3 percentage points to our estimated error rate for ‘Natural resources' this year.
Box 1.3 — Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers Under shared management, Member States are responsible for ensuring that the control systems function properly.
The EUR 1.1 billion financial correction will be repaid to the EU budget in three annual instalments (2015, 2016 and 2017).
The Commission would point out that the nature of the conformity clearance procedure, which applies ex-post, makes it very rare after the closure of the accounts of the year and after a counter-dictatory period in which the Member State concerned can present its own reasoning and calculation that a financial correction is already decided in the following year of the expenditure in question.
An ongoing conformity clearance procedure will protect the EU budget for 2014.

This was also the case in 2014.
Some of the projects we have examined continue to cause errors due to problems not covered by the corrections.
In its Annual Activity Report for 2014, the Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion (DG EMPL) pointed out that it continued to follow the implementation of the agreed action plan.
The financial corrections made do not necessarily mean that Romania will receive less EU funds, as Member States can make use of the possibility of making use of a larger amount of expenditure (33).

Each Directorate-General of the Commission shall draw up an annual activity report.
This report shall include — a report on the achievement of the main policy objectives (referred to in Chapter 3), — a management report from the Director-General to the College of Commissioners, and — a statement by the Director-General to ensure that the financial information contained in the report is properly presented and that the transactions falling within his/her area of responsibility are lawful and proper.
1.43.
The legislator has provided the Commission with the instrument of financial corrections to ensure that unlawful expenditure is not financed from the EU budget.
These financial corrections relate mainly to system deficiencies that lead to a risk of error.
It is the responsibility of the Member States and not of the Commission to identify improper amounts and recover them from the beneficiaries.
If this does not happen, EU funds will be replaced by national funds, as national budgets will have to bear the burden of financial corrections.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/39 DE HOFES COMMENTS Box 1.5 — Reservations in Annual Activity Reports 2014 In 2014, the Directors-General made a total of 20 quantified reservations as compared to 17 in 2013.
The increase in the total number of reservations is due to three new reservations from the Directors-General of the Directorates-General for Communications Networks, Content and Technology (DG CONNECT) (37) and Neighbourhood Policy and Enlargement Negotiations (DG NEAR)(38)(39) and the Service for Foreign Policy Instruments (FPI) (40); — the division of a recurring reservation into two reservations (41); — the abolition of a reservation (42).
In 2014, the expenditure figure with a reservation decreased from 2.4 billion euros in 2013 to 2.3 billion euros in 2014 (43).
1.49.
The European Parliament resolution on the 2013 discharge(44) calls on the Commission ‘to further clarify the calculation of the risk amount by explaining the estimated impact of correction mechanisms on that figure'.
(37) Reservation concerning the Information and Communication Technology Policy Support Programme (ICT) of the countries participating in the Competitiveness and Innovation Framework Programme (CIP), as the residual error rate exceeds 2% (2.94%).
(38) reservation regarding indirect management by the beneficiary countries, as the residual error rate is above 2 % (2,67 %).
(39) The problems identified in the 2013 annual report gave rise to a new reservation on reputational grounds by DG NEAR (formerly DG ELARG), see paragraph 7.16 of the 2013 annual report).
(40) Reservation on expenditure under the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP), as the residual error rate exceeds 2% (2.13%).
(41) The Directorate-General for Regional Policy and Urban Development (DG REGIO) divided its recurring reservation on the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF)/Cohesion Fund (CF)/ Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) into two reservations, one on the ERDF/CF and the other on the IPA.
(42) The Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (DG SANTE) has lifted its reservation regarding the programmes for the eradication and monitoring of animal diseases in the food and feed policy area.
(43) See synthesis report, Annex 2.
(44) Report on discharge in respect of the implementation of the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2013, Section III — Commission and executive agencies 2014/2075 (DEC) (A8-001/2015).
THE COMMENTS OF THE COURT 1.50.
In accordance with the request from the discharge authority, the Commission further developed its internal guidance (45) on the presentation of information in Annual Activity Reports in 2014.
The Directors-General are now to present an "average detected error rate" (46).
The application of this error rate to the total payments of the year leads to the calculation of the ‘risk amount'(47).
The synthesis report identifies this amount together with the estimate of the future correction capacity of ex post controls carried out by the Commission. The Commission acknowledges that the expenditure is significantly affected by errors...
1.51.
In the 2014 synthesis report, the Commission identified the ‘risk amount' as a range of between EUR 3.7 billion and EUR 5 billion.
This represents between 2,6 % and 3,5 % of the payments for 2014(48) covered by the synthesis report.
These figures show that total expenditure is significantly affected by errors.... however, points to the estimated impact of future corrections 1.52.
The 2014 synthesis report provides an estimated total of estimated future corrections (correction capacity).
On the basis of the corrections recorded during the last six years(49), the Commission estimates that in the coming years it will be able to "identify and correct errors of around EUR 2700 million in total" (50).
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC(2014) 553).
(46) This is the detected or estimated error rate at the time of payment (not the residual error rate), i.e. without adjustment due to subsequently corrected errors.
